headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2015 Welltower's Earnings Conference Call. My name is Colleia, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2015 Welltower's Earnings Conference Call. My name is Colleia, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
Now I would like to turn the call over to Jeff Mueller, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Colleia. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today for about hours fourth quarter 2015 conference call. If you did not receive a copy of the news release distributed this morning, you may access it via the company's website at
componenttext:
Thank you, Colleia. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today for about hours fourth quarter 2015 conference call. If you did not receive a copy of the news release distributed this morning, you may access it via the company's website at welltower.com. We are holding a live webcast of today's call, which may be accessed through the company's website. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that certain statements made during this conference call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although Welltower believes results projected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, the company can give no assurance that its projected results will be attained. 
Factors and risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are detailed in the news release and from time to time, in the company's filings with the SEC. I will now turn the call over to our CEO, Tom DeRosa. Tom?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. I'm pleased that we finished 2015 with our strongest quarterly performance of the year. These results are driven by solid fundamentals, a disciplined investment thesis and the unique operating platform that we have developed and employed at
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. I'm pleased that we finished 2015 with our strongest quarterly performance of the year. These results are driven by solid fundamentals, a disciplined investment thesis and the unique operating platform that we have developed and employed at Welltower over many years. 
Today, I want to highlight 3 topics that are top-of-mind: capital allocation, genesis and senior housing supply. On to the first topic: Capital allocation. This is the most important exercise of any management team and how I spend most of my time. We think about this as the framework for how we maximize shareholder returns. Essentially, every public company has 5 primary ways to deploy capital: acquisitions, investing in the existing business, paying down debt, paying dividends and buying back stock. And four ways to raise capital: internal cash flow, issuing debt, issuing equity, and disposing of assets. So as the equity capital markets were favorable, we took full advantage and built the industry-leading health care real estate portfolio. For us, it was not about winning a pie eating contest, but building unmatched local scale in major metro markets with the best operators in the business. Simply put, we have created a real operating platform, not a passive collection of assets in which success is measured only by year 1 after FO accretion. The good news for our shareholders is we don't take access to the capital markets for granted, and we don't gamble with our shareholder capital. Hence, we took advantage of the strong equity markets to significantly delever our balance sheet.  Now at a less than accommodating public capital market, we are sitting in an enviable position. 
We are also proud that in 2015, the Canadian pension plan, one of the largest investors in commercial real estate in the world, chose Welltower to be its joint-venture partner to make its first investments in health care real estate. Scott Brinker will talk about our most recent venture with CPP as well as our ongoing successful partnership with PSP. 
Welltower has always seen targeted dispositions as an important component of our capital allocation strategy, and 2015 was no exception. We sold the strategic assets, such as our last U.S. hospital asset, realizing an 11% unlevered IRR, and we took advantage of robust pricing and sold our life science portfolio at a 5% yield, realizing an unlevered IRR of 15%. May I remind you that we have sold $4 billion in assets over the last 5 years for cash and used that cash to buy better quality real estate and delever the balance sheet. 
Over the medium-term, we still see opportunity for targeted acquisitions to go deeper into markets where we have local scale in our senior housing business, and we also see enormous opportunity to grow our outpatient medical business. But only with the best health systems in this country. 
I talked about our desire to develop relationships with the leading academic medical centers on my very first investor call in May 2014. I told you that this would not happen overnight as institutions like Johns Hopkins and Cleveland Clinic really don't need our capital. However, increasingly, what they do realize they need from Welltower is our expertise in seniors housing, residential Alzheimer's care and read my lips, post-acute care, and the connectivity of the best-in-class operators that we bring to the table. I'm happy to tell you that these discussions are now starting to bear fruit and, for example, we now own 3 facilities with Johns Hopkins, which is the number one rated health system in the United States. 
So to talk about Genesis. I want to make it very clear, we believe in Genesis and the value that post-acute operators, like Genesis, bring to lowering health care costs and improving outcomes. 
The challenges facing the post-acute industry as a transition to a value-based care system are well known. If you sit with the CEOs of the leading nonprofit health systems in the U.S. like we do at Welltower, they realize that they need to connect to this expertise more than ever as they move to the reality of bundled payments. Have you seen the performance of the for-profit acute care hospital sector lately? After a brief benefit from the ACA that peaked in the second quarter of 2015, the cold reality is that higher co-pays are translating into a drop in hospital visits. This is why Welltower, as of year end 2015, no longer owns acute care hospitals in the U.S. We believe operating in margin pressures will push acute care operators to move patients to lower cost outpatient and post-acute settings. 
We are optimistic that operators like Genesis, that are delivering next-generation post-acute care, will become the preferred providers to the top end health systems and add a large inventory of low Q-Mix sniffs get taken out of service. 
We understand the market is a voting machine in the short run and the votes are in. While the market has implied the destruction of the majority of the equity value in our investment in Genesis, I can assure you that there is significant value in this relationship and in this investment. Scott Brinker is going to talk more about that in detail. 
Finally, to the topic of senior housing supply. You may recall we had a long discussion about this topic on the third quarter call. We continue to believe the fear of supply in the U.S. is overblown. There's no doubt that certain markets are oversupplied, but we are primarily in markets where it is difficult to build and hence, believe our performance will be resilient. You can look at the portfolio performance this quarter as evidence of this resiliency, as senior housing operating occupancy is rebounded sequentially, up 80 basis points, and same-store NOI was up 4.3% in the U.S. 
Like most companies in health care, and I know you're seeing this in the retail sector as well, we are seeing wage pressure in some parts of the U.S. due to increases in the minimum wage, and we're seeing it in the U.K. due to the imposition of the national living wage. Increased supply where it has impact will most likely exacerbate that problem. We are working with our operating partners to capture new labor efficiencies and identify opportunities for enhanced pricing power. 
In conclusion, we believe we have a superior portfolio in superior markets, best-in-class operating and capital partners and a seasoned team to execute across all markets. With the right assets in the right markets, we will prove the thesis that health care real estate has lower downside and better upside over the cycle. 
Now I'll turn it over to Scott Brinker.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. We took forward advantage of the up cycle. We now have unmatched scale in the markets where you want to own real estate. 77 properties in Southern California, 47 in greater London and 281 on the eastern seaboard from Boston to D.C. Our his
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. We took forward advantage of the up cycle. We now have unmatched scale in the markets where you want to own real estate. 77 properties in Southern California, 47 in greater London and 281 on the eastern seaboard from Boston to D.C. Our history in the business tells us these markets will produce superior results. 
We're entering a period of increased separation among companies. Our real estate quality will stand out more than ever. Each business segment turned in a strong fourth quarter, the results showed that our capital allocation is paying off. The operating portfolio trended higher, with 3.3% same-store NOI growth. Fundamentals are solid. Occupancy was up 20 basis points and rates increased 3.2%. Importantly, we're not buying the growth, as CapEx remains at very modest levels. The age of our properties is a material competitive advantage. 
Performance in the U.S. continues to be strong, with 4.3% same-store NOI growth. Large metro markets once again outperformed, validating our capital allocation. 
Same-store NOI in Canada grew 4.6%, despite an economy with near 0 inflation, highlighting the resiliency of our business. The U.K. portfolio is poised for a rebound this year based on recent revenue trends. 
Several Wall Street analysts recently ranked our outpatient medical portfolio as #1 in asset quality. The impact can be seen in our results. We hit all-time highs in occupancy and tenant retention last year, leading to another solid quarter, with 3.1% same-store NOI growth. Visibility is the key word here, and there are 3 drivers: one, very little lease rollover; two, when leases do roll, we typically renew more than 80% of them; and three, nearly all of our buildings are sponsored by health system. That's important because they act as a magnet for other tenants. The space leased directly to a health system is climbing and now sits at 60%. We see that number moving even higher as hospitals transition more and more services to outpatient settings. 
I'll move to triple net, a highly visible income stream that contributes half of our earnings. Same-store seniors housing NOI increased 3.2%, while post-acute long-term care increased 3.1%. 
We've been eagerly anticipating a chance to talk about the next topic, which is Genesis. Dramatic underperformance by managed care who is not in our portfolio is unfairly implicating Genesis, if not, the entire industry. Industry headwinds clearly exist, but they are not new. In fact, we've been preparing for years, including selling nearly $1 billion of last generation skilled nursing assets. And rather than focusing exclusively on the short-term headwinds, we also considered the bigger picture. According to Avalir, a highly regarded research firm, the dramatic increase in the Medicare population will more than offset the decline in length of stay and per capita utilization. As a result, the number of skilled nursing Medicare days is expected to increase by more than 10% over the next 5 years. That data reminds us that skilled nursing plays an important role in cost effective health care delivery. 
There's a reason we haven't suffered any lease rejections or rent reductions like other skilled nursing landlords. One, strong payment coverage. The cash flow from the Genesis properties that we own fully supports the rent payment to Genesis -- to Welltower. Our Genesis properties generate nearly $1.60 of operating income for every $1 of rent. Given the profitability inside the walls of our buildings that parent guarantee is simply an additional security blanket. And that parent guarantee does have value. Parent company fixed charge coverage increased last year and Genesis expects further improvement this year to north of 1.3x. 
Two, we've been actively managing the portfolio since the day we closed the sale lease back 5 years ago. That includes selling underperforming buildings, funding new development and acquisitions with strong coverage and facilitating mergers that generate synergies. And three, Genesis is a superior operator. Despite the challenging environment, our property level of Genesis payment coverage is only 1 basis point lower than it was 4 years ago -- 1 basis point. Property level EBITDAR increased a healthy 2.5% per year during that period. And remember that we own the legacy Genesis portfolio, which is concentrated in the mid-Atlantic and New England. These are hands down, their absolute core assets. 
Final comment here is that we expect Genesis to refinance our mortgage loans, with significant pay downs coming this year in line with the business plan. 
Turning to 4Q investments. We closed $1.5 billion at a 6.8% initial yield. It's fair to say that 2016 investment of volume will look much different than previous years. Capital allocation helped drive our historical outperformance and remained a top priority. Every day, we looked at the relationship between cap rates and our cost of capital. Discrepancies, plus or minus, provide an opportunity to create value. We have the luxury of not needing to make any rash decisions but if buyers have an aggressive yield asset value, we'll be happy to crystallize value in select properties. 
By design, our investment pipeline is quite limited today, and we can fully fund it with operating cash flow and in-process asset sales. 
I want to share color on a new relationship, a superb operator called Discovery Senior Living. Last quarter, we acquired 6 high-performing independent living communities in Florida that Discovery built and will continue to co-own and manage. The properties are typically 100% full with a waiting list. Significant renovations are nearly complete, which would allow Discovery to market the properties at a higher price point, generating strong earnings growth. 
To fund the acquisition, we partnered with the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, or CPP. This marks their first investment in U.S. senior housing, again highlighting the confidence in our platform by one of the world's leading investors. 
The other major acquisition last quarter was with Riviera, where we partnered with PSP, a long time and important pension fund partner of ours. The acquisition deepens our large metro market footprint. Welltower will receive a 6.1% preferred return that grows by 4% per year through 2020. We sold our final U.S. inpatient hospital last quarter. The number of hospital beds has been nearly cut in half the past few decades and there are foreclosures coming. The old physical plants require massive CapEx and even then, the buildings are often unprepared for advances in technology. 
We also see an adverse selection problem. The hospitals looking for sale-leasebacks are too often the ones you don't want to do business with. 
I'll wrap up with our excitement about the current environment. The last down cycle laid the foundation for what Welltower has come. The next few years will be the ideal environment to take another leap forward. 
Now, to Scott Estes.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. My financial message today echoes the capital allocation team that has been essential to our long-term successes and organization. Calendar 2015 was an important year for HCN and that we positioned the balance sh
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. My financial message today echoes the capital allocation team that has been essential to our long-term successes and organization. Calendar 2015 was an important year for HCN and that we positioned the balance sheet for the current period of volatility by opportunistically raising equity in response to the strength of our investment pipeline. 90% of the investments closed in the fourth quarter of 2015 were negotiated during the first half of the year. And while there's always an urge to perfectly time the equity market, we're glad that we chose to prefund the majority of this activity, allowing us to end the year with essentially the same conservative leverage ratios that we started within 2015. 
While we're poised to generate another year of solid financial results and dividend growth in 2016, our net asset seller message and public guidance for the upcoming year reflects our current mindset of remaining both disciplined and opportunistic while protecting our downside. More specifically, our ability to utilize dispositions as a source of capital in the current environment should provide multiple benefits. It should allow us to maintain or further reduce leverage. We can enhance our asset quality in private pay mix, and we can maintain adequate liquidity and execute our 2016 capital plan within a self-funded framework. 
Given the recent uncertainty surrounding the macroeconomic fact drop, our conservative approach leaves us well-positioned to wait out the current storm as we continue to appropriately allocate capital to maximize shareholder value. 
I'll begin my more detailed remarks with perspective on our fourth quarter financial performance and changes in our supplemental disclosure. As Tom said, we had a great fourth quarter as normalized FFO came in at $1.13 per share and normalized FAD was $0.99 per share, representing strong 10% and 9% year-over-year increases, respectively. Results were driven primarily by the solid same-store cash NOI increase, averaging 3.1% for the full year, and the $3.6 billion of net investments completed over the last 12 months. 
I note that our FFO and FAD payout ratios for the fourth quarter declined to 73% and 83%, respectively. There were two noteworthy items on our income statement this quarter that I'd like to take a moment to explain. First, we incurred $35.6 million in other expenses this quarter which represented a noncash charge related to marking the value of our Genesis stockholdings to market at year end. And as a reminder, we essentially received our initial $58.5 million in stock for free and as represented the amount our purchase option for 9.9% of Genesis within the money at the time they went public. 
Conversely on the positive side of the ledger, we realized a gain on the sale of asset of $31.4 million in the quarter, which is largely due to the profitable disposition of our final U.S. acute care hospital during the period. 
In terms of dividends, we'll pay our 179th consecutive quarterly cash dividend on February 22 of $0.86 per share. This new annualized rate of $3.44 per share represents a 4.2% increase over our 2015 dividend level and a current yield of 6.1%. 
In terms of our supplement this quarter, the only notable changes on page 2 where we did add a table providing detail on the number and dollar value of the individual acquisitions and joint ventures completed each year. 
Turning next to our liquidity picture and balance sheet. The fourth quarter was an active one in terms of capital raising activity for the company. In October, we completed the sale of $500 million of unsecured debt, price yields of just under 4.3% through a reopening of our 10-year notes due June 2025. And in November, we successfully tapped the Canadian senior note market for the first time in our history, completing the sale of CAD 300 million of 5-year notes, priced yield just over 3.4%. 
In terms of equity, we issued 1.1 million common shares under our dividend reinvestment program, generating $66 million in proceeds, and we tapped our ATM program for the first time since 2012, issuing 696,000 shares at an average price of $69.23, raising another $47 million. 
We also generated $225 million of proceeds through the sale of non-strategic assets and loan payoffs. And finally, we repaid approximately $104 million of secured debt at a blended rate of 5.9% and assumed or issued $674 million of secured debt at a blended 3.3% rate. 
So importantly, as a result, we have over $2 billion of liquidity entering 2016, with only $350 million of line borrowings, net of the $361 million in cash on balance sheet and the $124 million of cash received from CPP's Discovery portfolio buy-ins subsequent to year-end. 
Our balance sheet and financial metrics at the end of 2015 remain in excellent shape. As of December 31, our net debt to undepreciated book capitalization was 39.9% and net debt to enterprise value was 32.7%. 
Our net debt-to-adjusted-EBITDA stood at 5.6x, while our adjusted interest and fixed charge coverage for the quarter was strong at 4.3x and 3.4x, respectively. Our secured debt level remained at only 12% of total assets to quarter end. 
In light of the recent strength of the U.S. dollar against both the pound sterling and the Canadian dollar, I would like to remind you of our hedging strategy entering 2016. We've minimized any material risk as a result of exchange rate fluctuations. Through a combination of unsecured and property level debt denominated in local currencies and other currency hedges in place, our international investments are approximately 87% hedged from a balance sheet perspective and 83% hedged from an earnings perspective. So as a result, the sensitivity of both currencies moving 10% in relation to the U.S. dollar from current levels would impact our earnings either up or down by only $0.01 per share this year. 
Finally, I'll conclude my comments today with an overview of the key assumptions driving our 2016 guidance. In terms of same-store cash NOI growth, we're forecasting blended growth of 2.5% to 3% in 2016, as we continue to project solid predictable internal growth across our portfolio. 
To further break down this forecast by asset type, first, for our seniors housing operating portfolio, we're projecting growth in the 2% to 3% range as we remain confident in the operating environment and our operator's relative performance. 
For our seniors housing triple net portfolio, we anticipate growth of approximately 2.5% to 3%. For our long-term care post-acute portfolio, we're projecting an increase of approximately 3%. And last, for our outpatient medical portfolio, we project an increase of approximately 2% to 2.5%, driven primarily by annual rate increases, continued strong occupancy, very low turnover and a retention rate of approximately 80%. 
In terms of our investment expectations, there are no acquisitions beyond what we've announced to date in our formal guidance. As a result, the only acquisitions included in our 2016 guidance are the approximate $163 million of investments through our main street partnership and an initial cash yield of approximately 7.5%. Our 2016 guidance also includes $419 million of development conversions at a blended projected yield of 8.2%. 
In terms of dispositions, we've included $1 billion of dispositions in our forecast. This is comprised of $178 million of proceeds from assets currently held for sale at a blended yield on sale of 7.2%, with the remainder representing loan payoffs and other potential property sales. 
Although we prefer to avoid any specifics of what we might sell this year, Tom said earlier, we have a successful history of selling not only non-strategic assets, but also more opportunistic asset sales to lock in attractive values. My point here is that we have multiple options in our approach to sales this year and believe there are no pools of assets that are off limits as we evaluate asset sales to most efficiently allocate capital. 
Our capital expenditure forecast this year is $83 million, which is comprised of approximately $55 million associated with the seniors housing operating portfolio, with the remaining $28 million coming from our medical facilities portfolio. As Scott mentioned, these amounts continue to represent a relatively modest 7% to 8% of anticipated NOI in both asset categories due to our generally more modern portfolio. 
Our G&A forecast is approximately $160 million to $165 million for 2016, as the majority of growth on a year-over-year basis is due to the annualized 2016 impact of hires and infrastructure investments made during 2015. We remain very comfortable with these spending levels to support the continued growth of the organization. 
I would also note that we expect first quarter G&A to be slightly higher than the average for the year as it typically includes accelerated expensing of stock-based compensation for certain employees and directors. 
We anticipate incurring income tax expense of approximately $16 million to $18 million in 2016, based on our latest estimation of taxable income that is largely generated by our seniors housing operating portfolio. 
And finally, as a result of all these assumptions, we expect to report 2016 FFO in a range of 4 50 to 4 60 per diluted share, and FAD in the range of 3 95 to 4 05 per diluted share, both of which represents 3% to 5% growth over normalized 2015 results. 
So in conclusion, our focus on capital allocation entering 2016 prioritizes enhancing the quality of our portfolio and private pay mix, maintaining a strong balance sheet and low leverage, and retaining ample liquidity until the broader capital markets environment improves. 
So at this point in time, I'll turn it back to you for your closing remarks.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. I want to leave you with the message that we are confident in our ability to create shareholder value in 2016 and beyond. Let me remind you that when senior housing was in disarray because of lack of capital post financial crisis or because
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. I want to leave you with the message that we are confident in our ability to create shareholder value in 2016 and beyond. Let me remind you that when senior housing was in disarray because of lack of capital post financial crisis or because of the oversupply in the early part of the century, our shareholders benefited tremendously and we grew exponentially by recapitalizing the industry. 
Today, we are in the strongest position we have ever been with our leading balance sheet, long-term institutional capital partners like CPP and PSP, our portfolio of best-in-class operators, significant local scale in top markets, and a deep understanding of how all these worked together as a real operating platform, not a financially engineered yield portfolio. 
I could not be more excited about what lies ahead for Welltower. So for the Q&A, we have a few other folks in the room here. We've got two that are well known to you, Paul [indiscernible] and Steve Schroeder. And two that are new on the Q&A but who I think are well known to lots of people on the phone, Tim Hardin and Mitra. 
So now Colleia, please open up the line for questions.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is a from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is a from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about this shop same-store cash NOI, the 2% to 3% in 2016, and want to understand sort of what the buildup is there, and how you think about that sort of long-term sustainable. I know you guys have talked about a range, maybe slightly higher
componenttext: Wanted to ask about this shop same-store cash NOI, the 2% to 3% in 2016, and want to understand sort of what the buildup is there, and how you think about that sort of long-term sustainable. I know you guys have talked about a range, maybe slightly higher than that and obviously, you've operated a lot higher than that. And then I guess, as part of that, I know last quarter, you talked about these five facilities in the Northeast that has some flu issues that were 130-basis-point drag. Any update on those specifics? And I'm assuming the flu's a little bit more helpful now?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's for sure. Less flu and less snow this year in the markets that kind of crushed us last year with snow removal costs and labor cost because of difficulty in getting to and from the facilities.
componenttext: Yes, that's for sure. Less flu and less snow this year in the markets that kind of crushed us last year with snow removal costs and labor cost because of difficulty in getting to and from the facilities.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So Josh, I'm happy to answer that. Scott Brinker here. There a couple of questions. I'll try to remember them one at a time. The first, I think, was the 2% to 3% growth outlook and how did we get there. And from where we sit today, our same-store o
componenttext: Great. So Josh, I'm happy to answer that. Scott Brinker here. There a couple of questions. I'll try to remember them one at a time. The first, I think, was the 2% to 3% growth outlook and how did we get there. And from where we sit today, our same-store occupancy is slightly above last year, so that's a good starting point. I've said on a number of occasions that 90-plus percent of NOI in the senior housing space can be explained in 3 variables: Occupancy rate in labor. So I just talked about one of them. Occupancy looks good, but we've been conservative in our guidance and assumed essentially no change in occupancy through the year. Just given what's happening in the economy and the recent new supply, hopefully, we'll be better than that, but that's what's within our guidance. And then on rate, we've continued to grow in the 3% to 3.5% range and that's generally what we expect in 2016. And the third component is labor, and that's probably the one where -- I wouldn't say we're worried, but it could be a bit higher this year than it has been recently. A number of stage and cities have increases in the minimum wage and certainly, the new supply in certain markets does impact the labor pool. So we're expecting compensation expense to be a bit higher in the rate growth this year in our budget. And that's what leads into the 2% to 3% projection for the year.  Now longer term, what I'd tell you is we projected in the 4% to 5%, when we made our first [indiscernible] investment more than 5 years ago. Obviously, we've done better than that on average. There will be fluctuations. We also probably didn't expect the inflation would be virtually 0 when we made that projection, which is where it's at today in a lot of our core markets and yet we're still growing in the low 3s. So what we feel confident in is that we'll continue to outperform this sector, which we've done year-after-year after year and then we'll outperform our peers. And that's probably a better way to answer the long-term growth outlook, Josh. It's so hard to say for sure what the overall economy is going to look like.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I'll add to that is you really have to look at the markets where our assets are located. These major metro markets are very difficult to bring new supply. You know we're very focused on major metro markets where we already have assets a
componenttext: And the only thing I'll add to that is you really have to look at the markets where our assets are located. These major metro markets are very difficult to bring new supply. You know we're very focused on major metro markets where we already have assets and where we're looking to bring additional supply. And I -- if you look at the aging of the population, there's going to be more and more demand and limited options, or especially for people who have dementia and Alzheimer's disease. So that's one of the reasons why we're still pretty bullish on at least our portfolio and how it will perform over the long term.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

But is that something within the relationship that you guys are talking about?

Is there any hope that we can get that sort of reported on a real-time basis? Is there anything you can say anecdotally, I guess, about how the coverage changed in Q4 based on the results?

So they announced their -- preannounced their corporate a couple of weeks ago, but you'll probably remember, it was quite limited, what they talked about. And until they announce their full earnings next week, we're just unfortunately not in a position to really say much more. It's just -- if we have the data, we'd like to talk about it but we can't.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. Number two, Scott, can you talk a little bit about the loan advances you made in the fourth quarter? You guys lent out $183 million and brought the full year total October to $700 million. Can you talk a little bit about what types of lo
componenttext: That makes sense. Number two, Scott, can you talk a little bit about the loan advances you made in the fourth quarter? You guys lent out $183 million and brought the full year total October to $700 million. Can you talk a little bit about what types of loans were these? Were these construction loans? Bridge loans? Perm financing? And maybe talk about the underwriting what were the LTEs interest coverage? Can you give us some color on all of that?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Be happy to, Ross. These are mortgage loans that are very similar to what we did to help them finance the skilled help acquisition in early 2015. So when they closed on the portfolio acquisition with Revera in the fourth quarter, we provided some short-te
componenttext: Be happy to, Ross. These are mortgage loans that are very similar to what we did to help them finance the skilled help acquisition in early 2015. So when they closed on the portfolio acquisition with Revera in the fourth quarter, we provided some short-term fully secured mortgage financing to help them accomplish that transaction. On a long-term plan in both cases is that they will bring these properties to HUD and replace our, I'll call it, high-cost financing at 8-plus percent with very high escalators with lower cost in the 4% range, HUD financing that's nonrecourse and has a 30-year term. So that's what the majority -- the vast majority of the loan volume in the fourth quarter represents, Ross. It's just a mortgage loan to help them finance that Revera acquisition, and we expect it to be repaid over the next, call it 12 months.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And last question for me. Just based on current sources and uses of capital, if I look at the remaining development spend, that looks like you got just a little over maybe 550-something-million for 2016 and '17 to fund the development side. So if I think
componenttext: And last question for me. Just based on current sources and uses of capital, if I look at the remaining development spend, that looks like you got just a little over maybe 550-something-million for 2016 and '17 to fund the development side. So if I think about match funding and capital recycling of call it, $1 billion, that just the rough numbers will leave another, call it, around, even, say, $400 million that could be deployed towards acquisitions on a leverage [indiscernible] basis? Is that a wrong way to be thinking about in rough terms what the acquisition the volume would be on a leverage neutral basis without returning to the equity markets or increasing dispositions?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's generally right, Ross. This is Scott Estes. We do have a -- one thing you didn't mention is we have $400 million of debt maturing in March. So the only other item that is contemplated in guidance is that we replaced that with prevailing rat
componenttext: I think that's generally right, Ross. This is Scott Estes. We do have a -- one thing you didn't mention is we have $400 million of debt maturing in March. So the only other item that is contemplated in guidance is that we replaced that with prevailing rates. So 10-year debt for us today is probably in the 4.4%, 4.5% range. But the 3 pieces for sources other than that are retained earnings. We obviously get about $300 million from our drip and then $1 billion of dispositions in addition to that.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: So you're going to leave the drip line?

componenttext: Yes, the drip, yes, not the ATM.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on your $1 million [ph] of disposition guidance, can you just elaborate who the buyers in the market are today? And how we should be thinking about cap rates? 9% in dispositions in the fourth quarter, but as you mentioned, 7.2% of that is h
componenttext: Okay. And then on your $1 million [ph] of disposition guidance, can you just elaborate who the buyers in the market are today? And how we should be thinking about cap rates? 9% in dispositions in the fourth quarter, but as you mentioned, 7.2% of that is held for sale. So how should we think about cap rates going forward?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the $1 billion is loan repayments. So the buyer is HUD rather than [indiscernible] think about as a buyer. The others that we have in process is, for the most part, private equity groups. You have to ask them about their return expectations
componenttext: Well, a lot of the $1 billion is loan repayments. So the buyer is HUD rather than [indiscernible] think about as a buyer. The others that we have in process is, for the most part, private equity groups. You have to ask them about their return expectations. I know ours have increased a bit. But I don't think there's been enough transaction volume, at least in Seniors housing, to know where cap rates are going, which is a medical office is such a liquid market part of buyers that I don't think the impact of the public share prices or the nontraded REITs no longer raising money has much of an impact in that sector. And we're seeing several skilled nursing portfolios very recently trends and cap rate that are really no different than what we've seen for years in that business. Seniors housing where it slowed down a bit, so I think a lot of people are wondering where cap rates were ultimately had.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, Genesis. I appreciate it has a reported full year results yet, but it did guide to a sequential decline in EBITDA in the fourth quarter. Can you just elaborate why you feel confident that their headwinds are not the same as [indiscernib
componenttext: Okay. And finally, Genesis. I appreciate it has a reported full year results yet, but it did guide to a sequential decline in EBITDA in the fourth quarter. Can you just elaborate why you feel confident that their headwinds are not the same as [indiscernible] given the patters, it seems like it's very similar?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean there are a long list of things that are different. Now I know a lot a lot more about Genesis then I took about. so by this time, I focus my comments on Genesis. But it gets back to the comments I made in my script, John. They clearly are faci
componenttext: Yes, I mean there are a long list of things that are different. Now I know a lot a lot more about Genesis then I took about. so by this time, I focus my comments on Genesis. But it gets back to the comments I made in my script, John. They clearly are facing some industry headwinds, but those headwinds aren't new has been an issue for years and years, putting pressure on net of stay and rate and Genesis has stayed ahead by getting out of certain assets, acquiring assets that are better fits for the current environment and actively managing their labor cost, which again, is the most significant operating expense. And the other thing I would mention is, they have a much lower Medicare mix and that probably has an impact on why they've held up better over the past 4 years because a lot of the pressure has been on the Medicare side of the business. And the other distinction I would make is the results of the corporate level. So I talked about property level cash flow being more than adequate to pay their rent, but there's also a huge difference in terms of the corporate cash flow, which provides a significant security blanket for our rent payment, and they've been able to grow that cash flow through merger synergies and they'll growth it going forward to refinancing and probably some asset buybacks.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Can you remind us what percentage of equity that you own?

componenttext: It's just over 4%, John.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chuck Vana core of the Stifel.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just looking at the shop portfolio, occupancy actually improved for the past couple of quarters. What are you seeing or expecting that you're factoring into get to your flat occupancy in 2016?
componenttext: So just looking at the shop portfolio, occupancy actually improved for the past couple of quarters. What are you seeing or expecting that you're factoring into get to your flat occupancy in 2016?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chad, we like the market position of our buildings in the vast majority of our locations. But I just -- remember, just back 12 months ago, when it seems like the day after we hung up on our fourth quarter earnings call, occupancy started to drop pretty qu
componenttext: Chad, we like the market position of our buildings in the vast majority of our locations. But I just -- remember, just back 12 months ago, when it seems like the day after we hung up on our fourth quarter earnings call, occupancy started to drop pretty quickly because of the flu. So that's just something that you can't predict, and we're taking a conservative approach here. I mentioned earlier that occupancy today, in the same-store pool, is above last year. So that implies that we should be in a good position, and we continue to see positive trends really in all 3 countries.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's in all 3 countries. I think, Scott, you might have mentioned that you expect a rebound in the U.K., how should we think about that given your occupancy starting on a much lower level now and how should we think about that growth?
componenttext: So it's in all 3 countries. I think, Scott, you might have mentioned that you expect a rebound in the U.K., how should we think about that given your occupancy starting on a much lower level now and how should we think about that growth?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is and it will probably ramp-up over the course of the year. And I get back to the comment I made about the 3 variables that really impact performance. The first is occupancy, and there's clearly a rebuilding that was necessary after the flu seaso
componenttext: Yes, it is and it will probably ramp-up over the course of the year. And I get back to the comment I made about the 3 variables that really impact performance. The first is occupancy, and there's clearly a rebuilding that was necessary after the flu season last year. But we've seen it. Across that portfolio, occupancy is coming back very strongly. The second variable being rate, and we continue to increase rates in the 3% range, if not higher this year. The third variable is more challenging and that's labor because of the impact of the living wage, which is up 7% throughout the country and even higher in other markets. So unrelated to anything that sunrise can control, there's just an external factor that's going to be a headwind on NOI growth this year.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: ROI. Just 1 last 1. So you've done several JVs with capital partners now. Can you talk about your thoughts about this capital partners are bringing in to the table? And why don't you just go in alone?
componenttext: ROI. Just 1 last 1. So you've done several JVs with capital partners now. Can you talk about your thoughts about this capital partners are bringing in to the table? And why don't you just go in alone?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they bring some of the largest pools of capital in the world. And Chad, we believe that there is going to be an increasing need for senior housing in the major metro markets. And if you think about the cost of building in midtown Manhattan or sensua
componenttext: Well, they bring some of the largest pools of capital in the world. And Chad, we believe that there is going to be an increasing need for senior housing in the major metro markets. And if you think about the cost of building in midtown Manhattan or sensual Washington, D.C. or San Francisco, it's significant and it's important that institutions like CPP now understand the investment thesis for deploying capital to seniors housing. The other piece of these is that we, again, very much believe that it's going to take trillions of dollars to rebuild the acute care hospital system in this country to basically accommodate technology that is with us today or will be developed in the future that will dramatically allow us to lower health care costs and improve outcomes. We have a lot of antiquated acute care hospital infrastructure in this country. So while I'd like to think we could go it alone and the capital markets will accommodate us to fund every bit of capital need that we will -- that we will need to build this infrastructure, we aren't that -- we're not that big of a gambler. So it's been very important for us to spend time with institutions like PSP and CPPIB. And we'll bring others in because I think they understand we're smart, and we can provide them opportunities that they cannot find on their own. And they will also see interesting opportunities to deploy capital at returns that possibly aren't available in other sectors, in the traditional sectors of real estate where they are one of the major owners.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chad, the other thing I would mention is they give us a lot of flexibility. Keep in mind that in a healthcare REIT, we can't operating companies, at least we can't own more than 35% of them. So Sunrise is an example. We love to own the whole thing, but we
componenttext: Chad, the other thing I would mention is they give us a lot of flexibility. Keep in mind that in a healthcare REIT, we can't operating companies, at least we can't own more than 35% of them. So Sunrise is an example. We love to own the whole thing, but we can't. So this is a company that's worth probably 500 plus million dollars. This is a big profitable company and the question is if health care REIT Welltower can only own up to 35% of that company, who owns the rest? There are very limited people that can write a check that size, private equities, one, but frankly, generally speaking, they don't align with our approach to business. So PSP, acting through Revera, owns the balance of Sunrise alongside of us, and that's just one example of how we are, I think, controlling our own destiny, helping shape the future of the industry through these ownership stakes that without a group like PSP, we would not be able to do.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Scott just said, we're a real long-term investor and these are long-term investors. They're not managing to a 7-year find return. So we think we're much more aligned with this investor class, and I think you'll see more of that from us.
componenttext: As Scott just said, we're a real long-term investor and these are long-term investors. They're not managing to a 7-year find return. So we think we're much more aligned with this investor class, and I think you'll see more of that from us.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the RIDEA growth across different geographies, could you just maybe give us a range sort of how that 2% to 3% would pan out in the 3 different regions?
componenttext: Just going back to the RIDEA growth across different geographies, could you just maybe give us a range sort of how that 2% to 3% would pan out in the 3 different regions?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll be happy to. So the U.S. is 76% of that portfolio and drives the majority of the different rates so you should expect it to be right in the middle of that range. The U.K., probably a bit higher, but back end weighted in the second half of the ye
componenttext: Yes, I'll be happy to. So the U.S. is 76% of that portfolio and drives the majority of the different rates so you should expect it to be right in the middle of that range. The U.K., probably a bit higher, but back end weighted in the second half of the year and then Canada, a bit lower. Most of it because of the economy there. Inflation is 0.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you also talked about the expense of the wage pressures, in parts of the U.S. and then in the U.K.. And I think -- any similar trends in Canada or pressures in Canada?
componenttext: And you also talked about the expense of the wage pressures, in parts of the U.S. and then in the U.K.. And I think -- any similar trends in Canada or pressures in Canada?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen as much in Canada, Vik. Probably driven more just by the health of the overall economy there, but the labor market is much more reasonable. It's really in the U.K. because of the change in the living wage in that particular markets in the
componenttext: We haven't seen as much in Canada, Vik. Probably driven more just by the health of the overall economy there, but the labor market is much more reasonable. It's really in the U.K. because of the change in the living wage in that particular markets in the U.S., which have a higher minimum wage.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the U.K. has a [indiscernible] that has a very tight labor market. There is a demand, particularly for people with nursing skills. And a lot of that is the -- it's complicated because a lot of that demand is being met through nurses that are coming fr
componenttext: And the U.K. has a [indiscernible] that has a very tight labor market. There is a demand, particularly for people with nursing skills. And a lot of that is the -- it's complicated because a lot of that demand is being met through nurses that are coming from other countries, and then you expect to get into a whole immigration discussion. So it's quite complicated but that's where -- that's where a lot of pressure's been in the U.K.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to understand kind of the methodology we use to kind of come up with your RIDEA growth number and kind of what impact of supply, I think some of your peers use sort of a 3% absorption number factored into that equation. I'm just wondering what yo
componenttext: And just to understand kind of the methodology we use to kind of come up with your RIDEA growth number and kind of what impact of supply, I think some of your peers use sort of a 3% absorption number factored into that equation. I'm just wondering what you guys use and can any of you give us a little bit more color on how you -- what sort of industry trends you assume in that model?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vik. I think the number that you're referring to is in the supplement. So I'll just use the 3-mile radius as an example, because we still think that's the most appropriate for our urban locations based on where residents usually come from. We had a m
componenttext: Yes, Vik. I think the number that you're referring to is in the supplement. So I'll just use the 3-mile radius as an example, because we still think that's the most appropriate for our urban locations based on where residents usually come from. We had a more suburban or world market portfolio, I think, 5, 10 miles is more appropriate but for Welltower, I think 3 miles really is the best radius to be looking at. So in this quarter's supplement, we say that 1.7% of our total NOI is impacted by new supply, okay. And that assumes that all of the NOI from the properties that we own will be impacted 100% by the new supplies, so it's kind of a worst-case scenario, meaning if you take all the properties in our portfolio, they're impacted by new supply. That 1.7% assumes that NOI in those properties goes to 0, which is obviously not going to happen. In fact, our history is that properties in our portfolio that are subject to new supply have actually held up quite well when new supply enters the market. And we've studied it for years. If we look at the performance before and after the new competition enters the market and on average, occupancy is pretty much flat and NOI has been up 4% on average. So it's not the draconian downside necessarily that people assume.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just last one on Mainstreet. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe when you had announced this in '14, you had talked about potentially $1 billion worth of acquisitions, or at least the option to buy them. And you baked in, if I'm not wrong, $16
componenttext: And then just last one on Mainstreet. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe when you had announced this in '14, you had talked about potentially $1 billion worth of acquisitions, or at least the option to buy them. And you baked in, if I'm not wrong, $160 million. Can you just talk about incremental opportunities from over and above that?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there were 2 different pipelines. There were 17 buildings that we are committed to acquire and now closed on 12 of those so there are 5 more to come. And then there were 45 additional properties that had yet to be started, and those are starting to r
componenttext: Yes, there were 2 different pipelines. There were 17 buildings that we are committed to acquire and now closed on 12 of those so there are 5 more to come. And then there were 45 additional properties that had yet to be started, and those are starting to roll out and the structure on those is that we provide a small mezzanine loan. Mainstreet puts in a lot of equity and then obtained a third-party construction loan. And when those 45 buildings open, one at a time, we have the option to buy each one at a 7.7 cap rate. So it's one building at a time, at our option.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the proposed acquisition mix. I mean, there's nothing embedded in guidance today. But I'm curious, given sort of the dislocation in the public market related to the news, if you will, if there's any opportunity to get any opportunity in post
componenttext: A question on the proposed acquisition mix. I mean, there's nothing embedded in guidance today. But I'm curious, given sort of the dislocation in the public market related to the news, if you will, if there's any opportunity to get any opportunity in post-acute if you'd look to get bigger there, investing incrementally, and then maybe any other comment of any other vertical in the portfolio you'll be interested in, sort of the capital.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're saying has there been interest from other parties in our skilled nursing assets, either buying them from us or investing, helping us fund development skilled nursing?
componenttext: You're saying has there been interest from other parties in our skilled nursing assets, either buying them from us or investing, helping us fund development skilled nursing?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm more interested to know what you want to do with your capital as you look forward. So obviously, we saw DSL, but I'm curious what you'd do in the post-acute space.
componenttext: I'm more interested to know what you want to do with your capital as you look forward. So obviously, we saw DSL, but I'm curious what you'd do in the post-acute space.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what we're interested in post-acute is investing in the next-generation of post-acute care. We are not interested in owning lots of low Q-Mix nursing assets and you know we sold lots of them over the years that Scott mentioned, that's been a components
componenttext: So what we're interested in post-acute is investing in the next-generation of post-acute care. We are not interested in owning lots of low Q-Mix nursing assets and you know we sold lots of them over the years that Scott mentioned, that's been a components of the $4 billion in dispositions we've made. We believe in the post-acute sector. We do not think it's going away. And so we will deploy capital into the next-generation of post-acute, of which Genesis is one of the operators that is offering that product through its PowerBack facilities. We think that is a good place to commit capital, we think, recently, just this past Monday, we were with Sun Clinic, and they mentioned that they have just warmed their relationship with select medical where they're actually in a new suburban setting where they have an outpatient in a smaller hospital, where they're actually putting select medical post-acute beds attached to the hospital that select medical will run. So hospitals, more than ever, need strong, post-acute operators, and so that's where we will deploy capital. We're not looking to acquire skilled nursing beds because the cap rates were attractive. That is not what we do as a company. And I think that's a very important differentiating point about Welltower.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me answer that question, jordan, in a little bit of a different way, too. Let Tom's comment really focus on post-acute but really where time capital is more precious, we really focus on our existing partners. You all know that we have a partnership-ba
componenttext: Let me answer that question, jordan, in a little bit of a different way, too. Let Tom's comment really focus on post-acute but really where time capital is more precious, we really focus on our existing partners. You all know that we have a partnership-based approach, and we have 30 partners that we have been growing with historically. So again, if you think about assets, it comes to post-acute. Maybe a part of it, but I think primarily, seniors housing is where we have our largest share of relationships are always going to be, I think, focused in senior's housing area, first and foremost.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then separately, on returns and cap rates. Scott Brinker, I think, I heard you sort of in response to a question mentioned that you'd ratcheted your return expectations higher. I'm curious how much or to what degree would assets
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then separately, on returns and cap rates. Scott Brinker, I think, I heard you sort of in response to a question mentioned that you'd ratcheted your return expectations higher. I'm curious how much or to what degree would assets classes?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to even say what the number would be because we just think of our current stock price, there's no reason to do anything. It's ridiculous price to try to raise money at, and I don't think it has any connection to the intrinsic side of the company
componenttext: It's hard to even say what the number would be because we just think of our current stock price, there's no reason to do anything. It's ridiculous price to try to raise money at, and I don't think it has any connection to the intrinsic side of the company, let alone the platform. So we're not really thinking about acquisitions right now. There's a pretty large gap between market expectations for cap rates and what would make sense for us. And that means we're going to keep relationships warm. And when that discrepancy flips and at some point, it will, we'll be active again.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a disconnect between sort of that comment regarding the equity and keeping the drip on?
componenttext: Is there a disconnect between sort of that comment regarding the equity and keeping the drip on?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, yes. We would say -- I would say it couldn't hurt to look at it. Actually, we never turned it off and fortunately, we've been in a position and if we stayed -- what we would argue with a depressed stock price for a period of time, we could do it.
componenttext: I guess, yes. We would say -- I would say it couldn't hurt to look at it. Actually, we never turned it off and fortunately, we've been in a position and if we stayed -- what we would argue with a depressed stock price for a period of time, we could do it. So I think it's worth looking at again to the extent we traded at a lower value for a longer period of time. We're really raising only about 50 or 60-ish million per quarter in terms of the number of shares that typically come in.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Omotayo Okusanya.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Good results. Good to see. Two quick questions. headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably best that we spread it evenly, Tayo. I mean, what's held for sale on our balance sheet is about $110 million and will be a portfolio in a 60 million senior housing triple net portfolio. Scott Brinker mentioned loans is clearly a component of
componenttext: It's probably best that we spread it evenly, Tayo. I mean, what's held for sale on our balance sheet is about $110 million and will be a portfolio in a 60 million senior housing triple net portfolio. Scott Brinker mentioned loans is clearly a component of that again while using the potential Genesis refinancing as an example, we'll take time to play out throughout the year because due to high process and then everything else will be opportunistic. So I do think it's probably best to blend it throughout the year.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the last question is U.K.-related. I know it is a little bit different but the amount of residents in most every REIT facilities that get assistance from the local authorities lower than the national average. But just when we think about the U.K. as a
componenttext: And the last question is U.K.-related. I know it is a little bit different but the amount of residents in most every REIT facilities that get assistance from the local authorities lower than the national average. But just when we think about the U.K. as a whole, this combination of wages going up dramatically, this idea that a lot of the local authorities are trying to lower or not increase payment rates as aggressively as it's been in the past few years? And we think about a lot of care home operators in the U.K. being fairly levered entities. What do you actually think is the ultimate outcome here in the U.K? Do we go through a round of consolidations? Or do you kind of somehow think that somehow the other local authorities will be forced to [indiscernible]?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there are really 2 businesses in the U.K. 95-plus percent of what exists there are buildings that we wouldn't want to own because the real estate quality is pretty bad and the payer mix is virtually all government pay. And I think that business is in
componenttext: Yes, there are really 2 businesses in the U.K. 95-plus percent of what exists there are buildings that we wouldn't want to own because the real estate quality is pretty bad and the payer mix is virtually all government pay. And I think that business is in a lot of trouble. That's why we did not invest any capital into that space over the past 4 years when we so aggressively pursued the high-end private pay market. I say that because one, the real estate quality is low. But two, think about the minimum wage impact when government reimbursement rates are increasing, maybe 1% a year and your staffing costs are going up 8% to 10%, that's a tough dynamic to manage through. And I contrast that with the 3 portfolios that we own in the U.K, Sunrise, Signature and Avery, all of which have 90-plus percent private pay. They actually increased rates at pretty substantial percentages this year to offset most of that wage increase. And that's why you really do need to think about 2 different sectors that are targeting 2 very different residence.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We offer an alternative to either local authority when it comes to elder care or even in acute care, as you know, we own 4 hospitals in London that are private pay hospitals. So if you think about a network of, in London today, of over 70 elder care facil
componenttext: We offer an alternative to either local authority when it comes to elder care or even in acute care, as you know, we own 4 hospitals in London that are private pay hospitals. So if you think about a network of, in London today, of over 70 elder care facilities that are private pay that our networked with 4 private pay acute care hospitals, that is a formidable entity that -- because the fact is, you have, in the U.K., they can't afford to treat their growing elderly population in NHS beds. They just can't do that. And I think there's going to be an increasing demand for private pay health care options as more and more of the population will not get what they want from the government.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Scott, you indicated in your comments that [indiscernible] has been preparing for the changing reimbursement environment for the skilled nursing facilities base over the past few years. Can you quickly highlight what those changes were? Were those just mainly in the sale of lower quality assets, or [indiscernible] from higher quality assets you think you can benefit from these changes?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly, Michael. I talked about Genesis increasing property level NOI by 2.5% per year over the last 4 years. The assets that we sold were not held up that well. They had very low coverage, older buildings, really no corporate credit, and that's imp
componenttext: Yes, exactly, Michael. I talked about Genesis increasing property level NOI by 2.5% per year over the last 4 years. The assets that we sold were not held up that well. They had very low coverage, older buildings, really no corporate credit, and that's important to understand in the school nursing business, generally speaking, there's no corporate credit behind these leases. Although they may not be AAA, there's just substantial entity standing behind [indiscernible]. And we're happy to invest more with Genesis. We've been doing that, but we've been focused on the modern post-acute properties that often have higher payment coverage as well so there's an even bigger cushion.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are these modern facilities of a higher percentage of Medicare patients that will see more pressure? Or do you expect that the modern facilities will be able to capitalize on the bundled payments that can capture more of that volume?
componenttext: Are these modern facilities of a higher percentage of Medicare patients that will see more pressure? Or do you expect that the modern facilities will be able to capitalize on the bundled payments that can capture more of that volume?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they'll capture more volume, without question. When you think about the health care business really transitioning to one of a consumer-based industry, where did we better go? Given a choice. If you've been in one of the Mainstreet Properties or Power
componenttext: Yes, they'll capture more volume, without question. When you think about the health care business really transitioning to one of a consumer-based industry, where did we better go? Given a choice. If you've been in one of the Mainstreet Properties or PowerBack, these are very nice properties in terms of the private room, leaving the rehab space, amenities, in comparison to the typical 50 year old nursing home, semiprivate rooms.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the future is what I mentioned with Cleveland clinic, which is in your backyard. and/or what we have with Virtua in more east, where you got a PowerBack contiguous to the outpatient at the acute care hospital. That's the future. That's what hospital s
componenttext: And the future is what I mentioned with Cleveland clinic, which is in your backyard. and/or what we have with Virtua in more east, where you got a PowerBack contiguous to the outpatient at the acute care hospital. That's the future. That's what hospital systems have to embrace, that they need to partner with the best-in-class post-acute operators, and Genesis is one of them.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you guys know the breakdown of the Medicare mix for Genesis and Main Street and if they're being impacted by Medicare Advantage and their Medicare Mix, how much of that is Medicare Advantage?
componenttext: And do you guys know the breakdown of the Medicare mix for Genesis and Main Street and if they're being impacted by Medicare Advantage and their Medicare Mix, how much of that is Medicare Advantage?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, in the supplement, we give the quality mix for Genesis, which would include Medicare fee-for-service, Medicare Advantage as well as any other private pay or commercial insurance. And it's right around 48%. So slightly below half. We don't disclos
componenttext: Michael, in the supplement, we give the quality mix for Genesis, which would include Medicare fee-for-service, Medicare Advantage as well as any other private pay or commercial insurance. And it's right around 48%. So slightly below half. We don't disclose the specific breakdown among those different payer classes. The rates are generally in the same range anyway. I can't tell you of their Medicare revenues, roughly 2/3 is traditional fee-for-service and the rest is Medicare Advantage, and that's pretty consistent with the national average, where, if you look at all Medicare beneficiaries, about 2/3 of them are still in the traditional fee-for-service business and the other 1/3 are in the Medicare Advantage business.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
