componenttext: Yes, John, it's Scott Brinker. There are mutual rights of first offer based on defined radii around the properties that we acquired. That is limited to independent-living buildings since that's what we acquired with them.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on your $1 billion of disposition guidance, can you just elaborate who the buyers in the market are today? And how we should be thinking about cap rates? You have 9% in dispositions in the fourth quarter, but as you mentioned, 7.2% of that
componenttext: Okay. And then on your $1 billion of disposition guidance, can you just elaborate who the buyers in the market are today? And how we should be thinking about cap rates? You have 9% in dispositions in the fourth quarter, but as you mentioned, 7.2% of that is held for sale. So how should we think about cap rates going forward?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the $1 billion is loan repayments. So the buyer is HUD rather than what you would ordinarily think about as a buyer. The others that we have in process it's for the most part private equity groups. You'd have to ask them about their return
componenttext: Well, a lot of the $1 billion is loan repayments. So the buyer is HUD rather than what you would ordinarily think about as a buyer. The others that we have in process it's for the most part private equity groups. You'd have to ask them about their return expectations. I know ours have increased a bit. But I don't think there's been enough transaction volume, at least in seniors housing, to know where cap rates are going. I would say medical office is such a liquid market, a lot of buyers that I don't think the impact of the public REIT share prices or the nontraded REITs no longer raising money has much of an impact in that sector. And we've seen several skilled nursing portfolios very recently transact at cap rates that are really no different than what we've seen for years in that business. Seniors housing is where it slowed down a bit. So I think a lot of people are wondering where cap rates will ultimately head.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally on Genesis, I appreciate that they haven't reported full year results yet, but they did guide to a sequential decline in EBITDAR in the fourth quarter. Can you just elaborate why you feel confident that their headwinds are not the s
componenttext: Okay. And then finally on Genesis, I appreciate that they haven't reported full year results yet, but they did guide to a sequential decline in EBITDAR in the fourth quarter. Can you just elaborate why you feel confident that their headwinds are not the same as ManorCare given the pattern seems like it's very similar?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there are a long list of things that are different. Now I know a lot more about Genesis than I do about ManorCare, so I'll by design focus my comments on Genesis. But it gets back to the comments I made in my script, John. They clearly are fa
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there are a long list of things that are different. Now I know a lot more about Genesis than I do about ManorCare, so I'll by design focus my comments on Genesis. But it gets back to the comments I made in my script, John. They clearly are facing some industry headwinds, but those headwinds aren't new. Medicare Advantage has been an issue for years and years, putting pressure on length of stay and rate; and Genesis has stayed ahead by getting out of certain assets, acquiring assets that are better fits for the current environment and actively managing their labor cost, which again is the most significant operating expense. And the other thing I would mention is they have a much lower Medicare mix, and that probably has an impact on why they've held up better over the past 4 years because a lot of the pressure has been on the Medicare side of the business. And the other distinction I would make is the results at the corporate level. So I talked about property level cash flow being more than adequate to pay the rent, but there's also a huge difference in terms of the corporate cash flow, which provide a significant security blanket for our rent payment. And they've been able to grow that cash flow through merger synergies, and they'll grow it going forward through refinancing and probably some asset buybacks.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just remind us what percentage of the Genesis equity that you own?
componenttext: Can you just remind us what percentage of the Genesis equity that you own?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just over 4%, John.
componenttext: It's just over 4%, John.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chad Vanacore of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chad Vanacore of Stifel.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just looking at the shop portfolio, occupancy has actually improved for the past couple of quarters. What are you seeing or expecting that you're factoring in to get to your flat occupancy in 2016?
componenttext: So just looking at the shop portfolio, occupancy has actually improved for the past couple of quarters. What are you seeing or expecting that you're factoring in to get to your flat occupancy in 2016?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chad, we like the market position of our buildings in the vast, vast majority of our locations. But I just -- remember, just back 12 months ago when it seems like the day after we hung up on our fourth quarter earnings call occupancy started to drop prett
componenttext: Chad, we like the market position of our buildings in the vast, vast majority of our locations. But I just -- remember, just back 12 months ago when it seems like the day after we hung up on our fourth quarter earnings call occupancy started to drop pretty quickly because of the flu. So there's just some things that you can't predict, and we're taking a conservative approach here. I mentioned earlier that occupancy today in the same-store pool is above last year. So that implies that we should be in a good position, and we continue to see positive trends really in all 3 countries.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So speaking of all 3 countries. I think, Scott, you might have mentioned that you expect a rebound in the U.K. How should we think about that given your occupancy starting on a -- at a much lower level now, and how should we think about that gr
componenttext: All right. So speaking of all 3 countries. I think, Scott, you might have mentioned that you expect a rebound in the U.K. How should we think about that given your occupancy starting on a -- at a much lower level now, and how should we think about that growth?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is, and it will probably ramp up over the course of the year. And I get back to the comment I made about the 3 variables that really impact performance. The first is occupancy, and there is clearly a rebuilding that was necessary after the flu sea
componenttext: Yes, it is, and it will probably ramp up over the course of the year. And I get back to the comment I made about the 3 variables that really impact performance. The first is occupancy, and there is clearly a rebuilding that was necessary after the flu season last year, but we've seen it. Across that portfolio, occupancy is coming back very strongly. The second variable being rate, and we continue to increase rates in the 3% range, if not higher this year. The third variable is more challenging, and that's labor because of the impact of the living wage, which is up 7% throughout the country and even higher in other markets. So unrelated to anything that Sunrise can control, there's just an external factor that's going to be a headwind on NOI growth this year.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just one last one. So you've done several JVs with capital partners now. Can you talk about your thoughts on what these capital partners are bringing to the table and why don't you just go it alone?
componenttext: All right. And just one last one. So you've done several JVs with capital partners now. Can you talk about your thoughts on what these capital partners are bringing to the table and why don't you just go it alone?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they bring some of the largest pools of capital in the world.  And Chad, we believe that there is going to be an increasing need for senior housing in the major metro markets. And if you think about the cost of building in midtown Manhattan or C
componenttext:
Well, they bring some of the largest pools of capital in the world. 
 
And Chad, we believe that there is going to be an increasing need for senior housing in the major metro markets. And if you think about the cost of building in midtown Manhattan or Central Washington, D.C., or San Francisco, it's significant, and it's important that institutions like CPP now understand the investment thesis for deploying capital to seniors housing. The other piece of this is that we, again, very much believe is that it's going to take trillions of dollars to rebuild the acute care hospital system in this country to basically accommodate technology that is with us today or will be developed in the future that will dramatically allow us to lower health care costs and improve outcomes. We have a lot of antiquated acute care hospital infrastructure in this country. So while I'd like to think we could go it alone and the capital markets will accommodate us to fund every bit of capital need that we will need to build this infrastructure, we aren't that -- we're not that big a gambler. So it's been very important for us to spend time with institutions like PSP and CPPIB. And we'll bring others in because I think they understand we're smart, and we can provide them opportunities that they cannot find on their own. And they will also see interesting opportunities to deploy capital at returns that possibly aren't available in other sectors -- in the traditional sectors of real estate where they are one of the major owners.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chad, the other thing I would mention is they give us a lot of flexibility. Keep in mind that as a healthcare REIT, we can't have operating companies, at least we can't own more than 35% of them. So Sunrise is an example. We love to own the whole thing, b
componenttext: Chad, the other thing I would mention is they give us a lot of flexibility. Keep in mind that as a healthcare REIT, we can't have operating companies, at least we can't own more than 35% of them. So Sunrise is an example. We love to own the whole thing, but we can't. So this is a company that's worth probably $500-plus million, okay? This is a big profitable company. And the question is if healthcare REIT Welltower can only own up to 35% of that company, who owns the rest? There are very limited people that could write a check that size.  Private equity is one, but frankly, generally speaking, they don't align with our approach to business. So PSP, acting through Revera, owns the balance of Sunrise alongside of us. And that's just one example of how we are, I think, controlling our own destiny, helping shape the future of the industry through these ownership stakes that without a group like PSP we would not be able to do.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott just said it. We're a real long-term investor, and these are long-term investors. They're not managing to a 7-year fund return. So we think we are much more aligned with this investor class, and I think you'll see more of that from us.
componenttext: Scott just said it. We're a real long-term investor, and these are long-term investors. They're not managing to a 7-year fund return. So we think we are much more aligned with this investor class, and I think you'll see more of that from us.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the RIDEA growth across the different geographies, could you maybe just give us a range sort of how that 2% to 3% would pan out in the 3 different regions?
componenttext: Just going back to the RIDEA growth across the different geographies, could you maybe just give us a range sort of how that 2% to 3% would pan out in the 3 different regions?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll be happy to. Vik, the U.S. is 76% of that portfolio and drives the majority of the growth rates, so you should expect it to be right in the middle of that range. The U.K. probably a bit higher but back-end weighted in the second half of the year
componenttext: Yes, I'll be happy to. Vik, the U.S. is 76% of that portfolio and drives the majority of the growth rates, so you should expect it to be right in the middle of that range. The U.K. probably a bit higher but back-end weighted in the second half of the year. And then Canada, a bit lower. Mostly because of the economy there. Inflation is 0.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you also talked about the expense of the wage pressures in the -- in parts of the U.S. and in the U.K. Anything -- any similar trends in Canada or pressures in Canada?
componenttext: And you also talked about the expense of the wage pressures in the -- in parts of the U.S. and in the U.K. Anything -- any similar trends in Canada or pressures in Canada?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen as much in Canada, Vik. Probably driven more just by the health of the overall economy there. The labor market is much more reasonable. It's really the U.K. because of the change in the living wage and then particular markets in the U.S.,
componenttext: We haven't seen as much in Canada, Vik. Probably driven more just by the health of the overall economy there. The labor market is much more reasonable. It's really the U.K. because of the change in the living wage and then particular markets in the U.S., which have a higher minimum wage.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the U.K. has a tight -- particularly around London has a very tight labor market. There is a demand particularly for people with nursing skills. And a lot of that is being -- it's complicated because a lot of that demand is being met through nurses th
componenttext: And the U.K. has a tight -- particularly around London has a very tight labor market. There is a demand particularly for people with nursing skills. And a lot of that is being -- it's complicated because a lot of that demand is being met through nurses that are coming from other countries, and then you start to get into a whole immigration discussion. So it's quite complicated, but that's where -- that's where lot of the pressure has been in the U.K.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to understand kind of the methodology you use to kind of come up with your RIDEA growth numbers and kind of what the impact of supply is. I think some of your peers use sort of a 3% absorption number factored into that equation. I'm just wo
componenttext: Okay. And just to understand kind of the methodology you use to kind of come up with your RIDEA growth numbers and kind of what the impact of supply is. I think some of your peers use sort of a 3% absorption number factored into that equation. I'm just wondering what you guys use and can maybe just give us a little bit more color on how you -- what sort of industry trends you assume in that model?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vik. I think the number that you're referring to is in the supplement. So I'll just use the 3-mile radius as an example, because we still think that's the most appropriate for our urban locations based on where residents usually come from. If we had
componenttext: Yes, Vik. I think the number that you're referring to is in the supplement. So I'll just use the 3-mile radius as an example, because we still think that's the most appropriate for our urban locations based on where residents usually come from. If we had a more suburban or rural market portfolio, I think 5 to 10 miles is more appropriate; but for Welltower, I think 3 miles really is the best radius to be looking at. So in this quarter's supplement, we say that 1.7% of our total NOI is impacted by new supply, okay? And that assumes that all of the NOI from the properties that we own will be impacted 100% by the new supplies,. So it's kind of a worst-case scenario, meaning if you take all the properties in our portfolio that are impacted by new supply, that 1.7% assumes that NOI at those properties goes to 0, which is obviously not going to happen. In fact our history is that properties in our portfolio that are subject to new supply have actually held up quite well when new supply enters the market. And we've -- we studied it for years. If you look at the performance before and after the new competition enters the market -- and on average, occupancy is pretty much flat, and NOI has been up 4% on average. So it's not the draconian downside necessarily that people assume.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense. And then just last one on Mainstreet. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe when that you had announced this in '14, you had talked about potentially $1 billion worth of acquisitions or at least the option to buy them. And you bak
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. And then just last one on Mainstreet. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe when that you had announced this in '14, you had talked about potentially $1 billion worth of acquisitions or at least the option to buy them. And you baked in, if I'm not wrong, about $160 million. Can you just talk about incremental opportunities from -- over and above that?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there were 2 different pipelines. There were 17 buildings that we are committed to acquire, and we've now closed on 12 of those, so there are 5 more to come. And then there were 45 additional properties that had yet to be started, and those are start
componenttext: Yes, there were 2 different pipelines. There were 17 buildings that we are committed to acquire, and we've now closed on 12 of those, so there are 5 more to come. And then there were 45 additional properties that had yet to be started, and those are starting to roll out, and the structure on those is that we provide a small mezzanine loan. Mainstreet puts in a lot of equity and then obtained a third-party construction loan. And when those 45 buildings open, one at a time we have the option to buy each one at a 7.7 cap rate. So it's one building at a time, our option.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the proposed acquisition mix. I mean, I know there's nothing embedded in guidance today. But I'm curious given sort of the dislocation at least in the public market related to the ManorCare news, if you will, if there is any opportunity to g
componenttext: A question on the proposed acquisition mix. I mean, I know there's nothing embedded in guidance today. But I'm curious given sort of the dislocation at least in the public market related to the ManorCare news, if you will, if there is any opportunity to get -- any opportunity in post-acute if you'd look to get bigger there or invest incrementally? And then maybe any other comment of any other vertical within the portfolio you'd be interested in sort of deploying incremental capital.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jordan, let me make sure I understood. You're saying has there been interest from other parties in our skilled nursing assets, either buying them from us or investing, helping us fund development of skilled nursing?
componenttext: Jordan, let me make sure I understood. You're saying has there been interest from other parties in our skilled nursing assets, either buying them from us or investing, helping us fund development of skilled nursing?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm more interested to know what you want to do with your capital as you look forward. So obviously, we saw DSL, but I'm curious what you'd do in the post-acute space.
componenttext: I'm more interested to know what you want to do with your capital as you look forward. So obviously, we saw DSL, but I'm curious what you'd do in the post-acute space.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what we're interested in post-acute is investing in the next-generation of post-acute care. We are not interested in owning lots of low Q-Mix nursing assets, and you know we've sold lots of them over the years that Scott mentioned, though it's been a c
componenttext: So what we're interested in post-acute is investing in the next-generation of post-acute care. We are not interested in owning lots of low Q-Mix nursing assets, and you know we've sold lots of them over the years that Scott mentioned, though it's been a component of the $4 billion in dispositions we've made. We believe in the post-acute sector. We do not think it's going away. And so we will deploy capital into the next-generation of post-acute, of which Genesis is one of the operators that is offering that product through its PowerBack facilities. We think that is a good place to commit capital, we think. Recently, just this past Monday, we were with Cleveland Clinic. And they mentioned that they had just formed a relationship with Select Medical, where they're actually in a new suburban setting where they have an outpatient in a smaller hospital. They're actually putting Select Medical post-acute beds attached to the hospital that Select Medical will run. So hospitals, more than ever, need strong post-acute operators, and so that's where we will deploy capital. We're not looking to acquire skilled nursing beds because the cap rates look attractive. That is not what we do as a company. And I think that's a very important differentiating point about Welltower.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I might answer that answer that question, Jordan, in a little bit of a different way, too. A lot of Tom's comments just focused on post-acute, but really in a time where capital is more precious, we really focus on our existing partners. You all know that
componenttext: I might answer that answer that question, Jordan, in a little bit of a different way, too. A lot of Tom's comments just focused on post-acute, but really in a time where capital is more precious, we really focus on our existing partners. You all know that we have a partnership-based approach, and we have 30 partners that we have been growing with historically. So if you had to think about asset mix, as Tom said, post-acute may be a part of it, but I think primarily seniors housing is where we have our largest share of relationships. So we're always going to be, I think, focused in seniors housing area first and foremost.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then separately, on returns and cap rates. Scott Brinker, I think, I heard you sort of in response to a question mentioned that you'd ratcheted your return expectations higher. I'm curious how much or to what degree what assets -
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then separately, on returns and cap rates. Scott Brinker, I think, I heard you sort of in response to a question mentioned that you'd ratcheted your return expectations higher. I'm curious how much or to what degree what assets -- what asset classes?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to even say what the number would be because we just think at our current stock price there is no reason to do anything. It's a ridiculous price to try to raise money at. I don't think it has any connection to the intrinsic value of the company,
componenttext: It's hard to even say what the number would be because we just think at our current stock price there is no reason to do anything. It's a ridiculous price to try to raise money at. I don't think it has any connection to the intrinsic value of the company, let alone the platform. So we're not really thinking about acquisitions right now. There is a pretty large gap between market expectations for cap rates and what would make sense for us. And that means we're going to keep relationships warm. And when that discrepancy flips, and at some point it will, we'll be active again.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a disconnect between sort of that comment regarding the equity and keeping the DRIP on?
componenttext: Is there a disconnect between sort of that comment regarding the equity and keeping the DRIP on?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, yes. We would say -- I would say it couldn't hurt to look at it. Actually, we never turned it off and fortunately been in a position. And if we stated a -- what we would argue is a depressed stock price for a period of time we could do it. So I t
componenttext: I guess, yes. We would say -- I would say it couldn't hurt to look at it. Actually, we never turned it off and fortunately been in a position. And if we stated a -- what we would argue is a depressed stock price for a period of time we could do it. So I think it's worth looking at again to the extent we traded at a lower value for a longer period of time. We really are raising only about 50 or 60-ish million per quarter in terms of the number of shares that typically come in.

componenttextpreview: Got it. And then the $1 billion of dispositions. Any sense timing-wise as we try to model that? Should we just go with the media convention or spread it evenly throughout the entire 4 quarters? I'm just curious because it does make a bit difference to the
componenttext: Got it. And then the $1 billion of dispositions. Any sense timing-wise as we try to model that? Should we just go with the media convention or spread it evenly throughout the entire 4 quarters? I'm just curious because it does make a bit difference to the numbers.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably best to spread it evenly throughout the year, Tayo. I mean, what's held for sale on our balance sheet is about $110 million MOB portfolio and a $60 million senior housing triple-net portfolio. Scott Brinker mentioned loans is clearly a compo
componenttext: It's probably best to spread it evenly throughout the year, Tayo. I mean, what's held for sale on our balance sheet is about $110 million MOB portfolio and a $60 million senior housing triple-net portfolio. Scott Brinker mentioned loans is clearly a component of that. Again, by using the potential  Genesis refinancing as an example, we'll take time to play out throughout the year because due to HUD process and then everything else will be opportunistic. So I do think it's probably best to blend it throughout the year.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. Then the last question is U.K. related. I know Avery is a little bit different because the amount of residents in most Avery facilities that get assistance from the local authorities is lower than the national average. But just when we think
componenttext: Got it. Okay. Then the last question is U.K. related. I know Avery is a little bit different because the amount of residents in most Avery facilities that get assistance from the local authorities is lower than the national average. But just when we think about the U.K. as a whole, this combination of wages going up dramatically, this idea that a lot of the local authorities are trying to lower or not increase payment rates as aggressively as it's been in the past few years. We think about a lot of care home operators in the U.K. being fairly levered entities. What do you actually think is the ultimate outcome here in the U.K? Do we go through a round of consolidation? Or do you kind of somehow think that's somehow the other local authorities will be forced to continue to support the system as is?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tayo, there are really 2 businesses in the U.K. 95-plus percent of what exists there are buildings that we wouldn't want to own because the real estate quality is pretty bad, and the payer mix is virtually all government pay. And I think that busines
componenttext: Yes, Tayo, there are really 2 businesses in the U.K. 95-plus percent of what exists there are buildings that we wouldn't want to own because the real estate quality is pretty bad, and the payer mix is virtually all government pay. And I think that business is in a lot of trouble. That's why we did not invest any capital into that space over the past 4 years when we so aggressively pursued the high-end private pay market. I say that because, one, the real estate quality is low. But two, think about the minimum wage impacts when government reimbursement rates are increasing maybe 1% a year and your staffing costs are going up 8% to 10%, that's a tough dynamic to manage through. And I contrast that with the 3 portfolios that we own in the U.K, Sunrise, Signature and Avery, all of which have 90-plus percent private pay. They actually increased rates at pretty substantial percentages this year to offset most of that wage increase. And that's why you really do need to think about 2 different sectors that are targeting 2 very different residence.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tayo, we offer an alternative to either local authority when it comes to elder care or even on -- in acute care. As you know, we own 4 hospitals in London that are private-pay hospitals. So if you think about a network of -- in London today of over 70 eld
componenttext: Tayo, we offer an alternative to either local authority when it comes to elder care or even on -- in acute care. As you know, we own 4 hospitals in London that are private-pay hospitals. So if you think about a network of -- in London today of over 70 elder-care facilities that are private pay that our networked with 4 private-pay acute care hospitals, that is a formidable entity that -- because the fact is, you have -- in the U.K., they can't afford to treat their growing elderly population in NHS beds. They just can't do that. And I think that there is going to be a -- an increasing demand for private-pay healthcare options as more and more of the population will not get what they want from the government.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carroll of RBC Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carroll of RBC Capital.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, you indicated in your comments that HCN has been preparing for the changing reimbursement environment for the skilled nursing facilities base over the past few years. Can you quickly highlight what those changes were? Were those just mainly the sal
componenttext: Scott, you indicated in your comments that HCN has been preparing for the changing reimbursement environment for the skilled nursing facilities base over the past few years. Can you quickly highlight what those changes were? Were those just mainly the sale of lower-quality assets and retaining some of the higher-quality assets you think that could benefit from these changes?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly, Michael. I talked about Genesis increasing property level NOI by 2.5% per year over the last 4 years. The assets that we sold would not have held up that well. They had very low coverage, older buildings, really no corporate credit, and that
componenttext: Yes, exactly, Michael. I talked about Genesis increasing property level NOI by 2.5% per year over the last 4 years. The assets that we sold would not have held up that well. They had very low coverage, older buildings, really no corporate credit, and that's important to understand in the skilled nursing business. Generally speaking, there is no corporate credit behind these leases. Although they may not be AAA, there's just substantial entity standing behind our lease. And we're happy to invest more with Genesis. We've been doing that, but we've been focused on the modern post-acute properties that often have higher payment coverage as well, so that there's an even bigger cushion.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do these modern facilities have a higher percentage of Medicare patients that would see more pressure? Or do you expect that the modern facilities will be able to capitalize because with the bundled payments they can capture more of that volume?
componenttext: Do these modern facilities have a higher percentage of Medicare patients that would see more pressure? Or do you expect that the modern facilities will be able to capitalize because with the bundled payments they can capture more of that volume?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they'll capture more volume, without question. When you think about the healthcare business really transitioning to more of a consumer-based industry, where would you rather go, given a choice? If you've been in one of the Mainstreet properties or Po
componenttext: Yes, they'll capture more volume, without question. When you think about the healthcare business really transitioning to more of a consumer-based industry, where would you rather go, given a choice? If you've been in one of the Mainstreet properties or PowerBack, these are very nice properties in terms of a private room, big rehab space, the amenities. In comparison to the typical 50-year-old nursing home, you have semiprivate rooms.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The future is what I mentioned with Cleveland Clinic, which is in your backyard and/or what we have with Virtua in Voorhees, where you've got a PowerBack contiguous to the outpatient and the acute care hospital. That's the future. That's what hospital sys
componenttext: The future is what I mentioned with Cleveland Clinic, which is in your backyard and/or what we have with Virtua in Voorhees, where you've got a PowerBack contiguous to the outpatient and the acute care hospital. That's the future. That's what hospital systems have to embrace, that they need to partner with the best-in-class post-acute operators, and Genesis is one of them.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you guys know the breakdown of the Medicare mix for Genesis and Mainstreet? And if they would be impacted by Medicare Advantage? And I guess what's -- of their Medicare Mix, how much of that is Medicare Advantage?
componenttext: Okay. And you guys know the breakdown of the Medicare mix for Genesis and Mainstreet? And if they would be impacted by Medicare Advantage? And I guess what's -- of their Medicare Mix, how much of that is Medicare Advantage?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, in the supplement, we give the quality mix for Genesis, which would include Medicare fee-for-service, Medicare Advantage as well as any other private-pay or commercial insurance. And it's right around 48%. So slightly below half. We don't disclos
componenttext: Michael, in the supplement, we give the quality mix for Genesis, which would include Medicare fee-for-service, Medicare Advantage as well as any other private-pay or commercial insurance. And it's right around 48%. So slightly below half. We don't disclose the specific breakdown among those different payer classes. The rates are generally in the same range. Anyway, I can tell you that of their Medicare revenues roughly 2/3 is traditional fee-for-service, and the rest is Medicare Advantage. And that's pretty consistent with the national average, where if you look at all Medicare beneficiaries about 2/3 of them are still in the traditional fee-for-service business, and the other 1/3 are in the Medicare Advantage business.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.

componenttext: I just had a quick question on your loan portfolio. Are the -- is the interest on that all cash from the borrowers? Or is there any kind of pay-on-time arrangements for some of that? Or is it all just cash?

componenttext: The -- Smedes, it's all cash. The current rate is 8.1% on the blended loan portfolio, Smedes. Is there any -- very small part is not cash.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Okay. All right. You covered the rest of my questions.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Anderson of Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Anderson of Mizuho Securities.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to get back to post-acute. It's been said a few times in the call that this is not a new issue, and I think we can all agree with that. But now the rubber is kind of meeting the road, and operators are having to point out the pressures th
componenttext: So I just wanted to get back to post-acute. It's been said a few times in the call that this is not a new issue, and I think we can all agree with that. But now the rubber is kind of meeting the road, and operators are having to point out the pressures that they're seeing, and I would argue that, that is not -- or is a new issue. And so yes, there's a need for post-acute, of course, over the long term. But the question is, no one really knows what the ultimate landing point of all this is. And could there be a significant enough spread versus your rents to their profitability that will ultimately make this okay? So while the temptation is to maybe goose the rent escalators as much as possible, do you think the end game here, ultimately, over the long term will be lower rent growth in the industry so that you're partnering correctly with post-acute  operator, Genesis -- Genesis and others? I just want your comment on what the ultimate end game could be here when you consider the newness of the impact from these not-so-new events.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a tough question, Rich. You're asking us to make some predictions, which we don't like to do. It's hard to say -- the one -- the answer -- the way I'd answer the question -- and I would invite anybody in the room here to answer this as well.
componenttext: Well, that's a tough question, Rich. You're asking us to make some predictions, which we don't like to do. It's hard to say -- the one -- the answer -- the way I'd answer the question -- and I would invite anybody in the room here to answer this as well. I mean, the way I'd answer it is that you have acute care hospital providers that are going to be under increasing pressure because of bundled payments. They are going to need to align with post-acute and senior housing operators. So I think if you're focused on working -- oh, and also Scott mentioned a word that you don't often hear with respect to health care, which is called consumerism. As the consumer is forced to have more choices in the future because they're paying more, you're going to -- there's all these phenomenon that, to us, say if you are aligned with the leading, surviving health systems and you have a post-acute business that helps them manage in a new reimbursement world more effectively, I think that leads to a good outcome for both the acute care hospital as well as the post-acute provider as well as the consumer. And that is a new way of talking about health care.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess the ultimate question is where does this all end? And you're saying right now that you're not expecting anything in the way of rent cuts down the road, no matter how far out you look?
componenttext: Okay. I guess the ultimate question is where does this all end? And you're saying right now that you're not expecting anything in the way of rent cuts down the road, no matter how far out you look?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I -- it's hard to say. I mean, I think that this is a complicated area. There will be bumps in the road. It's very hard to answer that, but we feel we're very well positioned, Rich.
componenttext: I mean, I -- it's hard to say. I mean, I think that this is a complicated area. There will be bumps in the road. It's very hard to answer that, but we feel we're very well positioned, Rich.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, rent cuts are something that we talk about. I mean, that -- think about the facility-level payment coverage, which, again, is the cash from the buildings that we own, it's backstopped by a corporate guarantee. So we feel very comfortable with w
componenttext: Yes, Rich, rent cuts are something that we talk about. I mean, that -- think about the facility-level payment coverage, which, again, is the cash from the buildings that we own, it's backstopped by a corporate guarantee. So we feel very comfortable with where we're at from both ends.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the comment was just made about your Q-Mix with Genesis being below 50%, and I remember having this discussion with you guys about maybe we should be focused more on lower Q-Mix assets, and that concept was kind of pushed aside. Now maybe w
componenttext: Okay. And then the comment was just made about your Q-Mix with Genesis being below 50%, and I remember having this discussion with you guys about maybe we should be focused more on lower Q-Mix assets, and that concept was kind of pushed aside. Now maybe we're talking more swimmingly about low Q-Mix asset classes or assets within the post-acute world. Do you think that that's the next generation of thought process given all the pressures going on?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, and I think there's a huge misunderstanding on that point because the pressure that you're seeing from managed care in the Medicare business will also come from Medicaid. The states are throwing up their hands and giving their entire programs to comme
componenttext: No, and I think there's a huge misunderstanding on that point because the pressure that you're seeing from managed care in the Medicare business will also come from Medicaid. The states are throwing up their hands and giving their entire programs to commercial insurers who will continue to squeeze this business. And to me, government-funded long-term care is the high-cost setting for those residents when you consider the alternatives. Post-acute is the low-cost setting for those residents, so you have to think about a market and what it looks like 5 to 10 years from now and not just what the headlines suggest. So we continue to be a lot more bullish about this sector for post-acute than for long-term residential care, which frankly, every state is doing everything they can to keep patients out of long-term care nursing homes.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. Fair enough. Just a quick turn of the topic. U.K., there was a doctor strike a month or so ago for younger doctors. I don't remember specifically where that has gone since then, but I'm just curious if you can give any color on that how much it
componenttext: Yes. Okay. Fair enough. Just a quick turn of the topic. U.K., there was a doctor strike a month or so ago for younger doctors. I don't remember specifically where that has gone since then, but I'm just curious if you can give any color on that how much it concerns you, even though it may not have been a direct hit to your business.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think it was something that we focused a lot of attention on because it didn't affect us. I guess there are longer-term big issues in the U.K. regarding medical professionals. I think it affects mostly the National Health Service.
componenttext: No. I don't think it was something that we focused a lot of attention on because it didn't affect us. I guess there are longer-term big issues in the U.K. regarding medical professionals. I think it affects mostly the National Health Service.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last question is little bit of a brainstormer, but do you have any concern, you're partnering with large pension funds out of Canada, it's a country that is highly dependent on energy. Is there any -- have you given that any thought abo
componenttext: Okay. And then the last question is little bit of a brainstormer, but do you have any concern, you're partnering with large pension funds out of Canada, it's a country that is highly dependent on energy. Is there any -- have you given that any thought about the longevity of them as partners if we continue to see depressed nature of oil and other commodities?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, CPP and PSP have been around for decades. They are the -- every day they are receiving millions to billions of dollars, which have to be invested in safe assets. So they can pay out these pensions over time. They've been around across many cycles, w
componenttext: Rich, CPP and PSP have been around for decades. They are the -- every day they are receiving millions to billions of dollars, which have to be invested in safe assets. So they can pay out these pensions over time. They've been around across many cycles, whether oil was $100 a gallon or whether it's $20, whatever it's --  we don't worry about that. They are stable a institutional partner as you can find in the world.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I love brainstorming. So anyway, I appreciate it.
componenttext: Well, I love brainstorming. So anyway, I appreciate it.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, we like it when you brainstorm. We enjoy that. Come see us, and you can brainstorm -- come see us in Sweedom [ph]. We can brainstorm even more.
componenttext: Rich, we like it when you brainstorm. We enjoy that. Come see us, and you can brainstorm -- come see us in Sweedom [ph]. We can brainstorm even more.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karin Ford of Mitsubishi UFJ Securities.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Recognizing that you can't speak to your specific coverage in 4Q '15 ahead of Genesis' earnings reports, can you just talk generally about what you think the direction of the coverages will be for 2016 given your escalators and the ratcheting interest rat
componenttext: Recognizing that you can't speak to your specific coverage in 4Q '15 ahead of Genesis' earnings reports, can you just talk generally about what you think the direction of the coverages will be for 2016 given your escalators and the ratcheting interest rates on your loans?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, unfortunately, we can't talk about that because they talked about it in their press release a couple of weeks ago. And the specific comment was at the corporate level, fixed charge coverage is 1.31x in 2015, and they're projecting 1.35x in 2016.
componenttext: Well, unfortunately, we can't talk about that because they talked about it in their press release a couple of weeks ago. And the specific comment was at the corporate level, fixed charge coverage is 1.31x in 2015, and they're projecting 1.35x in 2016.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question is just wanted to ask about your 3% to 3.5% assumption for shop rate growth in 2016. Did Sunrise and your other operators push through rate increases on most of their units on Jan 1? And given that you're seeing occupancy pe
componenttext: Okay. And then second question is just wanted to ask about your 3% to 3.5% assumption for shop rate growth in 2016. Did Sunrise and your other operators push through rate increases on most of their units on Jan 1? And given that you're seeing occupancy perform pretty well here, is that what gives you confidence on that assumption?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Karin. I'm glad you brought that up because of our shop portfolio roughly half of the properties do increase rents for existing residents on January 1, but the other half do it on the anniversary date of when the resident moved in.
componenttext: That's a good question, Karin. I'm glad you brought that up because of our shop portfolio roughly half of the properties do increase rents for existing residents on January 1, but the other half do it on the anniversary date of when the resident moved in. So it takes some time to impact revenue, and I'll contrast that with wage pressure, which increases for everybody on January 1. And that's the main reason why we think the second half of the year probably looks a little bit better than the first half this year just given those dynamics. And when it comes to rates for new residents, coming in off the street, we do know what the operators are planning to charge in terms of an increase. But the variable is the timing, right? They come in throughout the course of the year. So it doesn't impact revenue on day one.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Tyler of Green Street Advisor.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Tyler of Green Street Advisor.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on the Genesis side. I know that there's been some additions to the loan portfolio there. What's the total balance today stand? Is it about $450 million on my math or...
componenttext: Just a quick one on the Genesis side. I know that there's been some additions to the loan portfolio there. What's the total balance today stand? Is it about $450 million on my math or...

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's $440 million.
componenttext: Yes, it's $440 million.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then is there anything contractually that obligates them -- I get the fact that the loans become more expensive as time goes on, but contractually anything obligating them to pay you back when HUD funds?
componenttext: Okay. And then is there anything contractually that obligates them -- I get the fact that the loans become more expensive as time goes on, but contractually anything obligating them to pay you back when HUD funds?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If HUD funds, they clearly have to pay us back. I mean, we have the first mortgage on the property. So HUD won't close without taking that back from us. And economically, they have a strong incentive to pay us back. I think the rate escalates by 100
componenttext: Yes. If HUD funds, they clearly have to pay us back. I mean, we have the first mortgage on the property. So HUD won't close without taking that back from us. And economically, they have a strong incentive to pay us back. I think the rate escalates by 100 basis points every 90 days, and it's at least twice as high as what HUD will charge them, so the incentives are well aligned here.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Tom, just kind of building on the -- some of the points earlier related to CPP. In your conversations, has there been anything from others -- almost like a follow-on effect from others of the likes the CPP that are now potentially interest
componenttext: Okay. And then, Tom, just kind of building on the -- some of the points earlier related to CPP. In your conversations, has there been anything from others -- almost like a follow-on effect from others of the likes the CPP that are now potentially interested in the -- more in the medical office, senior housing, healthcare space in general as they see maybe CCP being -- or CPP being one of the first movers?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question, Kevin. I think it's early days. I think that, clearly, these big institutions that have not invested in the sector before are typically more interested in either urban outpatient medical buildings or -- I would say that would
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, Kevin. I think it's early days. I think that, clearly, these big institutions that have not invested in the sector before are typically more interested in either urban outpatient medical buildings or -- I would say that would be their prime -- it's easy for them to get their hands around that sector. But I think this announcement that we made today that now, again, you have another big global institution partnering with us, like PSP in the senior housing space, I think raises a flag to others that maybe you should take a look as well. So I think it's early days, but we are in conversations with a number of them.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mueller of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thinking about new investments, it sounds like new acquisitions are on hold here. But that said, how are you thinking about RIDEA senior housing investments compared to triple nets, just given the comparable same-store NOI outlooks that you have over t
componenttext: So thinking about new investments, it sounds like new acquisitions are on hold here. But that said, how are you thinking about RIDEA senior housing investments compared to triple nets, just given the comparable same-store NOI outlooks that you have over the near term? And then also, are you still pursuing new development opportunities considering the yields are higher?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the first question, my triple net versus RIDEA, it's a good question. And it becomes a bit more nuanced because most of the triple-net opportunities that we see recently have been -- I'll call them lower-quality properties. They're not in our core mark
componenttext: On the first question, my triple net versus RIDEA, it's a good question. And it becomes a bit more nuanced because most of the triple-net opportunities that we see recently have been -- I'll call them lower-quality properties. They're not in our core markets, and the payment coverage tends to be quite low, okay, without much corporate credit standing behind the lease. And if I contrast that opportunity with a RIDEA Class A investment in Los Angeles or New York, I still prefer the risk/reward of RIDEA. Even though structurally that first triple net investment looks more attractive, I think that's -- you need to think about it in a little bit more detailed way. Now if I could get triple-net coverages at 2x, that may change my opinion. But for the most part, the market today is in the 1.1 payment coverage range, which to me you're not really getting as much protection on a triple-net lease as the structure may imply.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then development, any -- once you work your way through this part of the pipeline, are you refilling that just given the yields are higher? Or are you pulling back on that as well?
componenttext: Got it. And then development, any -- once you work your way through this part of the pipeline, are you refilling that just given the yields are higher? Or are you pulling back on that as well?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're very selective when it comes to development. And again, if you're going to see us develop -- now you know, we're developing in London because there's no -- we have already rolled up the existing supply of high-end private-pay elder care in the
componenttext: Well, we're very selective when it comes to development. And again, if you're going to see us develop -- now you know, we're developing in London because there's no -- we have already rolled up the existing supply of high-end private-pay elder care in the London market. There still is demand, and that's where we're doing some development. We will -- we look very selectively at markets in the U.S., where we know there is no supply or very limited supply of high-end private-pay senior housing. And that's where we, on a very selective basis, will allocate capital.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just for -- probably for Scott Estes. You have about $170 million of properties included in the available-for-sale bucket. Just because dispositions seem high this year, what kind of visibility do you have on the remaining portion of assets? And what's in
componenttext: Just for -- probably for Scott Estes. You have about $170 million of properties included in the available-for-sale bucket. Just because dispositions seem high this year, what kind of visibility do you have on the remaining portion of assets? And what's in that available-for-sale group?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again -- Todd, the held for sale is 2 portfolios. Again, about $170 million, like I said $110 million of medical office buildings and $60 million senior housing triple-net portfolio. I would say, you probably have -- getting us up to our -- from that $170
componenttext: Again -- Todd, the held for sale is 2 portfolios. Again, about $170 million, like I said $110 million of medical office buildings and $60 million senior housing triple-net portfolio. I would say, you probably have -- getting us up to our -- from that $170 million up to roughly half of the total disposition number with potential loan pay off. And there is a little bit of variability, again, largely to timing of Genesis going through the HUD process. And then the rest is really probably the most flexible fees. So I think we really just want to maintain that flexibility. We have the luxury of time here. We feel good about where our leverage is.  But do you have a more specific question? Because we -- again, we didn't want to identify specific assets. There's a lot of options, and where pricing is in certain markets, we can be opportunistic. And if we can also do some things that enhance the quality of the portfolio, we would do -- we would look at those, too.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that you're going into Florida with the CPP deal, any overlap with your existing footprint down there?
componenttext: Now that you're going into Florida with the CPP deal, any overlap with your existing footprint down there?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We don't have much in Florida, actually. It hasn't historically been one of our targeted markets. We just happen to like these assets in particular. These are big campuses that stay virtually full, 100% of the time and equally important discoveries as
componenttext: No. We don't have much in Florida, actually. It hasn't historically been one of our targeted markets. We just happen to like these assets in particular. These are big campuses that stay virtually full, 100% of the time and equally important discoveries as good as we've seen, especially at the marketing side of the business and controlling costs. So it's, I think, a reminder that our business is driven not by real estate but also by the quality of the operations. And that's what we found so attractive about this particular portfolio.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Long call, so just had one. I know you laid out your strategy and rationale for exiting U.S. hospitals, and that was very helpful. But wouldn't now be possibly a good time to increase exposure to the asset class given operators better understand the ACA i
componenttext: Long call, so just had one. I know you laid out your strategy and rationale for exiting U.S. hospitals, and that was very helpful. But wouldn't now be possibly a good time to increase exposure to the asset class given operators better understand the ACA impact and hospital value is probably more attractive than before last year's TQP [ph]? I'm just trying to understand your strategy to remove exposure to that sector, while one of your competitors is doing the opposite.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is where we -- this is our -- where we come out of that. The hospitals that we would want to own are not available. You can only buy hospitals that we would, today -- that we consider not good long-term investments. We believe that much of the hos
componenttext: So this is where we -- this is our -- where we come out of that. The hospitals that we would want to own are not available. You can only buy hospitals that we would, today -- that we consider not good long-term investments. We believe that much of the hospital supply that exists today in this country will be taken out of service. It will follow the path of many other sectors of real estate that you've seen taken out of service. We got a lot of empty department stores anchoring struggling malls in this country. Remember, there was a day that every city in America had its own unique department stores that were part of the social fabric. And those don't exist today because most of them have gone away or they're called Macy's. And you -- I predict that many of these communities that all have numerous acute care hospital systems, in the next 10, 20 years you'll see very few, and you'll see the big non-for-profit brand names in health care. So the Cleveland Clinics, the Mayo Clinics, the Johns Hopkins start to proliferate into other markets. So I think you can look a little bit at history and -- from a real estate perspective to know that a lot of hospital supply that you can buy today is probably going to be -- if you think the cap rates are attractive today, just wait a little while because they're going to be more attentive when you're buying buildings that are being taken out of service. So this is not an area that we will deploy capital. We think that is not the right strategy for our shareholders.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Juan, we have a guidance range that implies about, again, 10% growth, like you said. The majority of it is actually the run rate on existing hires and processes that have been put in place in 2015. That's about 2/3 of the growth. And then we have a
componenttext: Sure. Juan, we have a guidance range that implies about, again, 10% growth, like you said. The majority of it is actually the run rate on existing hires and processes that have been put in place in 2015. That's about 2/3 of the growth. And then we have a pretty limited remaining amount, call it, $5 million to $6 million that's largely what I would call professional services related. So those would included items like consulting, tax, legal, HR. And  what I would actually give as an example, because we're very focused on lowering our G&A cost, included in that G&A estimate is about $2 million to $3 million of consulting work we're doing in the tax area. But it's projected to generate savings of $6 million to $7 million on the tax expense line, so we actually had a little bit of a shifting that's going on this year where we're incurring a little bit higher G&A but net should save the company actually a good bit of money.

componenttext: Sure, yes. There's -- well, again, like we -- our tax expense guidance of $16 million to $18 million did include the benefit of those savings, so that number is lower in our forecast as a result. And an example is something like we have a pretty complicated number of structures in terms of the sheer number of TRSs in our RIDEA portfolio. So if we can consolidate 125 TRSs into one, that gets a lot more efficiency on which of them are generating income, the efficiency of it, the tax returns and it reduces your overall tax expenses. That's one of the projects that we're working on.
