headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Welltower Earnings Conference Call. My name is Holly, and I will be your conference operator today [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for repla
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Welltower Earnings Conference Call. My name is Holly, and I will be your conference operator today [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
Now I would like to turn the call over to Jeff Miller, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today for Welltower's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. If you did not receive a copy of the news release distributed this morning, you may access it via company's website at Wellt
componenttext:
Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today for Welltower's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. 
If you did not receive a copy of the news release distributed this morning, you may access it via company's website at Welltower.com. 
We are holding a live webcast of today's call, which may be accessed through the company's website.
Before we begin, let me remind you that certain statements made during this conference call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. 
Although, Welltower believes results projected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, the company can give no assurance that its projected results will be attained.
Factors and risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are detailed in the news release and from time to time in the company's filings with the SEC.
I will now turn the call over to, Tom DeRosa, CEO of Welltower. Tom?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff. This morning, I want to talk to you about real estate. The power of owning Class A real estate. What do I mean by that? I mean, real estate that is in locations and markets that cannot be easily duplicated. Real estate that is nimble, and
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff. This morning, I want to talk to you about real estate. The power of owning Class A real estate. What do I mean by that? I mean, real estate that is in locations and markets that cannot be easily duplicated. Real estate that is nimble, and adaptive to changing consumer preferences. 
Real estate that defies the conventional wisdom about supply and retain value across economic cycles. Overtime, the REITs that on Class A real estate have produced superior and resilient results as compared to our REITs that have not followed the strategy. Our quarter is yet another example, of a phenomenon that began for us in 2010. This my friends is why you own Welltower. 
The headline number that supports our thesis is that all operating same-store NOI grew by 5.5% in the first quarter. Now this number does not come as a surprise to us, in fact, it's totally consistent with the operating same-store NOI growth we have reported for our portfolio over the last 5 years. 
Our total portfolio NOI grew 3.8% and FFO has grown 9%, all parts of our business produced good results, but we did have a phenomenal quarter in our senior housing operating portfolio. While there have been real headwinds from increases in labor costs and other operating expenses, our Class A real estate was able to pass this along to the consumer in strong rate growth, while at the same time increasing occupancy by 60 basis points to 19.7%. 
Now on the last 2 earnings call, we told you that we remain bullish about the senior housing business, and continue to believe that despite pockets of oversupply in the industry, our portfolio of high barrier to entry markets, premier operators and modern assets will continue to create tremendous value for shareholders by generating attractive growth with minimal CapEx. 
We see the market taking the data on new supply and applying it broadly across the entire senior housing market. 
We think that is a mistake and our performance supports that.
We had a long conversation about our strategy around post-acute and Genesis last quarter. Despite short-term challenges, we continue to believe, you need to look beyond headlines and understand how the skilled nursing industry fits in the continuum of care. 
I'm very pleased by the fact that CMS recommended a 2.1% rate growth last week. The biggest Medicare increase in 7 years, and I think this supports our thesis. May I remind you that our Genesis portfolio remains concentrated in high density East Coast markets with significant 4 wall profitability. 
On our last call, we also discussed at length our capital allocation framework. Our sustained  relative out performance in same-store NOI growth is a product of the strategy as well as smart highly targeted investment discipline. 
Capital allocation is not just about when to buy, but also about what to buy, and what not to buy. You may have heard about our acquisition of a site on the corner of 56 Street in Lexington in New York City that together with Heines, we will build the Welltower, a state-of-the-art largely dimensional Alzheimer's care facility. The supply of residential care options for the growing elderly population of Manhattan is at best pathetic. 
For a population of over 1 million people, there are only 70 -- 70 marginal memory care beds in Manhattan. And I can tell you that they are a marginal quality, because we used to own them. The Welltower will be an anchor for an affluent challenge population that has been forced to live in the shadows. 
The Welltower will make them part of a larger community, which includes billionaires row 1 block away. Now we are limited by nondisclosure agreement and what I can share with you today, we hope to give you more color in the coming months. But what I can tell you is that we didn't sacrifice our return expectations and underwriting criteria to be in Manhattan. Frankly, I cannot think of a more Class A real estate opportunity. 
And with that, I'm going to turn the call over to Scott Brinker.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. A common question from investors the past few years was what would happen when the cycle turn? The answer today is very positive. Today's more challenging environment is highlighting that not all properties are the same, not all markets
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. A common question from investors the past few years was what would happen when the cycle turn? The answer today is very positive. 
Today's more challenging environment is highlighting that not all properties are the same, not all markets are the same, and not all operators are the same. Our portfolio outperformed in the up cycle, and today, we're seeing that continue. Each segment turned in a strong quarter with same-store results above guidance. That being said, I want to repeat something we said in the past. We don't overemphasize any one quarter good or bad. We think about our results overtime to reduce the noise that can occur over 90-day increments. 
I'll start with the operating portfolio, where top line fundamentals were incredibly strong. We increased rates 4.2%, out sacrificing sensors, as occupancy increased 60 basis points. The result was 5.5% same-store NOI growth well above expectations. 
CapEx remained at modest levels, the age of our properties is a material advantage, it allows us to generate superior, organic growth, while retaining earnings to fund new investments. 
Here are some color on each country. Performance in the U.S. was outstanding. Same-store NOI grew 5.1%, this is not a case of easy comps as we reported 5.2% growth in 1Q '15, not to mention in 8% CAGR in the first quarter of 2012, '13 and '14. An important takeaways that our core markets extended their long track record of out performance. And we'll continue to prioritize these markets with our capital allocation. 
Turning to Canada. Our 2 partners Revera and Chartwell delivered strong results, despite a sluggish economy. Same-store NOI grew 7.2% last quarter. Revenue increased nearly 5%, while expenses growth was in the mid-3s. It's to remind you seniors housing isn't perfectly correlated with the broader economy.
The U.K. bounce back with 6.1% same-store NOI growth. We're seeing very strong demand for our properties. Revenue grew by more than 5%, while expenses increased in the high-4s. By design, we are a private pay high end business in the U.K. This gives us the ability to better offset cost pressures like the increased minimum wage. It is equally true in the U.S..
Next I want to share you an observation on broader topic. Seniors housing is a private pay business, and it allows a supply and demand apply. That's why we chose to concentrate in markets with the ability and willingness to pay. These also happening to markets, which are more difficult to bring new supply. We know that location impacts performance, because we've been tracking the data inside a portfolio for years. 
Our data is a very powerful in a sector with the window in the industry level performance is limited to asking rents and occupancy. As a result, seniors housing remains an inefficient market, cap rates hardly vary at all based on locations. We think that will change as operating data in the industry becomes more transparent. When that happens, our unmatched scale in premier markets will be highly valuable.
Turning to outpatient medical. We extended our track record of consistent results, with 2.6% same-store NOI growth. We have excellent long-term visibility into this earning stream, driven by a low roll over and our history of renewing the vast majority of maturing pieces. 
Next up is the e triple-net portfolio. Quarter-after-quarter, including 1Q, the blended growth rate in this segment is in the 3% range. The lease structure gives us consistent and growing our rental income notwithstanding any volatility in the underlying operations. That's especially true of skilled nursing, a business that's long been subject to cycles. Public sentiment is even more volatile than the underlying business. And right now, the pendulum has clearly swung towards the negative. I'll contrast this volatility with skilled nursing valuations in the private market, which have been remarkably consistent overtime. If there is a prolonged disconnect between public and private valuations, we may look to take advantage to selective asset sales. 
Moving to investments. Our activity in 1Q was intentionally low given the environment. We funded $350 million at a 7.7% initial cash yield. As usual, these were done in private negotiations, not auctions, which helps explain the healthy yield. We expanded relationships with leading health systems like Accenture and Adventis, and we grew with core partners including Sunrise, Silverado and Signature. Each investment builds on what makes Welltower unique, premier markets, leading operators, and modern buildings. 
Our stock come back a bit since our last earnings call, but this still feels like a time to be highly selective with new investments. Our strong balance sheet and unmatched relationships allow us to be flexible, if conditions change. As expected, we had a $116 million loans pass last quarter, including $68 million of Genesis mortgage loans. We received continued repayments from Genesis throughout the year. The bridge to heart business plan is working as planned, will benefit Genesis cash flow and enhance the credit that stands behind our master lease. Now over to Scott Estes.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. We're off to a great start to the year, with strong quarterly earnings growth, and an increase in our same-store NOI forecast, reflecting our confidence in the continued strength of our portfolio. While significa
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. We're off to a great start to the year, with strong quarterly earnings growth, and an increase in our same-store NOI forecast, reflecting our confidence in the continued strength of our portfolio. While significant stock market volatility occurred during the first quarter, we remain highly focused on capital allocation. 
Our current earnings guidance continue to assume that we remain net sellers of assets for the full year. We're also able to enhance our liquidity position during the quarter, by opportunistically raising a $700 million of 10-year unsecured debt. Importantly, we are able to raise this debt in an overall leverage neutral manner through offsetting debt payoffs and a small amount of equity raise through our drip and ATM programs. As a result, we have no senior debt maturing until September 2017, and have only $398 million of secured debt maturing over the remainder of the year. With over $2 billion of current liquidity and a continued focus on capital allocation, our strong financial position allows us to remain both disciplined and opportunistic in regard to any incremental investments, dispositions and capital raises throughout the remainder of the year.
I'll again begin my detailed remarks with perspective on the first quarter performance and a minor change we made to our supplement this quarter. We started off the year with strong quarter-over-quarter earnings comparisons, generating normalized FFO of $1.13 per share, up 9% versus last year, and normalized FAD of $1.01 per share, increasing 10% versus last year. Results were driven primarily by our same-store cash NOI growth, and a $1.8 billion of net investments completed over the last four quarters. 
I'll comment briefly on several of the more noteworthy income statement items this quarter. First, our G&A came in at $46 million for the first quarter, this was in line with our expectations, as the first quarter is typically our highest of the year, due to the timing of expensing stock compensation grants for certain employees and directors. 
After a detailed review of our cost this year, we now expect to comment towards the low end of our initial guidance range of $160 million to $165 million for the full year. We recognized impairments of slightly $14 million in the first quarter, these impairments were result of a slight reductions in the carrying value of 2 relatively small seniors housing portfolios currently held-for-sale, which are now expected to be sold for roughly $167 million in the aggregate. And lastly, we recognized a tax benefit of $1.7 million in the first quarter. Our taxes came in slightly below our expectations for the quarter, as a result of both tax planning initiatives and several revisions to our TRS taxable income forecast. Based on this revised expectations, we now anticipate incurring quarterly tax expense of approximately $1 million to $2 million per quarter for the remaining 3 quarters of the year. 
In terms of dividends, we'll pay our 180th consecutive quarterly cash dividend on May 20 of $0.86 per share, rate of $3.44 annually. This represents a 4.2% increase over the dividends paid last year, and represents a current dividend yield of 4.9%.
In terms of our supplement, we made only one relatively minor adjustments in this quarter, as we moved our U.K.-based private pay outpatient facilities from our hospital getting ready to our outpatient medical category. This was done to reflect the fact that the vast majority of revenue comes from outpatient care and short stage surgery just like our outpatient surgical facilities in the U.S.. 
I'll now turn now to liquidity picture and balance sheet. I think the highlight of our first quarter capital markets activity was the unsecured debt offering, which closed on March 1. We completed the sale of $700 million of 10 years senior unsecured notes price to yield just over 4.3%. And took advantage of strong investor demand to upsize the transaction from the origin I announced size of $400 million. This offering help to extend our weighted average senior not maturities 10 and .2 years, and as a reminder, that this debt offering was not included in our initial earnings guidance for 2016. In terms of equity, we should over 1 million shares to our ATM program this quarter, raising $93 million in proceeds. As Scott mentioned, we generated $115 million of proceeds through loan payoffs, which included $68 million in Genesis mortgage loans repaid during the quarter. 
In terms of debt repayments, we repaid off $400 million of the 5-year 3 and 58 senior unsecured debt that matured on March 15 of 2016. 
And lastly, repaid approximately $130 million of secured debt at a blended rate of 4.5%, while refinancing $75 million of secured debt at a blended 3.1% rate. 
So as a result, we continue to have significant liquidity with over $2.2 billion available at quarter-end with only $645 million of line borrowings and $356 million in cash on balance sheet. Our balance sheet and financial metrics at end of the first quarter remain strong. As of March 31, our net debt to undepreciated book capitalization of 39.6% was consistent with last quarter, while our net debt to enterprise value improve 40 basis points to 32.3%. 
Our net debt to adjusted EBITDA stood at 5.7x, while our adjusted interest and fixed charge coverage the quarter remained solid at 4.1x and 3.2x, respectively. 
Our secured debt level remained at only 12.1% of total assets at quarter end. We were pleased to receive an affirmation of our BBB+ ratings from Fitch last week. And as a reminder, we set BAA2 BBB flat weddings with positive outlooks from both Moody's and S&P. 
I'll conclude my comments today with an update on the key assumptions driving our 2016 guidance.
First, in terms of same-store cash NOI growth. Based on our strong first quarter results across our entire portfolio, we're comfortable raising our same-store cash NOI guidance for the full year by 25 basis points to 2.75% to 3.25%. For same strength across virtually all of our respective portfolio components and as Scott mentioned, I think it's appropriate to remain focused on the blended forecast for our entire portfolio for the full year.
In terms of our expectations, the only acquisitions in our forecast beyond those closed in the first quarter are an additional $98 million of investments expected through our Mainstreet partnership at an initial cash yield of approximately 7.5%. In terms of development, we expect to fund an additional $363 million on projects currently under construction, and expect $283 million of additional development conversions at a blended project yield of 7.9%.
Now moving to a dispositions. We continue to include a total of $1 billion in our forecast. This is comprised of the $116 million of loan payoffs during the first quarter. Our current projection of $303 million in proceeds from properties currently held-for-sale at a blended yield on sale of 6.5%, with the remainder representing loan payoffs and other potential property sales over the rest of the year. 
Our capital expenditure forecast remains $83 million for 2016, which is comprised of approximately $55 million associated with the seniors housing operating portfolio, with the remaining $28 million coming from our outpatient medical portfolio. 
We typically see a lower cap expending during the first quarter, we do expect the remaining CapEx will be higher during the last 3 quarters of the year. 
As previously mentioned, our G&A forecast is tracking around a $160 million for the full year at this point. And as I also discussed earlier, our tax expenses are likely to be about $1 million to $2 million per quarter for the remaining 3 quarters of the year. So finally, as a result of these assumptions, we're maintaining our FFO guidance of $4.50 to $4.60 per diluted share. And FAD guidance of $3.95 to $4.05 per diluted share, both of which represents 3% to 5% growth over normalized 2015 results.
I think it's important to note that our decision to maintain both our FFO and FAD guidance ranges is today was related to the fact that our $700 million bond offering was not in our original forecast, and that there is still considerable variability around the timing of the approximate $900 million of dispositions that have yet to occur. 
Most importantly, we continue to focus on making prudent capital allocation decisions to sent in our balance sheet, and maintain significant liquidity and the current environment. So in conclusion, our continued focus on capital allocation this year will continue to prioritize enhancing the quality of our portfolio and private payments, maintaining a strong balance sheet and low leverage, and retaining ample liquidity is through greater stability in the broader capital markets environment. So at that point, I'll turn it back over to Tom for some closing comments.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. So as you heard, we're quite pleased by our Q1 results. It's all about the real estate, and how we are driving better performance and value from our industry-leading health care real estate platform. Our optimism and our ability to sustain
componenttext: Thanks, Scott. So as you heard, we're quite pleased by our Q1 results. It's all about the real estate, and how we are driving better performance and value from our industry-leading health care real estate platform. Our optimism and our ability to sustain this performance is reflected in our decision to raise our 2016 guidance for same-store NOI growth to 2.75% to 3.25%. And with that, I'd like to ask Holly to open up the line, so that we can take your questions about audits.

componenttext: Well, we'll all have something say to about this, but I would say again, not to be it's about having the best located senior housing assets in their markets with the equality operators. So there is demand to be in these buildings. And as the operators are sustaining real increases and expenses largely due to labor, they can pass it along, because there is demand to be in those buildings. I think it's  that's one of the simple, probably about simple answer I can give you. Scott, any other you want to say?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Paul on the outperformance, really 3 drivers of the business. Operating expenses, and those were up in the low to mid-4s, sort of where we expected. And the other 2 drivers are occupancy and rate. And we outperformed on, so we're expecting occupancy
componenttext: Yes. Paul on the outperformance, really 3 drivers of the business. Operating expenses, and those were up in the low to mid-4s, sort of where we expected. And the other 2 drivers are occupancy and rate. And we outperformed on, so we're expecting occupancy to be roughly flat to up slightly for the year, in stead we were up 60 basis points. And rate growth at 4.2% was quite a bit above where we were projecting.

componenttext: The colors that the majority of our portfolio is located at least in the U.S. in 6 core markets. And those markets continue to outperform by a very meaningful factor. So from quarter-to-quarter, it might be 2x, might my 5x, which was what we saw in the first quarter. And those are the markets that we prioritize for years, and we'll continue to prioritize. And so that doesn't you will see 100% concentrated in 6 years market, we like some level of diversification, but frankly just see much better supply demand over long periods of time in these core markets. And we've established partnerships with the operators that essentially control the markets. So a company like Sunrise, it has 31-plus buildings in Southern California, that's tough to replicate when it takes 4 to 5 years to seek approvals to build a new project. So we're very selective going back years, and who we chose to do business with in which markets they had a concentration.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're seeing the benefit of the discipline we have had to sell out of those marginal markets overtime. I mean, that is paying a dividend today. You know for a REIT, that's a difficult thing to do. But our shareholders have been on that line with us now f
componenttext: You're seeing the benefit of the discipline we have had to sell out of those marginal markets overtime. I mean, that is paying a dividend today. You know for a REIT, that's a difficult thing to do. But our shareholders have been on that line with us now for a number of years, we sold a lot of assets, we've acquired a lot of assets. And it's all about having the data and the discipline to allocate capital into the best markets and deemphasize the markets that just will not perform overtime. That's what we do. I think it's one of the keys to this company strategy and its success.

Rich, somewhat additional context on the rack audits, because it's I don't know maybe it's the name has everybody all worked up. We're not trying to suggest that it's not an issue, it's just we're trying to put some context around it because today as Tom mentioned, roughly $100 million of overpayments were essentially given back to the Medicare program for skilled nursing, that's on a $30 billion denominator, so it's 0.3%, 0.3%, even, if that number increases by 7x, right, I mean, 7x, it still just the equivalent of the Medicare inflation update that CMS is proposing for next year. 
So I mean, it's not like this is going to bankrupt the industry and for obligators that have trade documentation, it will have absolutely no impact other than in a case we're heading.

componenttext: They're definitely benefiting from some of the synergies on the acquisitions. They are benefiting from the refinancing of the bridge loans. It's roughly 10%, how does in the low force that's a big difference. But longer-term we actually, think the story is very positive, we are muster leases, 100 to 7 properties in major sin 16 years they have a lot of individual leases, and our smaller leases that mature next year are in the next 5 years, frankly, a very low coverage, they were rigid them are they will substantially read appreciate that rents and on words. So there is a lot of those types of opportunities, they could certainly, exit some of the lower quality buildings, that they have acquired. We support them in that effort, their optimization opportunities in the assets that they acquired because they are premier operator. And if you think long-term, bundling, the challenge right now with that, hospitals and managed care payers are already starting to reduce admissions to skilled nursing, but I don't think it started the process of targeting the best-in-class properties in each market, and when that happens I think there actually, is an opportunity for Genesis to outperform and take market share, but we're just not in that phase of the bundling rollout yet.

componenttext: Rich, at least in our world, we see no evidence of that, and let me give you an example of something that we recently saw. The Cleveland Clinic is building a new hospital in Avon, Ohio about 40 miles, that's west of Cleveland. And this hospital, which actually the project looks a lot like what we did in New Jersey. With that, you're going to have a skilled nursing facility attached to the hospital. And clinic isn't running that facility there is another operator, that would be running that facility, I believe it's select medical. That to me as a good indication of where the future might be going. And it validates the fact that the sector as not going away, when you have one of the finest hospitals in the systems in the world. Now putting skilled nursing, not only on the campus, but actually, I attached to the building. So I think that more and more some are conversations with the leading health systems, we don't spend a lot of time with the non-leading health systems, I continue the view from talking to that major players who will survive in the hospital sector, and that they want to see a strong skilled nursing industry, they know it is part of the future, and part of their ability to manage profitability under an ever-changing reimbursement environment.

And if anything you see in payment coverage is unfortunately, declined a bit art dust is flat, suggest the underlying and Hawaii properties only going 3% and clearly, been a lot better than that. So there is a divergence, it gets to the point I was making earlier, about there is variation in performance by market, by operator. And I don't think the market fully appreciates that yet, we are trying to tell the story, I think the longer-term history will be helpful, but we have seen that in our data, the industry data that is in there for people to see, there isn't even a reliable source of NOI in the industry, I men I need to say NICs doing a great job in trying to do change that. As of today the best you can get as occupancy and asking rent. At the national level, I mean, you talked about a lot of room to grow, you can pair that with 15 to 20 years of data in our portfolio that is detail for us to look at and help make investment decisions, we feel like it's a huge proprietary advantage that we have.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Triple-net coverage is a bit lower than we would like. It frankly is for the most part driven by 1 operator. So it was a 115, 2 years ago, now it's 110. All of that driven by a particular operator unfortunately. So the rest of the portfolio I saw that
componenttext: No. Triple-net coverage is a bit lower than we would like. It frankly is for the most part driven by 1 operator. So it was a 115, 2 years ago, now it's 110. All of that driven by a particular operator unfortunately. So the rest of the portfolio I saw that well. But the reality is it's the main reason you haven't seen us do a lot of triple-net lease acquisitions in recent years, because I think there was a mindset by some and is going back couple of years that if you could put something in the triple-net lease it was a low risk environment. So high escalators, life is great, a release work is fantastic and leave it sometimes a year to people to realize, if the asset quality isn't very good, notwithstanding that very structure, which on the surface seems to provide protection for the lawn are, at the end of the day is a very risky investment, in our view it is always been the higher risk investments actually, triple-net lease as a with low assets, coverage and low asset quality in comparison to doing every day, which granted have some quarter-to-quarter volatility in NOI, but overtime, if you own the grade assets in the right markets, you think that's the lowest risk investments.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, the new supply is, it's an interesting data point, that almost half of the new supply in the U.S. is in 6 specific markets, notwithstanding right, almost half of the new supplies in 6 markets, when you really think about it. And only 8% of our NOI in the operating portfolios in those 6 markets. So that means 92% of our NOI is in all of the other markets, where frankly, in the lot of them, either no new supply or not much. So it really is a market specific issue. We keep saying it and now you're starting to see it in the results, I think.

componenttext: Yes. No. That make sense. headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say with a lot of specificity, but for the most part, you increase wages on January 1. So you have to recognize that higher expense on day one of the year. And with rental rates, at least with existing resin, you try to increase rates on Janu
componenttext: It's hard to say with a lot of specificity, but for the most part, you increase wages on January 1. So you have to recognize that higher expense on day one of the year. And with rental rates, at least with existing resin, you try to increase rates on January 1, but half of our portfolio, the operators increase rates on the anniversary date. So they bleed in over the years. So when we again, this isn't black or white. But in general, you have to suffer the higher wage growth immediately, while the rate growth would blend in more of the course of the year.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just last one from me on the nursing side. Wondering, if you looked at the recent data CMS released on readmissions to hospitals. It's sort of in talking to different stakeholders it seems like that's going to be an important metric in determining who may be preferred vendors or who may see more volume. It's interesting, when you look at the star ratings, which I know there are several components, Genesis screen sort of average versus the U.S., but actually very well on the readmission side. Just wondering, if you dug into it or have any thoughts around that as to how that could be a future differentiator?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do think that quality operators in the skilled sector will again have the strategy and program built to minimize readmissions. I think that if you have a random portfolio of mom-and-pop operators, who may be very good at what they do, is just from our
componenttext: We do think that quality operators in the skilled sector will again have the strategy and program built to minimize readmissions. I think that if you have a random portfolio of mom-and-pop operators, who may be very good at what they do, is just from our perspective it could be difficult to understand if they do have the structure in place to be a more viable partner to the acute care hospitals. So and we just think that, again, because of it scale, because of its program strategy, because of technology, we think Genesis is in a pretty good position.

So a lot of question there, we're not talking about when we paid the rent, we're talking about what the coverage 1.24 or 1.28. headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Welltower Earnings Conference Call. My name is Holly, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for repl
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Welltower Earnings Conference Call. My name is Holly, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
Now I would like to turn the call over to Jeff Miller, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today for Welltower's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. If you did not receive a copy of the news release distributed this morning, you may access it via the company's website at w
componenttext:
Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today for Welltower's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. 
If you did not receive a copy of the news release distributed this morning, you may access it via the company's website at welltower.com. 
We are holding a live webcast of today's call, which may be accessed through the company's website.
Before we begin, let me remind you that certain statements made during this conference call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. 
Although, Welltower believes results projected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, the company can give no assurance that its projected results will be attained.
Factors and risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are detailed in the news release and from time to time in the company's filings with the SEC.
I will now turn the call over to Tom DeRosa, CEO of Welltower. Tom?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff. This morning, I want to talk to you about real estate. The power of owning Class A real estate. What do I mean by that? I mean real estate that is in locations and markets that cannot be easily duplicated. Real estate that is nimble, and
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff. This morning, I want to talk to you about real estate. The power of owning Class A real estate. What do I mean by that? I mean real estate that is in locations and markets that cannot be easily duplicated. Real estate that is nimble, and adaptive to changing consumer preferences. 
Real estate that defies the conventional wisdom about supply and retain value across economic cycles. Overtime, the REITs that own Class A real estate have produced superior and resilient results as compared to REITs that have not followed this strategy. Our quarter is yet another example of a phenomenon that began for us in 2010. This, my friends, is why you own Welltower. 
The headline number that supports our thesis is that our operating same-store NOI grew by 5.5% in the first quarter. Now this number does not come as a surprise to us. In fact, it's totally consistent with the operating same-store NOI growth we have reported for our portfolio over the last 5 years. 
Our total portfolio NOI grew 3.8% and FFO has grown 9%. All parts of our business produced good results, but we did have a phenomenal quarter in our senior housing operating portfolio. While there have been real headwinds from increases in labor costs and other operating expenses, our Class A real estate was able to pass this along to the consumer in strong rate growth while at the same time, increasing occupancy by 60 basis points to 90.7%. 
Now on the last 2 earnings calls, we told you that we remain bullish about the senior housing business, and continue to believe that despite pockets of oversupply in the industry, our portfolio of high barrier to entry markets, premier operators and modern assets will continue to create tremendous value for shareholders by generating attractive growth with minimal CapEx. 
We see the market taking the data on new supply and applying it broadly across the entire senior housing market. 
We think that is a mistake and our performance supports that.
We had a long conversation about our strategy around post-acute and Genesis last quarter. Despite short-term challenges, we continue to believe you need to look beyond headlines and understand how the skilled nursing industry fits in the continuum of care. 
I am very pleased by the fact that CMS recommended a 2.1% rate growth last week. The biggest Medicare increase in 7 years, and I think this supports our thesis. May I remind you that our Genesis portfolio remains concentrated in high density East Coast markets with significant 4-wall profitability. 
On our last call, we also discussed at length our capital allocation framework. Our sustained relative out performance in same-store NOI growth is a product of this strategy as well as a smart highly targeted investment discipline. 
Capital allocation is not just about when to buy, but also about what to buy, and what not to buy. You may have heard about our acquisition of a site on the corner of 56th Street and Lexington in New York City. That, together with Hines, we will build the Welltower, a state-of-the-art largely dementia Alzheimer's care facility. The supply of residential care options for the growing elderly population of Manhattan is, at best, pathetic. 
For a population of over 1 million people, there are only 70, 7-0 marginal memory care beds in Manhattan. And I can tell you that they are of marginal quality because we used to own them. The Welltower will be an anchor for an affluent cognitively challenged population that has been forced to live in the shadows. 
The Welltower will make them part of a larger community, which includes Billionaires' Row one block away. Now we are limited by a nondisclosure agreement in what I can share with you today. We hope to give you more color in the coming months. But what I can tell you is that we didn't sacrifice our return expectations and underwriting criteria to be in Manhattan. Frankly, I cannot think of a more Class A real estate opportunity. 
And with that, I'm going to turn the call over to Scott Brinker.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Tom. A common question from investors the past few years was what would happen when the cycle turned? The answer today is very positive. Today's more challenging environment is highlighting that not all properties are the same, not all
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Tom. A common question from investors the past few years was what would happen when the cycle turned? The answer today is very positive. 
Today's more challenging environment is highlighting that not all properties are the same, not all markets are the same, and not all operators are the same. Our portfolio outperformed in the up cycle, and today, we're seeing that continue. Each segment turned in a strong quarter with same-store results above guidance. That being said, I want to repeat something we've said in the past. We don't overemphasize any one quarter good or bad. We think about our results overtime to reduce the noise that can occur over 90-day increments. 
I'll start with the operating portfolio, where top line fundamentals were incredibly strong. We increased rates 4.2% without sacrificing census, as occupancy increased 60 basis points. The result was 5.5% same-store NOI growth well above expectations. 
CapEx remains at modest levels. The age of our properties is a material advantage. It allows us to generate superior, organic growth, while retaining earnings to fund new investments. 
Here are some color on each country. Performance in the U.S. was outstanding. Same-store NOI grew 5.1%. This is not a case of easy comps as we reported 5.2% growth in 1Q '15, not to mention an 8% CAGR in the first quarter of 2012, '13 and '14. An important takeaway is that our core markets extended their long track record of out performance. And we'll continue to prioritize these markets with our capital allocation. 
Turning to Canada. Our 2 partners, Revera and Chartwell, delivered strong results despite a sluggish economy. Same-store NOI grew 7.2% last quarter. Revenue increased nearly 5% while expense growth was in the mid-3s, to remind you that seniors housing isn't perfectly correlated with the broader economy.
The U.K. bounced back with 6.1% same-store NOI growth. We're seeing very strong demand for our properties. Revenue grew by more than 5% while expenses increased in the high-4s. By design, we're a private pay high end business in the U.K. This gives us the ability to better offset cost pressures like the increased minimum wage. It is equally true in the U.S..
Next, I want to share an observation on a broader topic. Seniors housing is a private pay business, and the laws of supply and demand apply. That's why we chose to concentrate in markets with the ability and willingness to pay. This is also happening to markets where it's more difficult to bring new supply. We know that location impacts performance because we've been tracking the data inside our portfolio for years. 
Our data is very powerful in a sector where the window in the industry level performance is limited to asking rents and occupancy. As a result, seniors housing remains an inefficient market. Cap rates hardly vary at all based on location. We think that will change as operating data in the industry becomes more transparent. And when that happens, our unmatched scale in premier markets will be highly valuable.
Turning to outpatient medical. We extended our track record of consistent results, with 2.6% same-store NOI growth. We have excellent long-term visibility into this earning stream, driven by low rollover and our history of renewing the vast majority of maturing leases. 
Next up is the triple-net portfolio. Quarter-after-quarter, including 1Q, the blended growth rate in this segment is in the 3% range. The lease structure gives us consistent and growing rental income notwithstanding any volatility in the underlying operations. That's especially true of skilled nursing, a business that's long been subject to cycles. Public sentiment is even more volatile than the underlying business. And right now, the pendulum has clearly swung toward the negative. I'll contrast this volatility with skilled nursing valuations in the private market, which have been remarkably consistent overtime. If there is a prolonged disconnect between public and private valuations, we may look to take advantage through selective asset sales. 
Moving to investments. Our activity in 1Q was intentionally low given the environment. We funded $350 million at a 7.7% initial cash yield. As usual, these were done in private negotiations, not auctions, which helps explain the healthy yield. We expanded relationships with leading health systems like Ascension and Adventist, and we grew with core partners, including Sunrise, Silverado and Signature. Each investment builds on what makes Welltower unique, premier markets, leading operators, and modern buildings. 
Our stock has come back a bit since our last earnings call, but this still feels like a time to be highly, highly selective with new investments. Our strong balance sheet and unmatched relationships allow us to be flexible, if conditions change. As expected, we had $116 million of loan payoffs last quarter, including $68 million of Genesis mortgage loans. We'll receive continued repayments from Genesis throughout the year. The bridge to HUD business plan is working as planned, will benefit Genesis cash flow and enhance the credit that stands behind our master lease. Now over to Scott Estes.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. We're off to a great start to the year with strong quarterly earnings growth, and an increase in our same-store NOI forecast, reflecting our confidence in the continued strength of our portfolio. While signifi
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. We're off to a great start to the year with strong quarterly earnings growth, and an increase in our same-store NOI forecast, reflecting our confidence in the continued strength of our portfolio. While significant stock market volatility occurred during the first quarter, we remain highly focused on capital allocation. 
Our current earnings guidance continues to assume that we remain net sellers of assets for the full year. We are also able to enhance our liquidity position during the quarter by opportunistically raising $700 million of 10-year unsecured debt. Importantly, we were able to raise this debt in an overall leverage neutral manner through offsetting debt payoffs and a small amount of equity raise through our DRIP and ATM programs. As a result, we have no senior debt maturing until September 2017, and have only $398 million of secured debt maturing over the remainder of the year. With over $2 billion of current liquidity and a continued focus on capital allocation, our strong financial position allows us to remain both disciplined and opportunistic in regard to any incremental investments, dispositions and capital raises throughout the remainder of the year.
I'll again begin my detailed remarks with perspective on our first quarter financial performance and a minor change we made to our supplement this quarter. We started off the year with strong quarter-over-quarter earnings comparisons, generating normalized FFO of $1.13 per share, up 9% versus last year, and normalized FAD of $1.01 per share, increasing 10% versus last year. Results were driven primarily by our same-store cash NOI growth, and a $1.8 billion of net investments completed over the last 4 quarters. 
I'll comment briefly on several of the more noteworthy income statement items this quarter. First, our G&A came in at $46 million for the first quarter. This was in line with our expectations, as the first quarter is typically our highest of the year due to the timing of expensing stock compensation grants for certain employees and directors. 
After a detailed review of our cost this year, we now expect to comment towards the low end of our initial guidance range of $160 million to $165 million for the full year. We recognized impairments of slightly over $14 million in the first quarter. These impairments were a result of slight reductions in the carrying value of 2 relatively small seniors housing portfolios currently held-for-sale, which are now expected to be sold for roughly $167 million in the aggregate. And last, we recognized a tax benefit of $1.7 million in the first quarter. Taxes came in slightly below our expectations for the quarter as a result of both tax planning initiatives and several revisions to our TRS taxable income forecasts. Based on these revised expectations, we now anticipate incurring quarterly tax expense of approximately $1 million to $2 million per quarter for the remaining 3 quarters of the year. 
In terms of dividends, we'll pay our 180th consecutive quarterly cash dividend on May 20 of $0.86 per share, a rate of $3.44 annually. This represents a 4.2% increase over the dividends paid last year, and represents a current dividend yield of 4.9%.
In terms of our supplement, we made only one relatively minor adjustment this quarter, as we moved our U.K.-based private pay outpatient facilities from our hospital category to our outpatient medical category. This was done to reflect the fact that the vast majority of revenue comes from outpatient care and elective short stage surgery just like our outpatient surgical facilities in the U.S. 
I'll turn now to our liquidity picture and balance sheet. I think the highlight of our first quarter capital markets activity was the unsecured debt offering, which closed on March 1. We completed the sale of $700 million of 10-year senior unsecured notes price to yield just over 4.3%. We took advantage of strong investor demand to upsize the transaction from the originally announced size of $400 million. This offering helped extend our weighted average senior note maturities to 9.2 years. And as a reminder, that this debt offering was not included in our initial earnings guidance for 2016. In terms of equity, we issued over 1 million shares through our DRIP and ATM program this quarter, raising $93 million in proceeds. As Scott mentioned, we generated $116 million of proceeds through loan payoffs, which included the $68 million in Genesis mortgage loans repaid during the quarter. 
In terms of debt repayments, we repaid off $400 million of the 5-year 3 5/8 senior unsecured debt that matured on March 15, 2016. 
And last, we repaid approximately $130 million of secured debt at a blended rate of 4.5%, while refinancing $75 million of secured debt at a blended 3.1% rate. 
So as a result, we continue to have significant liquidity with over $2.2 billion available at quarter end with only $645 million of line borrowings and $356 million in cash on balance sheet. Our balance sheet and financial metrics at the end of the first quarter remained strong. As of March 31, our net debt to undepreciated book capitalization of 39.6% was consistent with last quarter, while our net debt to enterprise value improve 40 basis points to 32.3%. 
Our net debt to adjusted EBITDA stood at 5.7x, while our adjusted interest and fixed charge coverage the quarter remained solid at 4.1x and 3.2x, respectively. 
Our secured debt level remained at only 12.1% of total assets at quarter end. We were pleased to receive an affirmation of our BBB+ ratings from Fitch last week. And as a reminder, we sit at Baa2 BBB flat ratings with positive outlooks from both Moody's and S&P. 
I'll conclude my comments today with an update on the key assumptions driving our 2016 guidance.
First, in terms of same-store cash NOI growth. Based on our strong first quarter result across our entire portfolio, we're comfortable raising our same-store cash NOI guidance for the full year by 25 basis points to 2.75% to 3.25%. We're seeing strength across virtually all of our respective portfolio components, and as Scott mentioned, I think it's appropriate to remain focused on the blended forecast for our entire portfolio for the full year.
In terms of our expectations, the only acquisitions in our forecast beyond those closed in the first quarter are an additional $98 million of investments expected through our Mainstreet partnership at an initial cash yield of approximately 7.5%. In terms of development, we expect to fund an additional $363 million on projects currently under construction, and expect $283 million of additional development conversions at a blended projected yield of 7.9%.
Moving to dispositions. We continue to include a total of $1 billion in our forecast. This is comprised of the $116 million of loan payoffs during the first quarter. Our current projection of $303 million in proceeds from properties currently held-for-sale at a blended yield on sale of 6.5%, with the remainder representing loan payoffs and other potential property sales over the rest of the year. 
Our capital expenditure forecast remains $83 million for 2016, which is comprised of approximately $55 million associated with the seniors housing operating portfolio, with the remaining $28 million coming from our outpatient medical portfolio. 
We typically see lower CapEx spending during the first quarter, so we do expect the remaining CapEx will be higher during the last 3 quarters of the year. 
As previously mentioned, our G&A forecast is tracking around $160 million for the full year at this point. And as I also discussed earlier, our tax expenses are likely to be about $1 million to $2 million per quarter for the remaining 3 quarters of the year. So finally, as a result of these assumptions, we're maintaining our FFO guidance of $4.50 to $4.60 per diluted share and FAD guidance of $3.95 to $4.05 per diluted share, both of which represents 3% to 5% growth over normalized 2015 results.
I think it's important to note that our decision to maintain both our FFO and FAD guidance ranges today was related to the fact that our $700 million bond offering was not in our original forecast, and that there is also still considerable variability around the timing of the approximate $900 million of dispositions that have yet to occur. 
Most importantly, we continue to focus on making prudent capital allocation decisions to strengthen our balance sheet and maintain significant liquidity in the current environment. So in conclusion, our continued focus on capital allocation this year will continue to prioritize enhancing the quality of our portfolio and private payments, maintaining a strong balance sheet and low leverage, and retaining ample liquidity and build a greater stability in the broader capital markets environment. So at that point, I'll turn it back to Tom for some closing comments.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. So as you heard, we're quite pleased by our Q1 results. It's all about the real estate, and how we are driving better performance and value from our industry-leading health care real estate platform. Our optimism and our ability to sustain
componenttext: Thanks, Scott. So as you heard, we're quite pleased by our Q1 results. componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about what -- kind of what came in above your expectations in the quarter in terms of the RIDEA portfolio? I mean is there anything sort of at the market level or -- that gave you the confidence kind of early in the year to boost the guidance or any color there?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll all have something say to about this, but I would say again, not to beat a dead horse, it's about having the best located senior housing assets in their markets with the quality operators. So there's demand to be in these buildings. And as the
componenttext: Well, we'll all have something say to about this, but I would say again, not to beat a dead horse, it's about having the best located senior housing assets in their markets with the quality operators. So there's demand to be in these buildings. And as the operators are sustaining real increases and expenses largely due to labor, they can pass it along because there is demand to be in those buildings. I think it's -- that's one of the simple -- that's probably the most simple answer I can give you. Scott, any other thing you want to say?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Paul, on the outperformance, really 3 drivers of the business. Operating expenses, and those were up in the low to mid-4s, sort of where we expected. And the other 2 drivers are occupancy and rate, and we outperformed on both. So we were expecting oc
componenttext: Yes. Paul, on the outperformance, really 3 drivers of the business. Operating expenses, and those were up in the low to mid-4s, sort of where we expected. And the other 2 drivers are occupancy and rate, and we outperformed on both. So we were expecting occupancy to be roughly flat to up slightly for the year, instead we were up 60 basis points. And rate growth at 4.2% was quite a bit above where we were projecting.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean is there any kind of color? You say it's not really kind of regional thing. Or in terms of kind of maybe the parts of your portfolio that are exposed to supply kind of hang in there better or I mean, kind of more than just sort of a kind of a macro
componenttext: I mean is there any kind of color? You say it's not really kind of regional thing. Or in terms of kind of maybe the parts of your portfolio that are exposed to supply kind of hang in there better or I mean, kind of more than just sort of a kind of a macro perspective?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The colors that the majority of our portfolio is located, at least, in the U.S. in 6 core markets. And those markets continue to outperform by a very meaningful factor. So from quarter-to-quarter, it might be 2x, it might be 5x, which was what we saw
componenttext: Yes. The colors that the majority of our portfolio is located, at least, in the U.S. in 6 core markets. And those markets continue to outperform by a very meaningful factor. So from quarter-to-quarter, it might be 2x, it might be 5x, which was what we saw in the first quarter. And those are the markets that we've prioritized for years, and we'll continue to prioritize. And so that doesn't you'll see us be 100% concentrated in 6 U.S. markets. We like some level of diversification, but, frankly, we just see much better supply demand over long periods of time in these core markets. And we've established partnerships with the operators that essentially control the markets. So a company like Sunrise, it has 30-plus buildings in Southern California. That's tough to replicate when it takes 4 to 5 years just to get approvals to build a new project. So we're very selective going back years in who we chose to do business with in which markets they had a concentration in.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're seeing the benefit of the discipline we have had to sell out of those marginal markets overtime. I mean that is paying a dividend today. For a REIT, that's a difficult thing to do. But our shareholders have been on that ride with us now for a numbe
componenttext: You're seeing the benefit of the discipline we have had to sell out of those marginal markets overtime. I mean that is paying a dividend today. For a REIT, that's a difficult thing to do. But our shareholders have been on that ride with us now for a number of years. We've sold a lot of assets, we've acquired a lot of assets. And it's all about having the data and the discipline to allocate capital into the best markets and deemphasize the markets that just will not perform overtime. That's what we do. I think it's one of the keys to this company's strategy and its success.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: One final point, I think, is important to add to in your question was, I guess, largely based on seniors housing. Our MOB performance was above our initial guidance for the full year as well as the post-acute same-store NOI. So we saw it really across the board this quarter.

componenttext: Okay. So just thinking about your shop portfolio. Can you actually go into the build up of that? I assume you're at 2.25% to 3.25% right now for the full year? Is that mostly going to be on -- that's going to be on rate still assuming not much occupancy change or are you assuming some occupancy decline as well?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chad, it's Scott Brinker. We're not really changing the guidance that we gave for the data portfolio. We've increased the company's overall same-store growth projection for the year, and that's, of course, driven in part by the outperformance on the opera
componenttext: Chad, it's Scott Brinker. We're not really changing the guidance that we gave for the data portfolio. We've increased the company's overall same-store growth projection for the year, and that's, of course, driven in part by the outperformance on the operating portfolio. But we're trying to keep people away from being overly focused on every single segment quarter-to-quarter. This is a portfolio, and it out performed in the first quarter. And that's why we raised the guidance. Your question is, do we feel good about the operating portfolio at the end of the day. The answer is yes. We have much better revenue growth driven by occupancy and rate and we were expecting at the beginning of the year, we don't see that changing overnight, but we also don't see a need to continue to update every quarter what the guidance is going to be.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. It did increase operating expenses, compensation in particular, because lot of the employees are hourly. So our rough guess is that compensation was up about 100 basis points more than it otherwise would have been because of the extra day. That being said, some of our operators charge by the day rather than by the month. So we did get some benefit on revenue.

componenttext: Sure. So we have 2 wholly secured first mortgage loans with Genesis that they used to complete 2 mergers last year. In total, they had about $500 million of original principle balance. And they've now repaid roughly $120 million. So their balance today is around $370 million, $380 million.

componenttext: Yes. Exactly. So they had a weak fourth quarter of 2014 as well. And at least some of the issues that they referred to in their fourth quarter earnings release did not impact our portfolio like all the bad debt adjustments they booked for Skilled Health, that doesn't impact us. And they reality is we own their best asset, and I think we're maybe at least a bit less impacted by some of the headbands that they're feeling elsewhere. But there's no question that the operating environment is a bit challenging. So I wouldn't be surprised if coverage was under at least a bit of pressure over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, you had mentioned earlier that seniors housing cap rates have been consistent or roughly the same for high and low barrier markets. But are you seeing them up more badly? And then is there maybe little bit of a faster creep higher in the lower barr
componenttext: Scott, you had mentioned earlier that seniors housing cap rates have been consistent or roughly the same for high and low barrier markets. But are you seeing them up more badly? And then is there maybe little bit of a faster creep higher in the lower barrier versus the higher barrier markets?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, we haven't really seen senior housing cap rates move at all. It feels like it's been almost a year now, where a lot of buyers, including us, have been trying to push for higher cap rates. But for the most part, especially in auctions, without much
componenttext: Kevin, we haven't really seen senior housing cap rates move at all. It feels like it's been almost a year now, where a lot of buyers, including us, have been trying to push for higher cap rates. But for the most part, especially in auctions, without much success. And at least the packages we see, the sellers and the brokers don't seem to reduce their expectations if they're trying to sell product that's outside of our core markets. So you've not seen us prioritize or allocate our capital for those types of investments because we just don't feel like historically or even today you really get the yield premium that you should to make an investment in those markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That make senses. And then maybe following on that point on the disposition side, it certainly seems like senior housing we be a good place, if cap rates have held firm, to potentially to take some chips off the table. But outside of that, I know th
componenttext: Okay. That make senses. And then maybe following on that point on the disposition side, it certainly seems like senior housing we be a good place, if cap rates have held firm, to potentially to take some chips off the table. But outside of that, I know there are some debt repayments that's coming through, but where do you see the best value today on the sales side?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably in skilled nursing. I mentioned in the prepared remarks that despite the sometimes wild volatility in the public market, private market valuations in skilled nursing have been remarkably consistent. And we have been doing this for 15 years n
componenttext: It's probably in skilled nursing. I mentioned in the prepared remarks that despite the sometimes wild volatility in the public market, private market valuations in skilled nursing have been remarkably consistent. And we have been doing this for 15 years now, and it feels like cap rates in the skilled nursing space have hardly moved at all maybe inside of 50 basis point ban plus or minus year-after-year after year, notwithstanding what's happening in the reimbursement environment or with publicly traded stocks. And today, look, skilled nursing is only 15-or-so percent of our overall company. So it's hard to say how much it impacts our stock price. But based on the number of questions we get about it, I would say it has a very big and very large negative impact. And yet, we see transactions in the private marketplace, including very recently, prices that are quite attractive, really no different than a year ago, or 2 years ago when the public market loved skilled nursing. So I could see us taking advantage of that, if these conditions persist.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are more inbound calls regarding our interest in selling skilled nursing today than in seniors housing. So I think there are lot of investors out there in the private markets, as Scott has said, that are seeing the headlines, seeing how some of the
componenttext: There are more inbound calls regarding our interest in selling skilled nursing today than in seniors housing. So I think there are lot of investors out there in the private markets, as Scott has said, that are seeing the headlines, seeing how some of the misinformation that has been put out there, has created some tremendous volatility, and they're looking to take advantage of that. Or at least it's given them -- it's raised the idea of buying skilled nursing to a higher position in the queue for how they might deploy capital. So it's an interesting time, a bit of a paradox about how the public market is viewing this sector and how the private market is viewing it.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I agree on senior housing as well, 2 of the assets that are in the held-for-sale bucket are in very much secondary, if not, rural markets. And if the sales proceed as planned, we'll be selling those for less than a 6 cap on our rent. So we do still
componenttext: Kevin, I agree on senior housing as well, 2 of the assets that are in the held-for-sale bucket are in very much secondary, if not, rural markets. And if the sales proceed as planned, we'll be selling those for less than a 6 cap on our rent. So we do still feel like this is maybe a good time to exit some noncore senior housing assets as well. And the same applies to medical office where we've got about $100 million of assets held-for-sale on the balance sheet today. Again, at least in our mind, very attractive cap rates relative to markets and asset quality.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then last quick one for me. On the development side, definitely an interesting project in New York, I'm looking forward to hearing more there. It sounds like there's not a whole lot you can share. But looking for a second at deve
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then last quick one for me. On the development side, definitely an interesting project in New York, I'm looking forward to hearing more there. It sounds like there's not a whole lot you can share. But looking for a second at development in senior housing in the U.K., and I know it dates largely back to some prior arrangements, but as those properties get delivered, how are they performing? Are yields consistent with prior underwriting? And for the newly built purpose-built product there, is that performing well in today's market?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kevin, there are really 3 buckets. We have triple-net leases with Avery, who's now one of our top 10 operators, and they've far outperformed expectations on everything they've done, whether it's the acquisitions or other new development we funded. We
componenttext: Yes. Kevin, there are really 3 buckets. We have triple-net leases with Avery, who's now one of our top 10 operators, and they've far outperformed expectations on everything they've done, whether it's the acquisitions or other new development we funded. We've also got a large development pipeline and arrangement with Signature, which is Tom Newell, the ex-President of Sunrise, and they have far outperformed all expectations. We have a mortgage loan program with them where we put roughly 60% of the capital into the development and they fund the balance with equity. And then we have a fixed price purchase option on the building after it opens and those have been remarkably successful. And we have quite a few more underway, all those in the greater London market. And then the third bucket is with Gracewell, which was essentially taken over by Sunrise. And those have been a bit below the underwriting expectations. I think Sunrise, to my point earlier to John's question, is just a lower price point than Sunrise is accustomed to operate in the U.K. And I think they're still trying to figure out what the right cost structure is for that lower revenue building. It's still mostly private pay, but it is a bit of a different building. So the NOI on those, Kevin, has been a bit lower than we had expected.
