componenttext: Kevin, there's only so much we can say about something like that. I would say that patience is a virtue sometimes, and the timing here worked particularly well for us, given cost of our capital today maybe versus in the past and our disposition proceeds that are pending. So we felt like this has always been our portfolio that we had our eye on. We always had operating partners that we thought could do a great job, creating value and the time he came together perfectly.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Kevin, we don't know of another opportunity to be able to create the level of scale in the Los Angeles and San Francisco markets that this acquisition will give to us. So we think it's a very -- a highly strategic move for us to be able to acquire Vin
componenttext: And Kevin, we don't know of another opportunity to be able to create the level of scale in the Los Angeles and San Francisco markets that this acquisition will give to us. So we think it's a very -- a highly strategic move for us to be able to acquire Vintage. We're very excited about it. I mean, the Vintage group --  Vintage Senior Living really assembled an excellent portfolio of assets in some extremely high barrier-to-entry locations. That's what we're all about. So this, as Scott said, down the middle of the fairway, this is exactly the type of growth opportunity that we seek out.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, I agree. Definitely some high-barrier locations there, right in our backyard here in Southern Cal. In the slides that you put out, the occupancy in the Southern Cal piece of the portfolio, I think it was around 83%. I was just curious given the
componenttext: Okay. Yes, I agree. Definitely some high-barrier locations there, right in our backyard here in Southern Cal. In the slides that you put out, the occupancy in the Southern Cal piece of the portfolio, I think it was around 83%. I was just curious given the nature of these assets and where they are, why that might be a little bit lower than kind of industry average? Any color there?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think there's opportunity to bring it up to the industry average. Our occupancy in these markets is in the low 90s. As our GE Sunrise, Silverado consistently run at that level and it will take a little time to get there, but we're confident that over t
componenttext: We think there's opportunity to bring it up to the industry average. Our occupancy in these markets is in the low 90s. As our GE Sunrise, Silverado consistently run at that level and it will take a little time to get there, but we're confident that over time, that these properties will be at the 90s percent level and that's why we -- one of the reasons why we seek the yield in this investment improving over time.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll just switch gears on to the Genesis and SNF side for a second. As we think about the overall exposure to these new bundling initiatives and try and quantify what that means for any particular operator, we try and pencil down what percent of NOI
componenttext: Okay. I'll just switch gears on to the Genesis and SNF side for a second. As we think about the overall exposure to these new bundling initiatives and try and quantify what that means for any particular operator, we try and pencil down what percent of NOI might be exposed to joints broadly. And then maybe go from there into the 67 geographies that are laid out under the CGR program. I'm just curious from you, and we can also talk exact numbers, but directionally, Genesis' exposure to CGR and in those 67 markets, how do you think about that and what if we're talking about ballpark terms, would you think that represents in terms of their NOI?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Kevin, the world of health care reimbursement is moving towards bundling. And it's hard to kind of answer your question incrementally because there's so many unknowns. Genesis is very much preparing for a world that looks different than today in
componenttext: I guess, Kevin, the world of health care reimbursement is moving towards bundling. And it's hard to kind of answer your question incrementally because there's so many unknowns. Genesis is very much preparing for a world that looks different than today in terms of reimbursement. And all I would say is the lowest cost setting with -- that can deliver the best outcome will be the winner.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping you could comment on the changes that Genesis announced yesterday with regards to its covenant to get a 20% to 25% buffer. If you could just comment on what we should expect that implies. Does that imply more pressure likely ahead? And i
componenttext: I was just hoping you could comment on the changes that Genesis announced yesterday with regards to its covenant to get a 20% to 25% buffer. If you could just comment on what we should expect that implies. Does that imply more pressure likely ahead? And if could you comment on what the covenants were and where they are now relative to those covenants and what the change was?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Juan. I'll answer what I can. Genesis will have their call on Friday. I think they're disclosing particular covenants but the point is when these covenants were set 3 and 4 years ago, it was a different business environment. And they were set at a le
componenttext: Yes, Juan. I'll answer what I can. Genesis will have their call on Friday. I think they're disclosing particular covenants but the point is when these covenants were set 3 and 4 years ago, it was a different business environment. And they were set at a level that give a cushion to the projected performance, and that's the same thing that we've done here. Right? I mean, the idea behind covenants is to give yourself a seat at the table when things are trending in the wrong direction so that you can sit down and have a rational discussion about how to proceed and that's what happened here among Genesis and its various capital partners. So we've agreed to reset the covenants to levels that certainly have all of us being paid. And as they disclosed, the cushion is in the 20% to 25% range against the EBITDA projection that they've recently provided that's based on today's operating environment.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so is the covenant with regards to fixed charge? And what's the new covenant level? And if you can comment, what did you guys get in return for the change to that covenant?
componenttext: And so is the covenant with regards to fixed charge? And what's the new covenant level? And if you can comment, what did you guys get in return for the change to that covenant?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't think it's appropriate to talk about specific numbers, Juan, but there is a fixed charge coverage, there's an interest coverage, there's a leverage covenant, liquidity, network, I mean, there are a number of covenants that hit all the key facto
componenttext: So I don't think it's appropriate to talk about specific numbers, Juan, but there is a fixed charge coverage, there's an interest coverage, there's a leverage covenant, liquidity, network, I mean, there are a number of covenants that hit all the key factors around corporate credit. And for us there's a master lease payment coverage as well.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on Genesis, you talked about the lenders being supportive of potential buyers of any assets you're looking to sell. What are you seeing in terms of lenders? And what kind of coverage levels do they want? And then maybe you can comment on ho
componenttext: Okay. And then on Genesis, you talked about the lenders being supportive of potential buyers of any assets you're looking to sell. What are you seeing in terms of lenders? And what kind of coverage levels do they want? And then maybe you can comment on how that is relative to your expectation for how your Genesis portfolio will look as the year progresses, given I think you said that the second quarter was strong, I don't know if that's 1 quarter trailing or kind of an asset today?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Juan, on the payment coverage, it's -- we're talking about because we always report on a trailing 12-month basis but also on a one quarter lag. So the number that you see in our reports is -- it can be a bit misleading. So when I talked about the sec
componenttext: Yes, Juan, on the payment coverage, it's -- we're talking about because we always report on a trailing 12-month basis but also on a one quarter lag. So the number that you see in our reports is -- it can be a bit misleading. So when I talked about the second quarter being strong, I'm talking literally about the 3 months from April 1 through June 30. And that, the performance in those 90 days was a nice improvement over the prior 2 quarters, which is encouraging to us. In terms of the payment coverage that lenders are looking for, and the same is true of the buyer pool, and it tends to be in the 1.3x coverage range. So our coverage today is close to 1.25x, so we're slightly below but not in any material way, which gives us additional comfort that these are very salable assets, particularly now that the Genesis corporate profile is a lot less uncertain than it was a week ago.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one last quick one from me. You guys have obviously a substantial exposure to Genesis and even if you were to call it $1 billion of dispositions over the next 12 months or whatever the time frame maybe, would you -- are you still rolling out a potent
componenttext: Just one last quick one from me. You guys have obviously a substantial exposure to Genesis and even if you were to call it $1 billion of dispositions over the next 12 months or whatever the time frame maybe, would you -- are you still rolling out a potential spin of whatever may remain after kind of a nation larger transaction?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are.
componenttext: Yes, we are.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico from UBS.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just another Genesis question. I mean, you said that one of the motivations here to do the term loan -- to become a term lender is to remove other lender parties from the discussion table, make it easier when trying to sell a chunk of the Genesis real est
componenttext: Just another Genesis question. I mean, you said that one of the motivations here to do the term loan -- to become a term lender is to remove other lender parties from the discussion table, make it easier when trying to sell a chunk of the Genesis real estate and deals where Genesis would stay as the tenant. So I get some of that motivation. But just the skeptic would say, it looks like no other lenders were willing to step in on a new term loan besides you and Omega, and then looking at the LIBOR plus 13% rate, doesn't that signal a very weak credit profile and that you were forced into becoming a lender of last resort here?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, it's Scott. It's interesting where we thought about the term loan is that it's not a core business. So 98% plus or minus of what we do is high-quality real estate. So you're not going to see us do things like this very often, on occasion to accompli
componenttext: Nick, it's Scott. It's interesting where we thought about the term loan is that it's not a core business. So 98% plus or minus of what we do is high-quality real estate. So you're not going to see us do things like this very often, on occasion to accomplish a longer-term, bigger goal, we'll extend the loan. And we have a good history of having those loans repaid. And in this situation, we can't speak for Omega but for Welltower, we told George and his team to go out and talk to the marketplace, see what a third party was willing to lend at, and we would be waiting to match it and that's what we did. Because this is an important security in the Genesis capital structure, and we prefer to control it rather than have a hospital third-party be in that position holding the cards even though they have 1% or less of the capital at risk. So the situation existed a week ago to us was untenable and was not allowing us to accomplish important goals. It was distracting Genesis, but we did not do a below-market loan, we didn't do an above-market loan. This is a market rate. Clearly, they are not a AAA credit. So we are being paid for the risks that we're taking.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then what's the incentive for Genesis at this point to go out and try to refinance the term loan? Right. I mean, it sounds like you guys want it to be a term loan in near term because it helps with some asset sales, helps shore up Genesis. But why --
componenttext: And then what's the incentive for Genesis at this point to go out and try to refinance the term loan? Right. I mean, it sounds like you guys want it to be a term loan in near term because it helps with some asset sales, helps shore up Genesis. But why -- if the rate is market, what is the incentive for Genesis to go out and refinance this with new term lenders?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, regardless of who the lender is, as one looks at one's capital stack, you'd want to pay off the highest costs that you can. So I would say that given that, Scott said, this is market terms for this kind of paper, it's always going to be the type of
componenttext: Well, regardless of who the lender is, as one looks at one's capital stack, you'd want to pay off the highest costs that you can. So I would say that given that, Scott said, this is market terms for this kind of paper, it's always going to be the type of paper that management wants to get rid of as soon as possible. So...

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the maturity at December of '17 is another consideration.
componenttext: And the maturity at December of '17 is another consideration.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just going back to the Vintage deal, can you just talk a little bit more about the time you think it's going to take to get from going into yield to the 30% NOI upside to get to mid-6% yield? And I forget if you said what the occupancy toda
componenttext: Okay. And then just going back to the Vintage deal, can you just talk a little bit more about the time you think it's going to take to get from going into yield to the 30% NOI upside to get to mid-6% yield? And I forget if you said what the occupancy today the portfolio is.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, the occupancy today is in the 84%, 85% range. It's a bit lower in Southern California than it is in Northern California. And it's going to take a couple of years. This is unlike a redevelopment opportunity. And we think given the locations and
componenttext: Yes, Nick, the occupancy today is in the 84%, 85% range. It's a bit lower in Southern California than it is in Northern California. And it's going to take a couple of years. This is unlike a redevelopment opportunity. And we think given the locations and the scale, the 6.5% to 7% stabilized yield is more than adequate return for this type of opportunity. And then longer term, we think this fits right into the profile of inflation plus outperformance. So this is not a future investment for us. This is continuing to build on a really important footprint in great markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's what's exciting about this acquisition is that we think while Vintage has been doing a good job, we think that the scale being -- that we already have in those markets and the operational efficiencies that being part of the Welltower umbrel
componenttext: I think that's what's exciting about this acquisition is that we think while Vintage has been doing a good job, we think that the scale being -- that we already have in those markets and the operational efficiencies that being part of the Welltower umbrella bring to any asset, our portfolio was the very reason why you see our performance leading the industry. It's not magic. It's hard work. And we believe we bring tremendous synergies with our other -- with the other pieces of our portfolio to the Vintage portfolio, and we think that will benefit our shareholders over time.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys had pretty solid same-store NOI growth in the operating portfolio again this quarter, ahead of some of your peers. So you kind of show some of the results there. I'm just wondering, on the expense side, was anything onetime? And the comp expense,
componenttext: You guys had pretty solid same-store NOI growth in the operating portfolio again this quarter, ahead of some of your peers. So you kind of show some of the results there. I'm just wondering, on the expense side, was anything onetime? And the comp expense, I think, was up 6%. And what should we assume sort of a good run rate over the next few quarters on expenses?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there's always unusual. It's one reason that we try not to focus too much on 90-day increments of time. Whether that's a plus or a minus with these many properties, there's always something unusual going on. But we don't really move those in
componenttext: Yes. I think there's always unusual. It's one reason that we try not to focus too much on 90-day increments of time. Whether that's a plus or a minus with these many properties, there's always something unusual going on. But we don't really move those in or out. The pool is the pool. If there are any adjustments that are particularly unusual, we tell you exactly what we did in the supplemental. So the numbers are always going to be a little bit more volatile and, say, triple-net lease. The compensation, for sure, is escalated this year, particularly in the U.K., in the U.S. We've talked about that at length. It's in our projections for the year. And those expectations are being met. I don't know if it's good or bad, but we actually predicted that costs would be up quite a bit with respect to labor. The fact is we're in core markets that are at the leading edge of the change in the minimum wage, like San Francisco and New York and Los Angeles. And the benefit is we have the pricing power to offset that, so we can't view these things in isolation. And our performance to date has shown that the revenue growth has been enough to offset the cost growth and still deliver really good performance.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think just look at the occupancy, the fact that our occupancy increased across the portfolio 100 basis points as we're pushing rate growth, that is not what you see across the industry. It is what we are able to do because of what we own, how our o
componenttext: Yes. I think just look at the occupancy, the fact that our occupancy increased across the portfolio 100 basis points as we're pushing rate growth, that is not what you see across the industry. It is what we are able to do because of what we own, how our operators manage and the benefits that the Welltower platform gives to the portfolio. That's why we get those results.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a fair point. And just more broadly, on the shop portfolio, you're now at, what, 37%, 38%. Can you maybe just give us some color on the opportunity set just going forward for similar types of large transactions that you just announced? And where do
componenttext: That's a fair point. And just more broadly, on the shop portfolio, you're now at, what, 37%, 38%. Can you maybe just give us some color on the opportunity set just going forward for similar types of large transactions that you just announced? And where do you want to see this segment of the business going in terms of business mix?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vik, there are many opportunities of this scale. Good or bad, most of what you'll see from Welltower in terms of investments in RIDEA portfolio will be select acquisitions that are in core markets and new development. And virtually every one of our 10 U.S
componenttext: Vik, there are many opportunities of this scale. Good or bad, most of what you'll see from Welltower in terms of investments in RIDEA portfolio will be select acquisitions that are in core markets and new development. And virtually every one of our 10 U.S. RIDEA partners is actively doing new development between 2 and 5 properties a year. Sometimes they do it alongside of us. Sometimes we have an option to buy it when it opens or when it stabilizes. So you're much more likely to see us do one at a time, 2 at a time acquisition and development to grow that portfolio going forward. But there are always a handful of portfolios that are interesting to us or that may be aggregated over time, but there's nothing else out there like this Vintage portfolio in terms of its scale in core markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last one, thanks for the triple-net coverage math. Those are really useful. I'm just wondering how -- what are operators seeing today when they look at -- when they look to and turn to the yields or they look at their own coverages, wh
componenttext: Okay. And then just last one, thanks for the triple-net coverage math. Those are really useful. I'm just wondering how -- what are operators seeing today when they look at -- when they look to and turn to the yields or they look at their own coverages, which, for some cases, maybe 1.1 or below 1.1 on an EBITDAR basis. What are they saying about the level of coverage doing new deals? Are you seeing some operators say, hey, we need to rethink about restructuring the deal?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so, Vikram. When I started doing this 14 years ago, the typical coverage for seniors housing was in the 1.25 or higher range. And to us, that was a structure that made sense for the landlord and the tenant. And as the businesses become more compet
componenttext: I think so, Vikram. When I started doing this 14 years ago, the typical coverage for seniors housing was in the 1.25 or higher range. And to us, that was a structure that made sense for the landlord and the tenant. And as the businesses become more competitive, the coverage ratios have declined and declined. And 1.1 today is sort of the market. And for years, operators are willing to enter into leases of those coverages. Frankly, we were not doing many, if any, acquisitions at those coverages. We have been saying for years now that to us, the distinction of risk in focusing on triple-net versus RIDEA was really not the way we think about risk, and we would always prefer to own a Class A asset in a Class A market and deal with the quarter-to-quarter variation in results. And that's exactly why you're seeing us concentrate our investments where you have. For the past 6 years, we've done very few triple-net investments. When we do, it tends to be a new development where there's an opportunity and enough profit in the development for there to be strong payment coverage or a turnaround opportunity, which is -- we don't like the thought of doing big acquisitions at near 1.0 coverage. It looks great on the press release because you've got great structural protection or so-called structural protection, but we've seen already that those don't always work out as planned. And if a deal doesn't work for both parties, it eventually doesn't work for either party. And I think you've seen that. And to us, the market coverage ratios today are not appropriate and there's not enough of a balance between risk and reward from the tenants.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vik, you see oftentimes the operators getting frustrated when most of the profitability is going into the rent. And we find that it's much more constructive to have the RIDEA structure where you're both incentivized to drive NOI, you share in the CapEx an
componenttext: Vik, you see oftentimes the operators getting frustrated when most of the profitability is going into the rent. And we find that it's much more constructive to have the RIDEA structure where you're both incentivized to drive NOI, you share in the CapEx and you want to drive the performance as opposed to trying to find some means of scratching out profitability when it's right around 1:1.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, that's a great point. And I think the other thing, Vik, is just understand that we have built an infrastructure here over the last 5 years that really allows us to maximize the performance along with the operator of the RIDEA asset. So I think th
componenttext: Yes. No, that's a great point. And I think the other thing, Vik, is just understand that we have built an infrastructure here over the last 5 years that really allows us to maximize the performance along with the operator of the RIDEA asset. So I think that's a key point that you have to consider. It really is going forward, there will be a rare occasion that we will -- you will see us acquire seniors housing assets in the triple-net lease structure. You might expect to see some of the triple-net lease assets we own move to our RIDEA structure if that's a possibility in the future. I think -- we think it's better for us. We think it's better for the operator. We think it's better for our shareholders.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tayo Okusanya from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tayo Okusanya from Jefferies.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on Juan's question about some of the changes to the covenants and if HCN actually received anything in consideration for that.
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on Juan's question about some of the changes to the covenants and if HCN actually received anything in consideration for that.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tayo, it's Scott speaking. There are a long list of projects that we're working on with Genesis. Some of them disclosed, some haven't. And it's fair to say that the term loans and what's the covenant relief were part of a much broader discussion. So we're
componenttext: Tayo, it's Scott speaking. There are a long list of projects that we're working on with Genesis. Some of them disclosed, some haven't. And it's fair to say that the term loans and what's the covenant relief were part of a much broader discussion. So we're not prepared to talk about the specific pluses and minuses. I would just ask that you have patience, give us time, we're clearly focused on the situation, and there's a much bigger picture that we're focused on than covenant relief and a term loan.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then did you do anything similar to what Sabra did in regards to changing the lease maturities as well to kind of help Genesis have a more staggered maturity schedule?
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then did you do anything similar to what Sabra did in regards to changing the lease maturities as well to kind of help Genesis have a more staggered maturity schedule?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't speak for the details of what Genesis and Sabra agreed to. I can tell you that all 180, plus or minus, of our properties are in one master lease that matures in 2032. So the new maturity date is not something we're worried about.
componenttext: Well, I can't speak for the details of what Genesis and Sabra agreed to. I can tell you that all 180, plus or minus, of our properties are in one master lease that matures in 2032. So the new maturity date is not something we're worried about.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Helpful. And then last one for me. I know you guys have always kind of been in and out of life sciences for a while. We've kind of thought Ventas -- this is -- the Wexford transaction. I guess I was a little bit surprised to see them do it and proba
componenttext: Okay. Helpful. And then last one for me. I know you guys have always kind of been in and out of life sciences for a while. We've kind of thought Ventas -- this is -- the Wexford transaction. I guess I was a little bit surprised to see them do it and probably not you guys just given your [indiscernible] experience with life sciences, and you've always kind of expressed an interest in it. But had expressed frustration, you could have grown it in the past. So just some thoughts around that transaction. Did you look at it? And why didn't you do it if you did look at it?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll only invest in real estate that's in core markets. That's part of our strategy. And I don't think you've heard us say that we want to invest in life science-related buildings. We told you when we did the deal with Four City in Cambridge, that
componenttext: Well, we'll only invest in real estate that's in core markets. That's part of our strategy. And I don't think you've heard us say that we want to invest in life science-related buildings. We told you when we did the deal with Four City in Cambridge, that was an opportunistic investment and it was an opportunistic sale. I don't think you've heard us say that we had any interest in getting into the life sciences real estate business.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: All right. And then what kind of a break assumptions are we making there?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the percentage of stabilized versus unstabilized, I probably think about it a little bit differently. There are properties that we think have the opportunity to grow centers pretty materially. And almost across the board, we feel like the
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the percentage of stabilized versus unstabilized, I probably think about it a little bit differently. There are properties that we think have the opportunity to grow centers pretty materially. And almost across the board, we feel like there are opportunities to change the service mix, the service level and change the value proposition pretty dramatically for the residents. So that's in addition to the occupancy off sites. It's really on the rate and service level that we see the portfolio changing the most over the years, but that will take some time. And it is a drag in the early years because you've got to put the new service platform in place before you can charge for it, right? People need to see it before they will pay for it, and it takes time to turn over the population. So this is a long-term investment for us. The 5% cap rate is what we prefer. It was accretive day 1, but the fact is where cost of capital is today, it probably is accretive at 5%. But this is very much a long-term play for us.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You said differently the way I think about it, Chad. Scott Estes. You really do have the opportunity for 4 to 5 years for mid- to high single-digit NOI growth the year after you spent the additional balance.
componenttext: You said differently the way I think about it, Chad. Scott Estes. You really do have the opportunity for 4 to 5 years for mid- to high single-digit NOI growth the year after you spent the additional balance.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: All right. And then just one more. So Scott, you made a comment that increasing private pay and reducing exposure was a priority, I think, a quarter or 2 ago. You guys may have made a comment that SNF actually looked like the best value at the time to you. Can you reconcile where we are today?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't recall anybody saying that SNFs were an area that we wanted to invest in. We've said that we are comfortable managing our SNF portfolio that's operated by Genesis. But I don't think you've heard us say...
componenttext: I don't recall anybody saying that SNFs were an area that we wanted to invest in. We've said that we are comfortable managing our SNF portfolio that's operated by Genesis. But I don't think you've heard us say...

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] just general, I think environment on the [indiscernible].
componenttext: [indiscernible] just general, I think environment on the [indiscernible].

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just say, Chad, that the skilled nursing environment is still one that is attracting investment dollars. It's just as we think about the direction of our company, it's probably -- that's not in Welltower's portfolio. So the fact is the population
componenttext: I would just say, Chad, that the skilled nursing environment is still one that is attracting investment dollars. It's just as we think about the direction of our company, it's probably -- that's not in Welltower's portfolio. So the fact is the population that uses those properties is going to double in size over 20 years and the supply of properties is declining. So when you think about the longer term rather than the next 3 quarters or 3 months, I think the supply/demand dynamics are still quite favorable for that business despite the headwinds that exist. And then a yield in a world with yields that are pushing 0% in most developed economies, you can still buy skilled nursing in the high single digits unlevered and get attractive financing, and it generates an awfully attractive return on equity immediately. And the payment coverage is -- unlike seniors housing where they're awfully low with 1.3x coverage, it's a pretty stable yield, particularly if you own good real estate with the good operators. So look, it actually still is a good investment. It's just not for us.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would even remind everybody, I think it's important to everyone. So focus on Genesis that we actually are, and even today, just announcing incremental progress on disposing of skilled nursing assets. So within our $1.3 billion of projected the disp
componenttext: Yes. I would even remind everybody, I think it's important to everyone. So focus on Genesis that we actually are, and even today, just announcing incremental progress on disposing of skilled nursing assets. So within our $1.3 billion of projected the disposition proceeds, about 60% of it or so of that is skilled nursing, and pro forma for what we've announced through today were already at 90% private pay. So Genesis is just a little bit a part of those numbers currently, but we're actually seeing those reasonable prices. We have $760-some million of potential proceeds from assets held for sale, and that low 9% is kind of cap rate. And that's kind of, I think, a good example of how we're continuing to improve the quality of the portfolio.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citi.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask you about how you're thinking if any changes by your investment in the U.K. if you want to maybe bring that down given their pending exit from the EU? Or does it change the way you think about investing there going forward? Or is it t
componenttext: I just wanted to ask you about how you're thinking if any changes by your investment in the U.K. if you want to maybe bring that down given their pending exit from the EU? Or does it change the way you think about investing there going forward? Or is it too soon to tell?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Smedes, yes, I think that you just answered part of the question. Yes, I think it is too soon to tell. I think we've seen a very different view of the impact of Brexit over the last couple of weeks. The thing you have to understand is 99% of the populatio
componenttext: Smedes, yes, I think that you just answered part of the question. Yes, I think it is too soon to tell. I think we've seen a very different view of the impact of Brexit over the last couple of weeks. The thing you have to understand is 99% of the population in our buildings are U.K. residents. So they are not leaving the U.K. because of Brexit. The U.K. is not going to be building new assisted living assets for its population. More and more, the U.K. residents will have to turn to a private pay alternative to local authority-funded eldercare. And the bulk of our assets are in the one in metropolitan area, which -- I don't think you bet against London long term. I think London has had a 30-year head start on building an irreplaceable infrastructure and economic machine that will prevail regardless of what happens here. So I don't think we're losing sleep over it. I think there are some challenges. You've heard us talk about on the wage side in the U.K., but we continue to manage through that again for the same reasons why we're managing through that in the U.S. I said we have the best located real estate with the best operators, and people want to live in this portfolio. So at the same time, we are watching what's happening in the U.K. and Europe very closely. And -- but at the end, I would tell you that we have a great -- we've assembled a really great portfolio of assets there.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Morgan from Canaccord.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple of quick things. So on your -- you mentioned that you're trending towards the high end of your full year same-store NOI guidance. And I think that implies maybe around 50 basis points of deceleration, if I have that right. Would you say that's accurate? And if so, were there any sectors or markets that might be driving that in your outlook?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. First quarter, I think it was 3.8% blended, so 3.3% averages, so that 3.5%. And I think, in short, we like to keep a little bit of conservatism in there and are tracking towards the higher end of the range. Really, the only variable is, again, around
componenttext: Yes. First quarter, I think it was 3.8% blended, so 3.3% averages, so that 3.5%. And I think, in short, we like to keep a little bit of conservatism in there and are tracking towards the higher end of the range. Really, the only variable is, again, around the operating portfolio, but we feel like it's doing pretty well. So we're hopeful we would again be able to come in toward the high end of that range at this point or maybe a little better.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on Genesis, I think you mentioned that one of the reasons for the coverage decline was based on held for sale assets. And so I might have thought that the sale assets would have lower coverage. Is that just specific to the deals? Or
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on Genesis, I think you mentioned that one of the reasons for the coverage decline was based on held for sale assets. And so I might have thought that the sale assets would have lower coverage. Is that just specific to the deals? Or is there anything kind of -- is there any color that you could offer?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's more because among the assets that are being sold are in some inpatient rehab hospitals that have particularly high values and extremely high payment coverage. And so that's what's driving it. And it's not a huge portfolio at the end of the day.
componenttext: Yes, it's more because among the assets that are being sold are in some inpatient rehab hospitals that have particularly high values and extremely high payment coverage. And so that's what's driving it. And it's not a huge portfolio at the end of the day. So if you sell a $60 million, $70 million property that has 3x payment coverage, it unfortunately impacts the portfolio by 2 or 3 basis points, and that's what happened.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, that's helpful. And then just lastly, going back to Vintage. Sorry if you mentioned this and I missed it, but is there anything in terms of a contribution to the kind of ramp in yields to the stabilized level that's coming from the cost side as
componenttext: Okay. Yes, that's helpful. And then just lastly, going back to Vintage. Sorry if you mentioned this and I missed it, but is there anything in terms of a contribution to the kind of ramp in yields to the stabilized level that's coming from the cost side as you roll those assets into your platform in those markets? Or is that all really occupancy and rate?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's more driven by revenue in this case. I mean, 1 property, 13 taxes have an impact immediately. The minimum wage is an issue in a lot of these markets, so we've budgeted for that. And our operating partners expect to increase the service level, no
componenttext: Yes, it's more driven by revenue in this case. I mean, 1 property, 13 taxes have an impact immediately. The minimum wage is an issue in a lot of these markets, so we've budgeted for that. And our operating partners expect to increase the service level, not decrease it. So it's not like we're assuming big expense cuts. It's really just the opposite here.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller from JPMorgan.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Spent a little bit of time, Tom, I think at the beginning of the call talking about performance in core markets and hearing that and talking about how after the Vintage, I think core markets are going to be 60% of the NOI for senior housing or for the ope
componenttext: Spent a little bit of time, Tom, I think at the beginning of the call talking about performance in core markets and hearing that and talking about how after the Vintage, I think core markets are going to be 60% of the NOI for senior housing or for the operating portfolio. And I guess just given the disconnect in terms of performance that you're seeing between the core markets, the 6 core markets and everything else, I mean, should we expect you to ramp up asset sales in those noncore markets over time?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Mike, we like what we own across the portfolio, but that's what is changing. Where -- what today is a good market may not be a great market in the future. So expect that we are always looking for opportunities to recycle capital and constantly impro
componenttext: Well, Mike, we like what we own across the portfolio, but that's what is changing. Where -- what today is a good market may not be a great market in the future. So expect that we are always looking for opportunities to recycle capital and constantly improve the quality of the portfolio. I would say that we are laser-focused on building scale in the top markets in the country. Scott mentioned that the sixth of the sexy 6 is D.C., where we're #2. But expect that we are very focused on building scale in D.C. And a number of our operators have development properties being constructed in the Greater D.C. market. That's an important market for us. But you've heard us say this before, we are looking to go deep in the top core markets in the 3 countries in which we operate and get as close to the center of the core as possible, which is not typically where you found senior housing assets. So that speaks to what we're doing in New York City, which we talked about on our last call. And it speaks to some of the things we're doing in markets like Toronto, very much in the center of the urban market there. You will see assets we are -- either own today or developing in Los Angeles. So it's very much our strategy. Expect you're going to continue to see us to follow that strategy. And the other piece of this, which you'll be hearing more about in the future, is how we are connecting what we do to the major health systems in those core markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing I'd add, Mike, Scott Estes, I think it's important that because what Tom just said, we've always adhered to this investing methodology, and I think we see less variability between the portfolio. I think when we start talking about these 6 core m
componenttext: One thing I'd add, Mike, Scott Estes, I think it's important that because what Tom just said, we've always adhered to this investing methodology, and I think we see less variability between the portfolio. I think when we start talking about these 6 core markets, it's generally in the industry, but I remember when Scott Brinker add some color here, in the first quarter, I think our same-store RIDEA NOI growth is 5%, 5.5%. The best markets were 7%, 8%. The low were 2% or 3%, all positive. And around the 4% is core. We don't see why variability and no big negatives or anything. We don't get to like any market. I think it's important that we feel pretty good about most of the markets we're in.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we talk about our performance, we talk about the entire portfolio. We're not bifurcating our portfolio. We generally like the markets we're in. We're skewed to the core markets. It's not 100% of what we own, but we have edited the portfolio over
componenttext: Yes, when we talk about our performance, we talk about the entire portfolio. We're not bifurcating our portfolio. We generally like the markets we're in. We're skewed to the core markets. It's not 100% of what we own, but we have edited the portfolio over many years, and that's why our performance is better because we don't have a lot of weak links in our portfolio. That is one of the key differentiators of the Welltower business model. Again, it's not magic that our same-store numbers are what they are. It's because we have better assets and much fewer lower-quality assets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just one quick follow-up. On Vintage, the $1.5 billion investment, does that capture everything as you go through this start of the 5% going in yield, ramp up to 6.5%? Or is there an incremental spend above and beyond that to get there?
componenttext: Got it. And just one quick follow-up. On Vintage, the $1.5 billion investment, does that capture everything as you go through this start of the 5% going in yield, ramp up to 6.5%? Or is there an incremental spend above and beyond that to get there?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. It starts at $1.15 billion, and there is some capital that needs to be put into a couple of village in; particular. But that's accounted for when we talked about a stabilize yield in the 6.5% to 7% range.
componenttext: Yes, Mike. It starts at $1.15 billion, and there is some capital that needs to be put into a couple of village in; particular. But that's accounted for when we talked about a stabilize yield in the 6.5% to 7% range.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: That number is fully loaded. Okay.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Correct.
componenttext: Yes. Correct.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's late, so I'll talk really fast. On Genesis, I wanted to ask about the facility-level EBITDAR coverage because it's interesting if you look at 1.57, it's actually being constant for over a year. And does that imply that basically, the operator propert
componenttext: It's late, so I'll talk really fast. On Genesis, I wanted to ask about the facility-level EBITDAR coverage because it's interesting if you look at 1.57, it's actually being constant for over a year. And does that imply that basically, the operator property-level EBITDAR on a same-store basis has been flat over the last year, which would appear to be a lot better than the overall commentary for the skilled nursing industry and also Genesis' portfolio overall?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Andrew, this is Scott speaking. We've commented in the past, and we'll do it again here, that our properties have performed quite well over the past 4 years. There's a 3.5% lease escalator in our master lease. That's a high bar for Genesis to climb o
componenttext: Yes, Andrew, this is Scott speaking. We've commented in the past, and we'll do it again here, that our properties have performed quite well over the past 4 years. There's a 3.5% lease escalator in our master lease. That's a high bar for Genesis to climb over every year. Now next year, that goes to 3%. So a bit of relief from their standpoint. But our coverages, other than in 2011 when Medicare cut reimbursement very substantially, have been very consistent over the past 4 years. And we think that is...

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a follow-up is how are they able to do that? And one thing I thought about, is there a difference because you're not in the ex on assets, right, you're not in ex skilled assets? Is that kind of legacy Genesis doing better?
componenttext: I guess a follow-up is how are they able to do that? And one thing I thought about, is there a difference because you're not in the ex on assets, right, you're not in ex skilled assets? Is that kind of legacy Genesis doing better?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious, is there a reason why?
componenttext: Just curious, is there a reason why?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: They have huge geographic scale in these markets. So we're concentrated in New England and in Mid-Atlantic. They've been there for decades. They have the referral networks, the brand, the staffing, and it's good real estate. So I don't know as much about
componenttext: They have huge geographic scale in these markets. So we're concentrated in New England and in Mid-Atlantic. They've been there for decades. They have the referral networks, the brand, the staffing, and it's good real estate. So I don't know as much about the Sun portfolio or the Skilled Health portfolio. We don't own those assets. We do own their core legacy assets, and they held in quite well, which is why we keep saying we're confident that there will be interest through our real estate. And the issue was clearing up the corporate credit situation because they've done 3 or 4 big acquisitions in the past 3 years that on hindsight, maybe not all the assets were perfect, and they could use a lot of debt to finance them. So the corporate credit isn't as strong as it could be despite strong performance in our real estate.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Andrew, thanks for noticing.
componenttext: But Andrew, thanks for noticing.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of John Kim from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Welltower Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
