headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Juan. Thanks for the question. I do think we provided quite a good bit of detail in regards to sources and uses to provide the pretty good run rate. You can see the disposition proceeds of $3.274 billion and then the specific uses. That's really the
componenttext: Sure, Juan. Thanks for the question. I do think we provided quite a good bit of detail in regards to sources and uses to provide the pretty good run rate. You can see the disposition proceeds of $3.274 billion and then the specific uses. That's really the numbers, I think, everyone should use to start thinking about 2017. We will provide guidance in February once we get all the models and everything done at that point. The one thing that will benefit 2017 are a couple of things beyond what's just in this press release though. As a reminder, obviously, you should model same-store NOI growth. Were going to have some development conversions, and obviously, it doesn't include any acquisitions as well. So we give you our fourth quarter number effectively with our guidance this year and I think I would just model up the in-place NOI from the numbers we gave you in the release.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the SNF dispositions, is the cap rate you guys quote, the 9%, is that affected at all by any rate cuts that the buyers are perceived or is that the cap rate -- your lost NOI to Welltower? And if you give us a sense of the delta on the re
componenttext: Okay. And then on the SNF dispositions, is the cap rate you guys quote, the 9%, is that affected at all by any rate cuts that the buyers are perceived or is that the cap rate -- your lost NOI to Welltower? And if you give us a sense of the delta on the reset rents?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Juan. It's Scott Binker. Thanks for listening today. The cap rate that we quoted is based on the in-place rent that exist today under the term master lease divided by the purchase price from the third party, so pretty straightforward. And in terms o
componenttext: Sure, Juan. It's Scott Binker. Thanks for listening today. The cap rate that we quoted is based on the in-place rent that exist today under the term master lease divided by the purchase price from the third party, so pretty straightforward. And in terms of the rent adjustment that Genesis received, I mean, our goal all along here was to create a better relationship, stronger relationship between Welltower and Genesis, and to improve Genesis credit. So I think we were able to come up with a pretty creative way to accomplish that in that we agreed with Genesis and the third-party buyers to essentially reduce the rent going forward by about 5% on both portfolios, so that's about $8 million of Year 1 rent. And in exchange for that, Genesis gave us a note with a 4-year term that bears interest at a 10% rate, but a good part of that is payable in kind versus in cash so that they have a sizable cash flow benefit in Year 1 from this transaction, not to mention materially lower increasers going forward. So one of the challenges in the Genesis portfolio has been the 3.5% lease escalators for the last 5 years, which George and his team, frankly, have done an amazing job of keeping up with because our payment coverage have been basically flat for 5 years now after the big Medicare cut, but it's tough. I mean, Medicare and Medicaid rates are growing 1-ish percent per year at best, plus the occupancy challenges in the business. It's just -- it's tough to keep up with that kind of an escalator. So in the new leases with the new buyers, they've agreed to 2% or below escalators for the next 15 years so that, over time, there's a meaningful benefit to Genesis.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to wrap that up, did you guys -- there is no reset the your remaining rents or changes for the escalators, correct? And if you wouldn't mind giving us any price per bed that was implied by the transactions.
componenttext: And just to wrap that up, did you guys -- there is no reset the your remaining rents or changes for the escalators, correct? And if you wouldn't mind giving us any price per bed that was implied by the transactions.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On your question, that's correct. The remaining Welltower master lease is unchanged. So no change in rent, no change in escalator, no change in the maturity date. And the price per bed, in the aggregate, it was probably 160-plus thousand per bed. Jua
componenttext: Yes. On your question, that's correct. The remaining Welltower master lease is unchanged. So no change in rent, no change in escalator, no change in the maturity date. And the price per bed, in the aggregate, it was probably 160-plus thousand per bed. Juan, I know it by portfolio but I don't have the aggregate number off the top of my head, but it's in that range. And these are high-quality properties. It generate a lot of cash, so the price per bed is quite high.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe just one last question, if you don't mind for Scott Estes. Obviously, a much lower levered balance sheet and a position to grow. How should we think about kind of the target range of where you could re-lever to and where you feel comforta
componenttext: Great. And maybe just one last question, if you don't mind for Scott Estes. Obviously, a much lower levered balance sheet and a position to grow. How should we think about kind of the target range of where you could re-lever to and where you feel comfortable to? And maybe just where you think acquisition cap rates will be to think about using that firepower?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The reality is, I think, we've reset the balance sheet to some extent. I feel really good about those new leverage metrics, the 34% to 35% area is a great one for net debt to undepreciated book and they like the lower 5s on net debt to EBITDA. So ob
componenttext: Sure. The reality is, I think, we've reset the balance sheet to some extent. I feel really good about those new leverage metrics, the 34% to 35% area is a great one for net debt to undepreciated book and they like the lower 5s on net debt to EBITDA. So obviously, resulting fixed charge and interest coverages are good. And at the end of the day, we will capitalize on acquisition opportunities, first and foremost, with our existing partners, but don't have to. And the key word here is really optionality in my opinion. I think we have great optionality where the balance sheet is. And maybe, Scott, I don't see -- if you want to comment on just cap rates and what you're maybe seeing in the current market in terms of pricing.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Juan, I would just say at the beginning of the year, we told people that this was a year to be extremely disciplined, just given where the market is from an operating environment and where we believe our cost of capital is relative to our NAV. So we'
componenttext: Yes. Juan, I would just say at the beginning of the year, we told people that this was a year to be extremely disciplined, just given where the market is from an operating environment and where we believe our cost of capital is relative to our NAV. So we've been pretty selective about what we bought. Our acquisition volumes are lower this year than they have been in as long as I can remember. But that's not because of lack of opportunity, that's because of conscious decisions we've made. And even though we now have a substantial free cash flow in our balance sheet, I don't think our mindset is going to change. There are deals that make a lot of sense with existing partners in our core markets, some of that is in the fourth quarter acquisition guidance that we gave this morning. But outside of that, I don't think you should expect us to change our approach that we show in the last 3 quarters, which is to be really, really disciplined in this environment.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Paul Morgan with Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Paul Morgan with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe you could give a little bit of an update on what you're seeing in terms of your external growth. Your acquisition pipeline looking forward, obviously, has been a very busy quarter 2 in terms of obstruction in these asset sales. But look, kind of now
componenttext: Maybe you could give a little bit of an update on what you're seeing in terms of your external growth. Your acquisition pipeline looking forward, obviously, has been a very busy quarter 2 in terms of obstruction in these asset sales. But look, kind of now that you've closed Vintage and as you look into '17, what's the opportunities look like? And I think, based on your comments, we should kind of think about post-close kind of the 2017 external growth being on a leverage neutral basis.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The outlook is favorable and that we have 20-plus operating partners in seniors housing alone that are regularly coming to us with opportunities. Now right now a lot of that is actually new development where we may provide a portion of the capital to
componenttext: Yes. The outlook is favorable and that we have 20-plus operating partners in seniors housing alone that are regularly coming to us with opportunities. Now right now a lot of that is actually new development where we may provide a portion of the capital to help them get the project up and running and then we have a purchase option when the project stabilizes. That is a run rate volume of 500-plus million of modern purpose-built properties that we get the first right on. And then, occasionally, we have an opportunity like Vintage that we work in tandem with one or more operating partners to fill out their existing core footprint. And you should expect us to look to do more of those types of investments. There are a few handful of operators in our core countries of U.S., Canada and the U.K. that we're still looking to establish as new partners and bring into the portfolio, so we have our targets and we're building those relationships.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just picking up on Scott's point, Paul. One thing we consistently remind people of is that this large portfolio of operators that our part of the Welltower family still own real estate that we don't own, and that provides us somewhat of an annuity st
componenttext: Yes. Just picking up on Scott's point, Paul. One thing we consistently remind people of is that this large portfolio of operators that our part of the Welltower family still own real estate that we don't own, and that provides us somewhat of an annuity stream of new -- of high-quality investment opportunities. And again, our operators are typically the dominant regional players in the best markets in the country, and those markets behave differently than a lot of the secondary markets where a lot of the new supply is coming into. So they still see good growth opportunities. Our strategy, we talked about on the last call, is to continue to go deep in the top markets in the U.S. And so we still see very good opportunities in the senior care business. Scott talked about some development opportunities because their markets, like Manhattan, where the product does not exist for us to acquire, so we're developing it. And I think we will see some interesting opportunities that will come from other sectors of health care delivery where we like the medical office business and we will continue to look for opportunities to grow that business because not only are we a good acquirer, we also have an excellent management company based down in Jupiter, Florida.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just my other question. You've obviously spoken to a lot of kind of new institutional capital investors and looking at health care real estate over the past few quarters as well is your kind of your ongoing relationships. But I mean, do you have
componenttext: And then just my other question. You've obviously spoken to a lot of kind of new institutional capital investors and looking at health care real estate over the past few quarters as well is your kind of your ongoing relationships. But I mean, do you have any kind of takeaways from the disposition process with respect the Genesis and kind of the conversations you had on how deep and kind of how broad are the pockets that are increasingly looking at health care real estate right now?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see lots of interest. As I mentioned in my remarks, we received significant inbound interest by private investors in owning post-acute long-term care assets as well as senior housing assets. So we're seeing continued interest from private capital sourc
componenttext: We see lots of interest. As I mentioned in my remarks, we received significant inbound interest by private investors in owning post-acute long-term care assets as well as senior housing assets. So we're seeing continued interest from private capital sources to build positions in health care real estate.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Maybe the one addition would be is the foreign institutional capital comes in to U.S. health care real estate for the first time. Almost across the board their first question is, do you have a portfolio or an opportunity on the East or West Coast? Li
componenttext: Yes. Maybe the one addition would be is the foreign institutional capital comes in to U.S. health care real estate for the first time. Almost across the board their first question is, do you have a portfolio or an opportunity on the East or West Coast? Like they always ask that question. You never hear that question from U.S. buyers, especially in seniors housing, medical office, nobody cares, right? And that's why we've said it for years, there's no -- very little differential in cap rate when you look at differences in asset class, building quality and particularly location. Everything is sort of the same. And our view is that, that's going to change pretty dramatically. You've seen that in other real estate sectors where there's a huge difference in cap rate, among building in New York, New Jersey, in California or secondary location in middle America. There's no question that health care real estate is going to move in that direction in our portfolio, and operating partners are going to benefit from that because the foreign capital is coming in a major way, and that's the thing they care about. You see the -- again, huge pricing differential in other real estate classes, you don't yet see that in our sector but it's coming.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other point on foreign capital coming in which I'll make with respect to Cindat, China has the same aging demographic issues that we have in the United States except it's amplified here because of the size of the population. We believe one of the reas
componenttext: The other point on foreign capital coming in which I'll make with respect to Cindat, China has the same aging demographic issues that we have in the United States except it's amplified here because of the size of the population. We believe one of the reasons that Cindat was attracted to forming this joint venture with us is that they want to learn how to invest in this asset class because it has relevance to what will happen back in their home country. And the other piece of this is that Genesis has a business in China, and so that's also important here. So there's lots of synergies at play here for Cindat forming the joint venture with Welltower and acquiring an interest in Genesis assets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to stick with the Genesis asset sale. I guess, can you just talk about a little bit about how the decision to include certain assets was in the disposition pull versus the key pull. And what did the profile look like for the stuff that will re
componenttext: I just want to stick with the Genesis asset sale. I guess, can you just talk about a little bit about how the decision to include certain assets was in the disposition pull versus the key pull. And what did the profile look like for the stuff that will remain going forward?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Vin, it's Scott. That's a great question. I think we spent more time on that particular topic than we did in taking the buyers that we chose to go forward with. So the concept with all the buyers that we talk to is that the properties that they bough
componenttext: Yes. Vin, it's Scott. That's a great question. I think we spent more time on that particular topic than we did in taking the buyers that we chose to go forward with. So the concept with all the buyers that we talk to is that the properties that they bought would be a representative pool of assets. So we've decided to keep all 9 PowerBacks in the Welltower master lease, so those are not included. But the traditional Genesis long-term care properties have been allocated among the Cindat joint venture, the Lindsay Goldberg purchase, the Genesis buyback portfolio and the remaining Welltower master lease in a way that everybody gets a broad cross-section of assets. So nobody cherry picked for the positive and nobody got cherry picked to the negative. And we all looked at a very comprehensive asset quality scoring metric that included things like building age, operating margin, occupancy, quality mix, star ratings and clinical outcomes so that everybody felt like they got a representative sample of assets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just talk about the 7% that remains. How much is that -- kind of the breakdown between PowerBack and traditional?
componenttext: Okay. And then just talk about the 7% that remains. How much is that -- kind of the breakdown between PowerBack and traditional?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the percentage would be -- I'd have to get back to you with the exact number, Vin, but the percentage is probably roughly 20% PowerBack, 80% long-term care if we're able to execute on the $600-plus million of additional 2017 dispositions that we tal
componenttext: Well, the percentage would be -- I'd have to get back to you with the exact number, Vin, but the percentage is probably roughly 20% PowerBack, 80% long-term care if we're able to execute on the $600-plus million of additional 2017 dispositions that we talk about in the press release. But I'll get back to you with the specific percentage.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then maybe another question just on the sources and uses, that was very helpful in terms of outlining exactly how that breaks down. I was just curious just on the debt repayments and some of the preferred stuff. How should we think
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then maybe another question just on the sources and uses, that was very helpful in terms of outlining exactly how that breaks down. I was just curious just on the debt repayments and some of the preferred stuff. How should we think about timing of that? Are you going to be able to do that all sort of at the end of the year? And I guess should we expect some hefty prepayment penalties?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are going to do it as quickly as possible. As the proceeds come in, we'll keep you updated. I think probably just modeling-wise, most of it you could generally assume at the end of the year in terms of the run rate. The one piece for sure, the preferre
componenttext: We are going to do it as quickly as possible. As the proceeds come in, we'll keep you updated. I think probably just modeling-wise, most of it you could generally assume at the end of the year in terms of the run rate. The one piece for sure, the preferred stock redemption is in March of '17, and the reason we put the $48 million of aggregate debt extinguishments and other costs in there, that's the number you asked about. So -- besides, that's the same uses as proceeds.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Michael Carroll with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Michael Carroll with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, was there a difference in the cap rate among the 3 Genesis portfolio sales? I believe it was announced that the Lindsay Goldberg purchase has an initial cap rate of about 9.4%. I mean is that -- how does that relate to the 9% that you guys quoted?
componenttext: Scott, was there a difference in the cap rate among the 3 Genesis portfolio sales? I believe it was announced that the Lindsay Goldberg purchase has an initial cap rate of about 9.4%. I mean is that -- how does that relate to the 9% that you guys quoted?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there was some differential. I can't comment specifically on what Omega reported. I'll leave that to them. But in terms of the cap rate, as we view it, there was a differential and a couple of things drove that. One, the asset quality was the same so
componenttext: Yes, there was some differential. I can't comment specifically on what Omega reported. I'll leave that to them. But in terms of the cap rate, as we view it, there was a differential and a couple of things drove that. One, the asset quality was the same so that was not the issue. But there was a timing issue and Lindsay Goldberg was the first to step up. That's why they're the first one to close. They bought a bigger portfolio, which was relevant. It wasn't easy to finance. That's a lot of money to raise in today's environment, so that was meaningful to us. And the last thing I would point out is that they bought 100% interest. So it was a free and clear purchase versus a retained interest. But frankly, we're pretty happy about the joint venture with Cindat because it gives us a lot of optionality. After 5 years, either party is able to create a liquidity event that we could either take more or exit the portfolio. And we're going in with the expectation that we're going to grow the partnership with Cindat and Union Life, but it's nice to have that optionality. So I think that mix of structures is actually quite beneficial to our shareholders.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then what about the potential Genesis sales in 2017? Is there a type of an agreement you have with the tenant amount to be $120 million noncore sales in the cap rates that you give them for the rent credit? And is there a discussion on the cap rate
componenttext: Okay. Then what about the potential Genesis sales in 2017? Is there a type of an agreement you have with the tenant amount to be $120 million noncore sales in the cap rates that you give them for the rent credit? And is there a discussion on the cap rate for the $500 million potential buyback that the tenant has?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is. And it would be in line if not a bit below the 9% cap rate that we reported today on the dispositions.
componenttext: There is. And it would be in line if not a bit below the 9% cap rate that we reported today on the dispositions.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, can you talk a little bit about the remaining exposure you have to Genesis and the post-acute care facilities? Are you comfortable with your exposure now or would you like to reduce that further?
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, can you talk a little bit about the remaining exposure you have to Genesis and the post-acute care facilities? Are you comfortable with your exposure now or would you like to reduce that further?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have very publicly stated that it is our intention to grow our private pay mix. So you should expect to see us continue to grow that by acquisition and, in some cases, by disposition.
componenttext: We have very publicly stated that it is our intention to grow our private pay mix. So you should expect to see us continue to grow that by acquisition and, in some cases, by disposition.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sure you guys did a lot over the last quarter to get this done, a lot of moving parts. Just first question, just picking off over the last comment about growing private pay. Can you maybe just update us? I think the portfolio is out there for the -- t
componenttext: I'm sure you guys did a lot over the last quarter to get this done, a lot of moving parts. Just first question, just picking off over the last comment about growing private pay. Can you maybe just update us? I think the portfolio is out there for the -- the large caps are probably more different today than they've been in recent past. And I'm just trying to understand having post-acute in your portfolio, how do you view that, whether it's even smaller for you or not? But just your view on is it important to be part of a diversified portfolio like you guys have?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We believe that it is still important to have some investment in the post-acute care space. If you talk to the leading hospital systems in this country, they will tell you that they are very interested in having a viable post-acute care option to work wit
componenttext: We believe that it is still important to have some investment in the post-acute care space. If you talk to the leading hospital systems in this country, they will tell you that they are very interested in having a viable post-acute care option to work with as they look to their futures because post-acute care is a much lower cost setting than the inpatient hospital setting. So we believe this is not going away, and we also believe that post-acute care in the future may look different than the historic skilled nursing model that you're familiar with. So Scott used a word that we often use around here called optionality. We are a long-term investor in health care real estate, and we want to maintain optionality to be opportunistic and deploy capital across the spectrum if we believe it's in the best interest of our shareholders.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just on the senior housing triple net sales, the 6.3% cap was pretty impressive. I'm just wondering, can you give us some flavor of type of assets, what percent were may be below 1 covered? And sort of what prompted the sale overall?
componenttext: Okay, great. And just on the senior housing triple net sales, the 6.3% cap was pretty impressive. I'm just wondering, can you give us some flavor of type of assets, what percent were may be below 1 covered? And sort of what prompted the sale overall?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vik. It's a combination of a couple of things. One is that we think this is an opportunistic time to be a seller in the seniors housing market; and secondarily, these are portfolios that aren't a perfect fit for our strategy at this point. They're o
componenttext: Sure, Vik. It's a combination of a couple of things. One is that we think this is an opportunistic time to be a seller in the seniors housing market; and secondarily, these are portfolios that aren't a perfect fit for our strategy at this point. They're operators that, generally speaking, we're not growing with. And therefore, we're probably better off freeing them up to grow their business with a different capital partner. And helps to have existing portfolio to bring to the table for that. And for the most part, these have quite low payment coverage. So we're optimistic that the triple net senior housing portfolio that we have left will have improved credit metrics and payment coverage than what we had before.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have a pro forma coverage post this?
componenttext: Do you have a pro forma coverage post this?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vik, it's not going to move materially in any event when you think about just the size of that denominator. But our hope would be that it's moving up 1, 2, 3 basis points, which it has been the past couple of quarters after a number of years of steady dec
componenttext: Vik, it's not going to move materially in any event when you think about just the size of that denominator. But our hope would be that it's moving up 1, 2, 3 basis points, which it has been the past couple of quarters after a number of years of steady decline driven by one operator in particular. We're now finally trending up because we have some development projects stabilizing, and we've been able to remove some of these lower covering master leases.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last quick one on the shop portfolio. Within expenses, there's and all other bucket that increased, I think, 8%. Can you give us some sense of what's in there and what led to that increase?
componenttext: Okay. And just last quick one on the shop portfolio. Within expenses, there's and all other bucket that increased, I think, 8%. Can you give us some sense of what's in there and what led to that increase?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can. One, it's management fees. So we generally pay a base 5% management fee to our operating partners, and there are always incentives up and down based on their performance. It's also things like insurance, professional fees, worker's compensatio
componenttext: Yes, I can. One, it's management fees. So we generally pay a base 5% management fee to our operating partners, and there are always incentives up and down based on their performance. It's also things like insurance, professional fees, worker's compensation. So I wouldn't -- we've said this before, including the first quarter when we reported 5.5% NOI growth, and I'll say it again. This quarter, when we generated 2.2% NOI growth. It's just that 90 days is just too short a period of time to make conclusions about performance of the portfolio or the trend or trajectory. It just -- $1 million is not much money in the scheme of things and yet, it moves the same-store growth rate by 50 basis points. So small accruals, adjustments that simply happen. And they're unpredictable. Moved that number a lot. So by the same argument, I wouldn't read too much into that other line item this quarter. The fact is operating expenses are driven by labor at 60% or so of the total operating costs, and we've been saying for over a year now that labor costs are the headwind. That's the biggest challenge that our portfolio is facing. And to date, our operators, our properties have done a remarkable job offsetting that cost pressure.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then this is for Scott Estes but also the whole team. I think it's a -- just a comment from my side. It's pretty impressive given all the portfolio activity you've had to take the dividend up 1.5% for next year. So congrats, guys.
componenttext: Okay, great. And then this is for Scott Estes but also the whole team. I think it's a -- just a comment from my side. It's pretty impressive given all the portfolio activity you've had to take the dividend up 1.5% for next year. So congrats, guys.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks.
componenttext: All right. Thanks.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another very busy quarter for you guys. So to anyone in the room, if you had done this Genesis sale 2, 2.5 years ago, you probably would have gotten 8% cap on it, and I don't know if that's a precise number. But clearly, things have gotten -- the question
componenttext: Another very busy quarter for you guys. So to anyone in the room, if you had done this Genesis sale 2, 2.5 years ago, you probably would have gotten 8% cap on it, and I don't know if that's a precise number. But clearly, things have gotten -- the question marks have come to the table and has resulted maybe in a little tougher sale there. And I'm wondering if anything about this is a teaching moment, and if you kind of should be thinking a few more steps forward on a go-forward basis. For example, it seems -- you mentioned the escalators coming down on the sold Genesis portfolio but yours are staying at 3. I mean is there any reason to think about that more proactively and saying, maybe we should be reassessing our escalator for the next 16 years with Genesis? Or anything like that, that you think is more on the forward-thinking docket for you now having had this experience with the Genesis situation?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll just start off by saying that I think we are a very forward-thinking organization and we take a long-term view of our investments and we own and manage diversified portfolio of health care investments. So that will not change. We don't have cry
componenttext: Well, I'll just start off by saying that I think we are a very forward-thinking organization and we take a long-term view of our investments and we own and manage diversified portfolio of health care investments. So that will not change. We don't have crystal balls. We try and make sound investment decisions as we can, and I think we have a pretty good track record of that.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so -- no argument on your process. I'm speaking just specifically on the Genesis sale and if again your -- how does Genesis produce a situation where they'll do better than 3% growth over the next 16 years versus your escalator? I'm just curious
componenttext: Okay. And so -- no argument on your process. I'm speaking just specifically on the Genesis sale and if again your -- how does Genesis produce a situation where they'll do better than 3% growth over the next 16 years versus your escalator? I'm just curious if you're giving that any thought at all.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of our goals in selling assets out of the portfolio, Rich, was to have a remaining Genesis portfolio that had better coverage so that there was a broader cushion. And to the point earlier, they've actually kept up with the escalator to date so t
componenttext: Well, one of our goals in selling assets out of the portfolio, Rich, was to have a remaining Genesis portfolio that had better coverage so that there was a broader cushion. And to the point earlier, they've actually kept up with the escalator to date so the rent payment to HCN is going to be more than cut in half as a product to these transactions. So we're confident that they'll continue to pay us the 3% escalator.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. To ask Scott Estes, you kind of gave some guidelines about timing of use of proceeds, the preferred redemption maybe in the first quarter but everything else kind of backend with the exception of the acquisitions and dispositions this quarter.
componenttext: All right. To ask Scott Estes, you kind of gave some guidelines about timing of use of proceeds, the preferred redemption maybe in the first quarter but everything else kind of backend with the exception of the acquisitions and dispositions this quarter. You kind of do that math and you get to some meaningful dilution, at least in the short term, and you're raising the dividend. I'm not going to ask you to put a number on that dilution, but your -- I'm just curious, are you looking at payout ratio being temporarily at the very high end of a comfort level next year and expecting a return to more normalized level in '18 and beyond? Is that the way you're thinking about the dividend?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's fair, Rich. Like again, I would go back to the answer of we threw a lot of numbers that you hear that does get you to the run rate net sources and uses. My point would be that as you start to think about '17, we'll have normal same-store NOI
componenttext: I think it's fair, Rich. Like again, I would go back to the answer of we threw a lot of numbers that you hear that does get you to the run rate net sources and uses. My point would be that as you start to think about '17, we'll have normal same-store NOI growth acquisitions, development, conversions, et cetera that will offset some of that potential dilution. But you're absolutely right, we don't want to do a knee-jerk dividend policy reaction what's based on an awesome long-term growth potential for the company. The balance sheet just made a humongous leap forward. Full line of credit available. You can think about all the optionality again that we've been talking about when we talked to the board and say, hey, over the next 3 years, let's look at what the earnings power of the company is. And we think it's very significant. So we concluded that a slight increase was right for next year, and I think it's more important to think about that context and the bigger picture.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then another maybe one for Mr. DeRosa. The increased exposure now, almost entirely private pay. You and others are all kind of jumping on this private pay bandwagon. I'm just curious, what are the risks in going so far field in that direction wh
componenttext: Okay. And then another maybe one for Mr. DeRosa. The increased exposure now, almost entirely private pay. You and others are all kind of jumping on this private pay bandwagon. I'm just curious, what are the risks in going so far field in that direction when you think about a very uncertain economy? You become much more kind of tethered to, worst case, some type of recession or something like that. What are you doing to manage that issue given going so far deeply into the private pay world?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you have to look at the markets where we concentrate capital in. And I think that that's the markets where population is moving, where there's job growth. We see that strategy as -- in terms of concentrating our assets in centers of wealth as a mi
componenttext: I think you have to look at the markets where we concentrate capital in. And I think that that's the markets where population is moving, where there's job growth. We see that strategy as -- in terms of concentrating our assets in centers of wealth as a mitigant. But we're also of the opinion that health care will be moving much more in a private pay direction, that in the future, those who can pay for their health care will be shouldering a bigger percentage of their health care costs. We know that Medicare is quite challenged and not prepared for the aging demographic that we're going to see over the next -- over the coming decades. So we believe that the markets that we're focused in delivering a product that is a premium product for the upper end of the market who will have no choice as they age other than to seek an alternative residential setting to live productively. So we see this business as not a nice to but a must have. And Rich, we don't know what that world looks like. We never experienced a world where the 85-plus percentage of the population will start to dominate. And so we think that staying at the top end of that market is a good place to be long term.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question for me and Brinker kind of touched on this when you talked about optionality in the joint venture. Is it a fair way to think about this as -- so post-acute skilled is kind of going through a weak, uncertain patch right now. Bu
componenttext: Okay. And then last question for me and Brinker kind of touched on this when you talked about optionality in the joint venture. Is it a fair way to think about this as -- so post-acute skilled is kind of going through a weak, uncertain patch right now. But longer-term, it could be a great business again depending on how it evolves. And so if you get down to 11% or 12% of your portfolio's post-acute skilled but giving yourself the optionality to get back, are you kind of pining this in some ways where you think ultimately this is a good business and don't want to kind of leave it and that's kind of the mindset that if you might have to take a few steps back and then a few steps forward? Is that how you're thinking about post-acute on, call it, a 10-year horizon type timeframe?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich. We're trying to look forward, so I think you just summed it up well.
componenttext: Yes, Rich. We're trying to look forward, so I think you just summed it up well.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Mike Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Mike Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had a couple of quick follow-ups on asset sales, Tom. I heard your comments about trying to reduce further significant exposure via acquisitions and maybe some asset sales. But can you help us try to put some brackets around dispositions for 2017? It
componenttext: Just had a couple of quick follow-ups on asset sales, Tom. I heard your comments about trying to reduce further significant exposure via acquisitions and maybe some asset sales. But can you help us try to put some brackets around dispositions for 2017? It sounds like you have another $600 million here of skilled nursing tied to Genesis. In the past, you've talked about normalized calling -- call it maybe $300 million, $400 million of just normal core stuff [ph]. So should we think of a base case for 2017 as being that $600 million because it's highly likely plus a few hundred more to kind of get you to $1 billion or so? Is that reasonable?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, that sounds like a reasonable assumption. I think we're giving you a little bit more clarity than we normally do because we've talked about the Genesis portfolio. So yes. I mean we are constantly looking at our assets. We own about a little under 1,
componenttext: Mike, that sounds like a reasonable assumption. I think we're giving you a little bit more clarity than we normally do because we've talked about the Genesis portfolio. So yes. I mean we are constantly looking at our assets. We own about a little under 1,500 buildings today. And we have very dedicated asset management -- a very dedicated asset management function here. So we're always looking at the real estate we own in the markets that we're in and trying to make as educated a decision about which assets we want to own for the long term because that could change every year. So we do the best we can here. I think we have -- I think you've seen some of the systems that we've built here to better assess the long-term viability of the assets we own in the markets that we're in. So I'd say we will always, as we have in the past, disposed of assets in a year. We'll continue to do that in the future, and I think that your assumption is probably a good one.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And last follow-up on that. For the $500 million option for Genesis, I mean what do you think would cause them not to exercise that?
componenttext: Got it. And last follow-up on that. For the $500 million option for Genesis, I mean what do you think would cause them not to exercise that?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they have to raise the capital to do it. So hopefully with this announcement and continued stable operating results, their stock price recovers. One of the benefits at the time of going public 2 years ago is that they would have liquidity to people
componenttext: Well, they have to raise the capital to do it. So hopefully with this announcement and continued stable operating results, their stock price recovers. One of the benefits at the time of going public 2 years ago is that they would have liquidity to people raise equity to buy back assets. So that clearly hasn't gone as planned to date. But our expectation and hope is that the stock will start to rebound as they announce important transactions like this one and stabilize the operations. And they may raise joint venture capital. I think they have a number of options but that would be the biggest one. They clearly like to [indiscernible] so the due diligence in underwriting isn't a problem. They just need to raise the money.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But clearly, major institutions choosing to own Genesis real estate doesn't hurt the story that Scott just outlined. I mean that should all be a positive reflection on Genesis.
componenttext: But clearly, major institutions choosing to own Genesis real estate doesn't hurt the story that Scott just outlined. I mean that should all be a positive reflection on Genesis.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And they can finally turn their attention to that opportunity. They have been bending over backwards to help us, and we'll forever be grateful, to help us get these transactions done. They can only do so many things at once. I mean they're an operati
componenttext: Yes. And they can finally turn their attention to that opportunity. They have been bending over backwards to help us, and we'll forever be grateful, to help us get these transactions done. They can only do so many things at once. I mean they're an operating business not a transaction business. So they've been super helpful and cooperative. This is a good deal for both companies. And now, they'll be able to focus on the $500 million buyback, which is a great opportunity for them.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the changing landscape in senior housing. So over the last couple of days, there have been at least 2 new private capital sources entering the senior housing market, acquiring at sub-7% cap rate. But at the same time, when you look at
componenttext: I had a question on the changing landscape in senior housing. So over the last couple of days, there have been at least 2 new private capital sources entering the senior housing market, acquiring at sub-7% cap rate. But at the same time, when you look at Brookdale's share price, it suggests a dislocation between public and private market values. And given they are one of your major partners, I'm wondering if there's something that you could do bigger with Brookdale?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brookdale is -- has a large footprint in senior housing in this country, and they're dealing with challenges that relate to the Ameritas transaction. We are always looking for opportunities in the senior care space and there may be opportunities that come
componenttext: Brookdale is -- has a large footprint in senior housing in this country, and they're dealing with challenges that relate to the Ameritas transaction. We are always looking for opportunities in the senior care space and there may be opportunities that come from Brookdale or some other senior care operators in the U.S. that are not currently part of the Welltower family of brands. We like the space, we believe in the long-term viability of the space. And we, everyday, look for opportunities to make smart investments in the space.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add. I think it's important, the way we look at transactions always would be like the Genesis. We want transactions that would be a win for Welltower as well as a win for our partners. That's the way we would approach any operating relati
componenttext: And I would just add. I think it's important, the way we look at transactions always would be like the Genesis. We want transactions that would be a win for Welltower as well as a win for our partners. That's the way we would approach any operating relationship.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think Tom mentioned Cindat's interest in Genesis assets and that's partially due to their business in China. But what about their interest in Brookdale? Was that specific to Brookdale? Did they -- did you bring those assess forward to them or did th
componenttext: And I think Tom mentioned Cindat's interest in Genesis assets and that's partially due to their business in China. But what about their interest in Brookdale? Was that specific to Brookdale? Did they -- did you bring those assess forward to them or did they want interest in a national operator like Brookdale?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think like Genesis, I would say that again, Cindat's and Union Life's investment here is to understand how to invest in this sector. And that's not just skilled nursing, it's also senior's housing. If we have a need, a long-term need, for good qua
componenttext: Well, I think like Genesis, I would say that again, Cindat's and Union Life's investment here is to understand how to invest in this sector. And that's not just skilled nursing, it's also senior's housing. If we have a need, a long-term need, for good quality senior care in this country, they've got it multiply higher perspective. So Scott?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's exactly right. They wanted to invest with the best-in-class capital partner and high quality, well known operating partners. And Brookdale and Genesis clearly fit that bill. These are 11 high-quality properties mostly on the West Coast that have co
componenttext: That's exactly right. They wanted to invest with the best-in-class capital partner and high quality, well known operating partners. And Brookdale and Genesis clearly fit that bill. These are 11 high-quality properties mostly on the West Coast that have continued to perform well. So they haven't been as challenged as some of the other maybe portfolios or properties that Brookdale is working through right now. So that's the background.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And given your -- the joint ventures you've established in the past year, and I think your focused on increasing scale. Will you be more focused on AUM growth going forward rather than balance sheet asset growth? Or is balance sheet asset acquisitio
componenttext: Okay. And given your -- the joint ventures you've established in the past year, and I think your focused on increasing scale. Will you be more focused on AUM growth going forward rather than balance sheet asset growth? Or is balance sheet asset acquisitions still a major part of your strategy?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be both.
componenttext: It will be both.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Chad Vanacore with Stifel. And our next question will come from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Chad Vanacore with Stifel. And our next question will come from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the theme of the joint venture, can you share some of the details about the exit or buyout options that exist for you guys within the JV?
componenttext: Just on the theme of the joint venture, can you share some of the details about the exit or buyout options that exist for you guys within the JV?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Todd, I don't want to get into the details of the joint venture but it's pretty straightforward. After 5 years, it's their mutual right to seek liquidity rights. So we're going in with the expectation we're going to do more with Union Life and Cindat. But
componenttext: Todd, I don't want to get into the details of the joint venture but it's pretty straightforward. After 5 years, it's their mutual right to seek liquidity rights. So we're going in with the expectation we're going to do more with Union Life and Cindat. But it's nice to know for both of us that that's there if we choose to change our exposure to the post-acute space 5 years from now one way or the other.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on acquisitions, is it limited to just the U.S.? I mean is this something that you could enter China with one of the partners or both? What constraints or what opportunities exist?
componenttext: And then on acquisitions, is it limited to just the U.S.? I mean is this something that you could enter China with one of the partners or both? What constraints or what opportunities exist?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Todd, we see tremendous opportunities in the markets that we already have a foothold in. One of the things we've said, we're not prepared to go into markets unless we're prepared to put significant boots on the ground like we have in the U.K. and like we
componenttext: Todd, we see tremendous opportunities in the markets that we already have a foothold in. One of the things we've said, we're not prepared to go into markets unless we're prepared to put significant boots on the ground like we have in the U.K. and like we have in Toronto. And actually, we're putting significant boots on the ground in Los Angeles because of the percentage of assets that we will own that are in South California. So we see lots of opportunities in those markets, and we're not very actively looking for opportunities outside of those markets.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to stay with you, Tom, if you don't mind. You touched on Brookdale's large national footprint. Kind of in that theme and consistent how you allocated operators to certain markets around the country like you did with the recent Californ
componenttext: Okay. And then just to stay with you, Tom, if you don't mind. You touched on Brookdale's large national footprint. Kind of in that theme and consistent how you allocated operators to certain markets around the country like you did with the recent California acquisition, do you see operators becoming more sharpshooters like the Silverados or the Brandywines as opposed to more national operators?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Todd. I do think so. I think that you will see some of these operators go maybe expand a little bit across state borders. I mean some of them were just in one given state with great concentration. I think you'll see some of them ex
componenttext: That's a good question, Todd. I do think so. I think that you will see some of these operators go maybe expand a little bit across state borders. I mean some of them were just in one given state with great concentration. I think you'll see some of them expand regionally. But I would say other than Sunrise and Brookdale, we don't see any of our operators having great aspirations to develop a national footprint. We think there are a lot of benefits in having a deep position in quality markets, and that's what we like to see.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question will come from the line of Smedes Rose with Citi Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question will come from the line of Smedes Rose with Citi Research.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman with Smedes. Scott Estes, I was wondering if you can just provide a little bit more clarity in terms of the run rate. And as you said, the fourth quarter implied we can get to, which is about $1.05 to $1,10, $1.11. But obviously, the
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman with Smedes. Scott Estes, I was wondering if you can just provide a little bit more clarity in terms of the run rate. And as you said, the fourth quarter implied we can get to, which is about $1.05 to $1,10, $1.11. But obviously, the timing of the dispositions and the reinvestment of those proceeds has a significant effect to where you are sort of December 31 on a quarterly basis. And so it would be really helpful just to understand what that quarterly number is, to know where our starting point is from an annualized perspective heading into '17.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand the desire for clarity. I think I got to stick with our numbers. You have a blended yield on disposition proceeds right there at 8%. You have a blended yield that you can calculate. I would assume that all the proceeds come in right at year e
componenttext: I understand the desire for clarity. I think I got to stick with our numbers. You have a blended yield on disposition proceeds right there at 8%. You have a blended yield that you can calculate. I would assume that all the proceeds come in right at year end. And then obviously we're going to work as fast as we can so you can make some general assumptions on some of the things like secured debt may take a few months to pay off. And the preferred stock, as I mentioned, is March. But that's really the way you're going to get the run rate from the number you just cited for the fourth quarter. And I would tell you more importantly, the first quarter really isn't that important. We're going to get all these things done. We have all the benefits attended. We're going to work as fast as we can and give you updates. And there's a lot of things that will help 2017 earnings that I mentioned like the same-store NOI growth and development and acquisitions. So we'll give you a full update in February.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- I mean just doing the simple math, you have about $0.09 of quarterly dilution. So how much of that -- it sounds like that -- most of that $0.09 is not in the $1.05 to $1.11 of the fourth quarter. The only reason I'm asking, The Streets at $4.70 for
componenttext: So -- I mean just doing the simple math, you have about $0.09 of quarterly dilution. So how much of that -- it sounds like that -- most of that $0.09 is not in the $1.05 to $1.11 of the fourth quarter. The only reason I'm asking, The Streets at $4.70 for next year clearly with almost $0.40 cents of dilution from doing this and then potential other dilution from the sales into next year. Again putting aside all the benefits you'll get from the development coming online same store, there's a significant amount of earnings that will have to come off. And I think -- I just want to better understand how much of that $0.09 of dilution is actually in the $1.05 to $1.11 in the fourth quarter. It sounds like it's nothing.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, they way to answer that is we talked about closing about $1.1 billion or $1.2 billion of the Genesis transaction that was just announced today. So you have about that amount that's already in the numbers. So assume November 1. And then I woul
componenttext: I would say, they way to answer that is we talked about closing about $1.1 billion or $1.2 billion of the Genesis transaction that was just announced today. So you have about that amount that's already in the numbers. So assume November 1. And then I would assume the rest of the numbers are roughly at the end of the quarter.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then from a balance sheet perspective, that's the other part of it in terms of the deleveraging, it sounded like you rather stay at these levels, 5x debt to EBITDA, mid-30s from the debt underappreciated book so that we should expect any future
componenttext: Okay. And then from a balance sheet perspective, that's the other part of it in terms of the deleveraging, it sounded like you rather stay at these levels, 5x debt to EBITDA, mid-30s from the debt underappreciated book so that we should expect any future investment should be funded either by increased EBITDA leveraging that or through additional sales are new common equity. Is that a fair way to characterize it? Or do you want to have the ability to go back up to the mid-5 debt to EBITDA and towards the 40s debt unappreciated book? How should we think about the goal posts?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would think that modeling for everyone generally on a leverage neutral basis based on these new numbers is the way to go. And we obviously would have those options available to us if we saw good options and have always been pretty conservative. But mode
componenttext: I would think that modeling for everyone generally on a leverage neutral basis based on these new numbers is the way to go. And we obviously would have those options available to us if we saw good options and have always been pretty conservative. But modeling-wise, I would say assume leverage neutral based on these new numbers.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then can you just review a little bit the loan receivable book at least at quarter end for Page 20 of the sup is at $950 million. Memory serves, that excludes the development loans you have outstanding. You have another $150 million coming into the fo
componenttext: And then can you just review a little bit the loan receivable book at least at quarter end for Page 20 of the sup is at $950 million. Memory serves, that excludes the development loans you have outstanding. You have another $150 million coming into the fourth quarter, $75 million of which was the note you took back from Genesis. So you're going to be at $1.1 billion. Can you sort of review the chunks of that in terms of cash pay versus PI and any large sort of borrowers in that $1.1 billion?

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. I'm happy to try to give some color. Those big pictures that we rarely, if ever, make loans is a standalone business model. It's always done to support an important real estate relationship. In many cases, the loan is secured by real estate
componenttext: Yes, Michael. I'm happy to try to give some color. Those big pictures that we rarely, if ever, make loans is a standalone business model. It's always done to support an important real estate relationship. In many cases, the loan is secured by real estate and is reflected that way on our balance sheet. The loan balance is a bit higher than it has been in the past, roughly $1 billion. We're actually expecting substantial repayments in the fourth quarter from Genesis and others. So I think you'll see that loan balance decline going forward even though we are taking back the $75 million of loans from Genesis, and it should meaningfully decline if you take a longer-term view into the late 2017 timeframe.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how much of -- so what's the current yield on that $1 billion? How much is cash pay versus PIK? And if -- because my assumption is if it's producing higher than average earnings, right, so high -- pretty high-yield, the reinvestment asset loan balance
componenttext: And how much of -- so what's the current yield on that $1 billion? How much is cash pay versus PIK? And if -- because my assumption is if it's producing higher than average earnings, right, so high -- pretty high-yield, the reinvestment asset loan balance comes, there's another sort of dilutive effect to earnings and cash flow.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that is definitely the case. The yield on most of the loans is in the high single digits, if not, 10% on average. The vast majority, Michael, is cash pay. There are a couple that have PIK interest, including these take back notes from Genesis but tha
componenttext: Yes, that is definitely the case. The yield on most of the loans is in the high single digits, if not, 10% on average. The vast majority, Michael, is cash pay. There are a couple that have PIK interest, including these take back notes from Genesis but that's the exception.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is there any concentration within that $1 billion in terms of to a certain borrower? Like what are the top 2 or 3 borrowers in that? And how much is real estate versus non-real estate? There's a footnote that says some of it's non-real estate.
componenttext: And is there any concentration within that $1 billion in terms of to a certain borrower? Like what are the top 2 or 3 borrowers in that? And how much is real estate versus non-real estate? There's a footnote that says some of it's non-real estate.

headline: Welltower Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. By far, the biggest amount is with Genesis. So there's the $330-or-so million of first mortgage loans on our books as of September 30. That number will continue to decline going forward. And then there's the $72 million term loan that we made to Gene
componenttext: Yes. By far, the biggest amount is with Genesis. So there's the $330-or-so million of first mortgage loans on our books as of September 30. That number will continue to decline going forward. And then there's the $72 million term loan that we made to Genesis last quarter that's not secured by real estate. And then we'll add this additional $75 million note to Genesis here in the fourth quarter. That's, by far, the biggest component of the $1 billion.

componenttext: Yes. I want to start by clarifying a couple of things. One is the coverage that we talked about is after management fee. So not everybody reports that way. That's important. The coverage before management fee is often 40 basis points higher. The second clarification is that, that coverage ratio that you talked about, Karin, is for the entire long-term post-acute portfolio. It's not for Genesis in particular. And then as to your specific question, it's 10 basis points higher than it is today. So we're definitely happy about that. We like it to be higher. But at this point, I would say it's above market, not below market. And the evidence for that would be 2 very sophisticated and knowledgeable investors. Lindsay Goldberg and Omega just bought Genesis assets at roughly 1.3 coverage, plus or minus. So we feel good about having 1.45. We hope it keeps going higher, but it's certainly not below market.
